From carla at bratgrrl.com  Sat Nov  1 07:25:03 2003
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sat Nov  1 07:25:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] running a mixed Debian system
In-Reply-To: <1067639904.21374.74.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <200310301539.50145.carla@bratgrrl.com> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0310310010270.29388@shaft.bitmine.net> <1067639904.21374.74.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <200311010724.31956.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Friday 31 October 2003 2:38 pm, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> The crux of the problem with saying distributions
> are just about package management is that
> unlocking a distribution and getting the most
> benefit out of it over say spending the extra
> time to build your own thing from source is
> one of the major reasons to use distributions.
>
It's more than package management, though that is a large part of it. Debian 
Woody, for example, is rock-solid stable and thoroughly tested. debs are not 
accepted into Woody without meeting stringent requirements. Dependencies are 
also torture-tested. 

The beauty of apt-get is it satisfies dependencies all on its own. RPM cannot 
do this. Because RPM cannot fetch packages to satisfy dependencies, apt-rpm 
and urpmi were created. And Red Carpet, and up2date, and doubtless more.

> I think the rpm idea is fine, problem is the
> dependency database needs to be trainable so
> that if say I compile something on an rpm
> system I can find out what packages on that
> system need to be installed for it to work
> installing it as a package with those
> dependencies. 

There are ways to do this. One is to use source RPMs. Another is Paul 
Heinlein's kewl fake spec file hack, which has been posted here a couple of 
times. This is the way to go for libs that are already installed. The easy 
way is to use CheckInstall. The neat thing about CheckInstall is you don't 
have to wait for someone to create a deb, rpm, apt-rpm, Red Carpet, etc. 
package. It works with any source tarball. But it's not retroactive, like 
Paul's hack.

--

www.tuxcomputing.com

On Fri, 2003-10-31 at 12:09, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> On Thu, 2003-10-30 at 22:56, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> > Note also that you probably do NOT want to put a PCI wireless card into
> > a typical desktop.
> 
> Derek Loree wrote:
> > The PCI wireless cards themselves are fine, its the antennae that they
> > come with that suck so bad.  At least get a 3 or 4 foot cable with a
> > desk mount antenna.
> 
> Good point - but the antennae are a bit harder to find.  Also, note that
> there will be significant cable losses if you try to go more than a few
> feet, or aren't using top-quality cable.

True, but some loss is worth it, to get the antenna out from behind the
metal box.  A larger antenna will make up for the loss, and may even
increase the gain.  The internet has a lot of sites selling antennae,
some are better quality others, some a cheaper than others.
>   
> 
> I found it easier to just perch a WAP on a high shelf, and run ethernet
> and power up to it.  Antenna placement can be nasty.
> 
That is why I recommended a desk mount model.
> 
> Derek Loree wrote:
> > I haven't tried to build a wireless network with only external WAP's,
> > how is that done?  Ad-hoc (or peer-to-peer) mode?
> 
> No, regular old managed mode, with the WAP serving DHCP and so forth.
> I suppose there could be problems with handoff - I only have one WAP,
> so I haven't worked that out yet.  You will have the same problem with
> PCI/Linux-box wireless systems;  you will need to make the systems hand
> off connection information one to another.  It can be done.
> 
One device does not make a network.  I assume that there will be other
computers, both mobile and stationary that will need to operate in the
same subnet.  In my opinion, it will be easier to add PCI cards to the
stationary computers, and use one of these as the Access Point.
> 
> Derek Loree wrote:
> > I've had lots of problems with the off the shelf WAP's, a lot more than
> > when running a PC based linux firewall/AP with a PCI card.  It is
> > infinitely more configurable, and much more user friendly to have your
> > connection inside your box.
> 
> Sometimes infinite configurability is NOT a feature :-).  But that
> wouldn't be us, would it?  :-) :-)
> 
> The problem with most wireless cards is that many do not have Linux
> drivers, and the manufacturers have a tendency to change chipsets and
> keep the same model number.  I'd guess that 60% of the hardware on the
> shelf at Fry's doesn't have Linux drivers.  If you do a LOT of research
> before buying, you can probably reliably buy a card with a supported
> chipset.
> 
> On the other hand, if you get a web-configurable WAP, you may not get
> all the configurability you would like, and you might not be able to
> coordinate a mesh of WAPs, but you are almost guaranteed compatability,
> because web browsers are mostly OS agnostic.  And you can usually find
> out about web-configurability from the product box.
> 
> Case in point - I purchased a Siemens PCMCIA card for my laptop, and
> a Siemens WAP, real cheap from Frys.  Well, the PCMCIA card uses the
> TI chipset (on the wlan website, it says PRISM2) and while there is 
> a Linux driver development program going on, it is nowhere near ready
> for prime time.  

I have a similar story about 2 Siemens PCI cards, both the same model
number, bought at the same time, one had linux drivers and is still
working, the other had to go back because it had no linux drivers.  That
is why I recommended the MA311, it always (at least so far) has the same
chipset.

> The WAP, on the other hand, was up and running in about
> 30 minutes with DHCP, 128 bit WEP, and similar goodies.  Granted, I was
> *not* able to do things like force a fixed address for the laptop, and
> the WAP wants to be its own little firewall, but I can live with such
> annoyances.
> 
> When I go for configurability, I will either use an old laptop as an
> access point, or I will go for a Soekris box.  Either way, I can 
> move the box right up next to the antenna, and I will be using a
> PCMCIA card.  Given that the PCMCIA cards are cheaper (higher volume,
> and the PCI cards are often a PCMCIA card mounted in a box on a PC
> board) and more versatile, and don't need extra cabling to get to
> a decent antenna mount point, this is probably a better way to go.
> 
Used PC's are much easier to find than laptops, and they run linux
headless, plunk them where you want and forget about them, especially if
they don't have harddrives.  Replacement parts are cheap too.

> BTW, I hope to take one of my old TP560 laptops and put a couple of
> PRISM2 PCMCIA cards in it, make it into a WAP/repeater, and broadcast
> "Radio Free Linux" from my attic.  Since my comcast TOS does not permit
> me to broadcast internet access, I will probably just serve up local
> content - a dozen or so downloadable Linux distros.
> 
I sure do like my DSL, it has no restrictions about services.  But I
also like my bandwidth, so my linux AP is encrypted, firewalled and on a
separate subnet.

Derek Loree

Carla Schroder said:
> The beauty of apt-get is it satisfies dependencies all on its own.
> RPM cannot  do this. Because RPM cannot fetch packages to satisfy
> dependencies, apt-rpm  and urpmi were created. And Red Carpet, and
> up2date, and doubtless more.

Dpkg can't do that either. I always thought apt vs. rpm was a bad
comparison. Put your SAT analogy hat on:

Redhat : rpm
Debian : _____

The answer is dpkg, not apt. Dpkg is "the package maintenance system
for Debian". Apt is a dependency resolving front-end for dpkg. Here's
a more fair analogy:

Debian : apt
Redhat : _____

Yum, apt-rpm, up2date, urpmi, etc. all fit here. Dependency resolving
front-ends for the package management tool, rpm.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

From drl at drloree.com  Sat Nov  1 10:47:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sat Nov  1 10:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] running a mixed Debian system
In-Reply-To: <200310301539.50145.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200310301539.50145.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1067712393.1961.615.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Thu, 2003-10-30 at 15:39, Carla Schroder wrote:
> Any particular issues with running a mixed stable/testing system? Or 
> testing/unstable? Can the unwary user get sucked into Dependency Hell Slough, 
> or does it generally work OK?

I've been thinking about this, and I would have to say, that in general
it will work OK.  The Debian system is designed to build your
distribution from as many sources as you want.  The majority of linux
developers create .deb's, and most can be added to your sources.list
without any problems.  The usual problem is that a package will have a
dependency that can't be filled from the sources, and the fix is to find
a source that has the dependency.

As an example, earlier this week, I did a "Sarge" install.  I did the
usual install a minimal Woody first, then change the sources.list to
point to Sarge instead of Stable, updated, then started installing
software.  Evolution wouldn't install, it had an unmet dependency.  When
I added "Stable" to the sources.list, the missing pieces were found and
Evolution was installed.

I think the problems occur when you start building software systems that
are dependent on specific versions of libraries.  As an example, the
developer will create code that has work-arounds to bugs in the library,
and when the bugs get fixed (in the next release), the work-arounds will
break.  This kind of defeats the purpose of the concept of "this package
depends on this library version foo or higher".  Most of the time,
though, new versions of libraries will not lose functions, just gain
them.

I guess what I'm saying is that the problems of running mixed sources
are more developer problems, not user problems.

HTH,

Derek Loree

> I could just get a PCI card and an antenna, but are there WAPs that'll act

I certainly don't - such a setup would definitely be unique.  My
Wireless Bridging Router has a WAN ethernet port on the back for that.

> Hrm, also need to figure out where all the campus WAPs are so I can choose
> an apartment with good line-of-sight...

If you go searching around PSU's online help pages, you'll find a
diagram of what areas of campus are covered by Pubnet and which aren't.

I'm going to assume you're a student.

I watched some jackass hack in to pubnet a few weeks ago, kicking an
authorized user off in the process.  That's not cool, if you ask me,
especially when you consider how much the authorized user is paying in
tuition.

I really don't think Pubnet is meant to be used as somebody's full-time
Internet connection.  Hopefully you aren't breaking the AUP in the
process.  But, considering how much tuition you are hopefully paying, I
certainly don't see a problem with it.

Rob

Here you go:

  http://www.superpass.com

Here's a strong radio:

  http://www.superpass.com/SP-AP-TE-EX1S.html

Here's a very nice omni:

  http://www.superpass.com/SPDG16OP.html

I note that I don't see the radio sold without the antenna. Ask "John"
to see if he still does that.

Short of that, the prices are reasonable and the radios themselves use
standard N connectors. One can "light up" the entire neighborhood with
these radios attached to a directional panel. 

I once performed a wireless installation that was an RF nightmare, metal
shelving with auto parts stacked on them, steel grate floor, etc. I have
to say that these components worked exceptionally a lot better than I
expected. I was able to heat up the entire office (both floors) and the
outside yard area (perhaps .5 acres) with only two radios!

I hope this helps!


Best,


Cooper

> > because web browsers are mostly OS agnostic.  And you can usually find
> > out about web-configurability from the product box.
> > 
> > Case in point - I purchased a Siemens PCMCIA card for my laptop, and
> > a Siemens WAP, real cheap from Frys.  Well, the PCMCIA card uses the
> > TI chipset (on the wlan website, it says PRISM2) and while there is 
> > a Linux driver development program going on, it is nowhere near ready
> > for prime time.  
> 
> I have a similar story about 2 Siemens PCI cards, both the same model
> number, bought at the same time, one had linux drivers and is still
> working, the other had to go back because it had no linux drivers.  That
> is why I recommended the MA311, it always (at least so far) has the same
> chipset.
> 
> > The WAP, on the other hand, was up and running in about
> > 30 minutes with DHCP, 128 bit WEP, and similar goodies.  Granted, I was
> > *not* able to do things like force a fixed address for the laptop, and
> > the WAP wants to be its own little firewall, but I can live with such
> > annoyances.
> > 
> > When I go for configurability, I will either use an old laptop as an
> > access point, or I will go for a Soekris box.  Either way, I can 
> > move the box right up next to the antenna, and I will be using a
> > PCMCIA card.  Given that the PCMCIA cards are cheaper (higher volume,
> > and the PCI cards are often a PCMCIA card mounted in a box on a PC
> > board) and more versatile, and don't need extra cabling to get to
> > a decent antenna mount point, this is probably a better way to go.
> > 
> Used PC's are much easier to find than laptops, and they run linux
> headless, plunk them where you want and forget about them, especially if
> they don't have harddrives.  Replacement parts are cheap too.
> 
> > BTW, I hope to take one of my old TP560 laptops and put a couple of
> > PRISM2 PCMCIA cards in it, make it into a WAP/repeater, and broadcast
> > "Radio Free Linux" from my attic.  Since my comcast TOS does not permit
> > me to broadcast internet access, I will probably just serve up local
> > content - a dozen or so downloadable Linux distros.
> > 
> I sure do like my DSL, it has no restrictions about services.  But I
> also like my bandwidth, so my linux AP is encrypted, firewalled and on a
> separate subnet.
> 
> Derek Loree
>

From galamar at creative-designs-ltd.com  Sat Nov  1 13:10:04 2003
From: galamar at creative-designs-ltd.com (Chris Healy)
Date: Sat Nov  1 13:10:04 2003
Subject: [PLUG] running a mixed Debian system
In-Reply-To: <1067717881.26184.103.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <00d401c3a0bc$84dd7e70$0a00a8c0@PORTLAND>

Hello all!

I'm a new member of this mailing list, and with luck a new member of the
group.  I have spent some time reading this thread this morning and
think I finally have something to add, so here goes.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Michael C. Robinson
> I've had trouble more than once.  I can exclude non Unix
> systems and still have plenty to do.  It would be good
> to know multiple systems, but I see no need to even
> work with the general public in Windows as Linux and
> other alternatives are quite mature.

The question of heterogeneous network integration is not a matter of OS
maturity.  It's a matter of reality.  As a system admin you are
responsible for making sure everyone that uses your network can get
there job done, and inevitably this will include someone using a
microsnot product. It's inescapable (For the most part). It might be as
simple as how to troubleshoot why Joe blow's Outlook won't get his mail,
or configuring the networking on his box so he can get out to the net.
Someone in the organization is most likely running a windoze system.  

Of course, this doesn't mean you have to know the nitty gritty of
everything about all the OS's.  I couldn't configure XP's web server if
my life depended on it right now. But I am more then capable at using
windoze as a client system, which in reality, is most of what you will
run into as a Linux admin.  

At least, this is what I have run into.  95% of the technical calls, and
troubleshooting requests I get, are in relation to someone trying to use
their windoze system, to do something on the Linux system. 

-- Chris Healy

From galamar at creative-designs-ltd.com  Sat Nov  1 13:38:02 2003
From: galamar at creative-designs-ltd.com (Chris Healy)
Date: Sat Nov  1 13:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] running a mixed Debian system

> From: Felix Lee
> 
> Aaron Burt <aaron at speakeasy.org>:
> > And don't focus on Linux to the exclusion of other stuff.  Any dope
can
> > learn to admin a homogenous, unchanging system.  Mixed environments
and
> > integration are where the action's at.
> 
> yeah.  I'd add, keep in mind this is all transient technology.
> in five years it will be all different.  learn fundamentals and
> flexibility.

I'd say evolutionary, not transient.  

And also need to disagree about things being all that different in 5
years. Looking back over the last 5, or even 10 years, things haven't
changed that much.  The quantum leaps just don't happen.  Even looking
back to the inception of windoze wasn't that shocking as point and
click, menus, and general mouse usage had been in use back in the days
of DOS.  

Linux itself has changed even less over the years.  Sure, it's more
stable, more secure, easier to use, and more efficient. Bt when you get
down to it, FTP is still FTP.  Email still works the same as it pretty
much always has (Email is how old?  30+ years?). We still use TCP/IP to
send info back and forth.  Even the web itself had predecessors, WAIS,
and Gopher.  

Only the content seems to change. I bet that won't change in the next 5
or even 20 years. 

So gain a strong footing now, hold on, and enjoy the ride.  Getting
started is the hardest. Everything else comes in little bits.  Small
improvements here and there, and subtle changes. The rest is easy.

-- Chris Healy

> > infinitely more configurable, and much more user friendly to have your
> > connection inside your box.

> On the other hand, if you get a web-configurable WAP, you may not get
> all the configurability you would like, and you might not be able to
> coordinate a mesh of WAPs, but you are almost guaranteed compatability,
> because web browsers are mostly OS agnostic.  And you can usually find
> out about web-configurability from the product box.

> When I go for configurability, I will either use an old laptop as an
> access point, or I will go for a Soekris box.  Either way, I can 
> move the box right up next to the antenna, and I will be using a
> PCMCIA card.  Given that the PCMCIA cards are cheaper (higher volume,
> and the PCI cards are often a PCMCIA card mounted in a box on a PC
> board) and more versatile, and don't need extra cabling to get to
> a decent antenna mount point, this is probably a better way to go.

There is a semi-middle ground, the Linksys APs. They've got a web
interface, but they're also known to use Linux as their OS. They don't
appear to be officially supporting directly talking to the OS, but it is
possible to do. TiVo-hacking anyone?

I started thinking about it, and don't see any way they could secure
Pubnet from issues like this.  Maybe some of you have ideas?

The best thing I could come up with was using WEP and only letting
students know what the WEP key was - but that's so easily leaked.

You see, you can easily capture packets going through the air, with the
MAC addresses attached.  How easy is it to forge a MAC address?  Then
obtain a new DHCP lease with the forged MAC, essentially kicking the
other guy off?

Way too easy, unfortunately.

You don't need to crack the password at all.

The problem with that is some professors actually make books and make
them only available at the PSU bookstore.  When I say make books, I mean
they make them out of parts of other books.

All too often they also will say you only need one or two of the three
or four books they list for the class - and only list the books for the
class at the bookstore.  Oh, and the bookstore doesn't tell you what
ISBNs go with which classes, you have to go and physically look up the
ISBNs from the books listed with each class.

For this reason, I rarely purchase my books before the class begins. 
Before the third class is usually good.

Purchasing from an online source requires you wait for shipping, and the
last time I depended upon an online bookstore to ship something within a
reasonable amount of time, I found I was up a creek without a paddle.

It would all be fine if the bookstore practiced reasonable ethics. 

If they find out the number of students in a class, they only order
80-90% of the books that would be needed if everybody bought their
books, regardless of what the professor says.  For a 101-level class,
the droppage rate isn't very high, and this makes things difficult when
the professor makes his own book.

Their prices are inflated, yet they claim they are low, because it is
run for the students, by the students, or some BS like that.  If you
don't look around, you may actually think they prices are low.  If you
look around, though, you're very dissapointed.

The PSU bookstore just plain sucks.

Rob

Hi,

While getting a Masters degree and later teaching at PSU, I was on the
board of the bookstore.  

For a lot of complex reasons it is very hard to just break even let alone
make a profit in the retail college bookstore business.  Nobody at the PSU
bookstore is getting rich.

Also, like many college bookstores, the one at PSU is a member owned co-op.
 If they displease you, you can do something about it.

Finally, like many instructors, I advise students to checkout bookpool.com
or one of the isbn search engines before going to the bookstore.  Lately,
safari.com has also been an option.

Cheers,
Mike

P.S.  The Linux classes at PCC do focus on Linux.

From felix.1 at canids.net  Sat Nov  1 16:04:02 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Sat Nov  1 16:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] running a mixed Debian system 
In-Reply-To: <00d501c3a0c0$5cfceb30$0a00a8c0@PORTLAND> 
    on Sat, 01 Nov 2003 13:37:29 PST
    from "Chris Healy" <galamar@creative-designs-ltd.com> 
Message-ID: <20031102000302.CE5DD158D80@kanga.canids.net>

"Chris Healy" <galamar at creative-designs-ltd.com>:
> And also need to disagree about things being all that different in 5
> years. Looking back over the last 5, or even 10 years, things haven't
> changed that much.  The quantum leaps just don't happen.  Even looking
> back to the inception of windoze wasn't that shocking as point and
> click, menus, and general mouse usage had been in use back in the days
> of DOS.

you're rewriting history with hindsight.  ten years ago, the IT
landscape was still dominated by mainframes and COBOL, and
"client-server" was a new buzzword, it was going to be all sorts
of things that people do now with web browser "thin clients".

and there were lots of interesting projects that just died.
nobody knows anything about Plan 9 or the Connection Machine or
whatever any more.  token ring networks were going to be hot,
floptical discs too, etc.  and who would have thought we'd still
be using plain SMTP for email instead of X.400 or whatever?

ten years ago, you couldn't have planned for the shape of the
Internet today.  it's _hard_ to guess which technologies will
become important and which ones will disappear without a trace.

and that's true for any stage of the game we're in.  perhaps the
future ten years from now is going to be based on something
that's here today, but who has time to follow the hundreds of
things that are going to die, just so you don't miss the one
thing that doesn't?

if you want to "play it smart" and go with the clear winners, ten
years ago it was IBM, "nobody ever got fired for buying IBM".
today it's Microsoft.  Google Zeitgeist has a chart of users by
Operating System.  last year it said:
  92% Windows, 4% Mac, 1% Linux, 3% Other
today it says:
  91% Windows, 3% Mac, 1% Linux, 5% Other
the changes seem unlikely to be statistically significant, but if
you want to read the future from it, the Microsoft empire is
going to become toppled by something in "Other".  what's it going
to be?  how are you going to find it?

it's all a crapshoot.  just pick a few things that are fun and
useful enough for now, and stay flexible.
--

very disappointed.  I didn't stay in part because
this instructor fighting the other prof seemed to be 
coming onto me too which decidedly wasn't the thing to 
stick around for.  It wouldn't have looked good to get 
a grade from her.  The environment wasn't safe 
where I had no interest in even the possibility 
of somehow ending up between these two.

So no, the prostitutes comment is not an accurate
one as far as what's "fun."

As far as mixed debian which is what this thread is about...
I'm wondering why mix stable and unstable source code?
Is the idea here to have a stable and unstable system
installed on the same partitions functioning as any
normal stable or unstable system would?  This I would
think ought to translate to multiple root paths and
library paths.  How about user mode linux here, maybe 
that is what's needed.

On Sat, Nov 01, 2003 at 10:46:33AM -0800, Derek Loree wrote:
> As an example, earlier this week, I did a "Sarge" install.  I did the
> usual install a minimal Woody first, then change the sources.list to
> point to Sarge instead of Stable, updated, then started installing
> software.  Evolution wouldn't install, it had an unmet dependency.  When
> I added "Stable" to the sources.list, the missing pieces were found and
> Evolution was installed.

That is the nature of testing, though I would strongly recommend
pinning to testing and using unstable instead of stable for a source.
Less likely to run into twisted breakages that have been known to
result from mixing stable with anything newer.

the homophobic label in this city, it's one of the major 
problems here.  Look what happened to Kroeker who debatedly 
wasn't after gays as so many claim, and I'm sure
there is or will be an even less controversial example.  
I've heard that Katz micromanages and that this is what 
lead to his resignation.  

It's a tragedy that Kendra got shot, but why is the officer 
involved taking the heat if he was following proper police 
policy?  Some have said that Katz created a situation to get
Kroeker to resign.  Maybe Kroeker had problems, though 
looking at this and other situations one can conclude that 
the politics in Portland stink.  Is the wrong person taking
the media heat?  A good leader should eat crow instead of 
sacrificing the underlings for political gain.

A certain segment of the gay community is very outspoken 
in Portland which the Kroeker controversy proved.  Further 
proof is the litmus test many have tried to throw against 
Smith.  Do you have to be pro gay in this state to get 
elected?  What exactly does that mean?  It's interesting 
that the opinions flip, perhaps too far, on many issues 
when you get a few miles out from Portland.  I don't 
want to see people hung because they are thought to be 
gay, but I don't approve of this are you pro gay litmus 
test that is getting to be well known around Portland
either.  

I don't care for the filibusters that are preventing Bush 
from exercising his authority to fill vacancies in the 
supreme court either.  Does our president have this 
authority?  What are the implications of him losing it?

Because of the politically hostile nature of Portland even
for a quiet person, it's just not a place I want to be.  
To some degree I could tell certain people to leave me 
alone, but why should I live where I'd have to do that? 
Why do I have to conform to Portland when it ought to 
conform to me?  I'm not inflexible, but there's a limit.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Nov  2 13:09:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sun Nov  2 13:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] clever way to do construct all-pairs
Message-ID: <86ekwqiimj.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

Consider a list of information in a text file, with columns

  id  meas  val1 val2 ... valn
   1    1    ...
   1    2    ...
   1    3    ...
   2    1    ...
   2    2    ... 
   3    1    ...
   3    2    ... 
   3    3    ...
   3    4    ...
   [...]

Within "id", I want to match all possible pairs of meas:

  id  meas_a val1_a val2_a ... valn_a meas_b val1_b val2_b ... val2_n
   1      1  ...                          2  ...
   1      1  ...                          3  ...
   1      2  ...                          3  ...
   2      1  ...                          2  ...
   3      1  ...                          2  ...
   3      1  ...                          3  ...
   3      1  ...                          4  ...
   3      2  ...                          3  ...
   3      2  ...                          4  ...
   3      3  ...                          4  ...
   [...]

I am doing something like:

awk '$1 != last { n = 1 ; a[n++] = $0 }
     $1 == last { a[n++] = $0 ; for (i=1 ; i<n-1 ; i++) { print a[i],$0 } }
     { last = $1 }' input-file

Can anyone thing of any thing more clever or clean?

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Nov  2 16:27:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun Nov  2 16:27:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Bookstore pointers
Message-ID: <20031103002558.GA31471@gate.kl-ic.com>

>A particularly handy website for finding them is http://isbn.nu

Thanks for adding to the list.  Other good bookstore links:

www.addall.com   (searches other lists)
www.amazon.com   (reviews, ISBN, sometimes even worth buying from)
www.powells.com  (it's local, sometimes it's on the shelf)

The faster you want a book, the more expensive it will be.  The earlier you
start looking, the cheaper you can find a book in time to start classes.
Perhaps things are different now, but when I was in college, I could
usually find out from an instructor weeks in advance of posted schedules
what the text would be.  That meant I could find the cheapest copies
available (I usually had my pick of the used copies) and it also meant
I could skim the book and read a few chapters before class started. 
And that meant that I could stay ahead of the curve rather than grimly
race to catch up.

Keith

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sun Nov  2 17:26:05 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sun Nov  2 17:26:05 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NTFS driver on RedHat
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F706FDsQO8qPLl00095b69@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F706FDsQO8qPLl00095b69@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <1067822679.11435.42.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Sun, 2003-11-02 at 17:19, VVV YYY wrote:
> Yeah, that is exactly what I would like to do.  Mount another Window box 
> NTFS partition
> and read it from my Linux box.
> 
> So you don't recommend it?

You misunderstand... as long as the Windows box has it shared out, it
doesn't matter if it's NTFS, FAT, or whatever else (as long as Windows
can read it without any problems).

Just set up sharing on the Windows Box and set up Samba on the linux box
to mount it.  If the Windows box is shared without any passwords or
anything, you can probably just do a:

mount -t smbfs //windowscomputername/sharename /where/you/want/it/mounted

And have it there.

Rob




From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Sun Nov  2 17:28:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Sun Nov  2 17:28:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NTFS driver on RedHat
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F706FDsQO8qPLl00095b69@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0311021725180.15357-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

If it's NTFS partition on the same PC which runs Linux (i.e. you
dual-boot) you can read it, you may need to compile the ntfs.o module in
the kernel (in some versions of RH this module is available, in others
they compiled the kernel with NTFS option disabled in config).

If the partition is on another machine, you don't even care that it's
NTFS, enable sharing on that Windows machine and use samba to access the
shared partitions.

From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Nov  2 17:31:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sun Nov  2 17:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NTFS driver on RedHat
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F706FDsQO8qPLl00095b69@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F706FDsQO8qPLl00095b69@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <200311021730.09090.russj@dimstar.net>

On Sunday 02 November 2003 05:19 pm, VVV YYY wrote:
> Yeah, that is exactly what I would like to do.  Mount another Window box
> NTFS partition
> and read it from my Linux box.
>
> So you don't recommend it?

NTFS isn't a networking file system. 

NT/XP/W2K/W2K3 share these file systems via the SMB protocol. If you are 
wanting to mount any partition that exists on a windows based machine, you 
look into installing samba on your *nix box. Alternatively, you install an 
NFSd driver on the Windows system to share the drives out via NFS.

The NTFS driver project is so that you can mount a drive locally. I.e. You 
physically move the hard drive from the Windows machine to your linux box, 
and then mount it there.

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sun Nov  2 17:35:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sun Nov  2 17:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Digital audio connection problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0311021720570.15357-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0311021720570.15357-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <3FA5B0B8.9000103@pacifier.com>

Fedor Pikus wrote:
> I've got a new DVD drive (Pioneer 106 recorder), and it has a 4-pin
> digital audio connector. Until now I've only seen 2-pin digital audio
> (spdif), that's what my previous drive had, and that's what my sound card
> has (one might guess by now that the cable also has two wires). Now this
> device has four. Anyone knows the pinout for such connection? I suspect
> there is still only one digital out pin (and ground), and the rest is not
> used (or may be it has digital input too?), but which one?
> And yes, I read the slip of paper which comes with it, it only mentions
> analog audio (which is always 4-pin but different connector).


If you don't have an oscilloscope, a DC volt meter should indicate the 
presence of signal (assuming an audio disc is playing).  To find ground, 
look for continuity between the chassis and one of the pins.

If you don't have a DMM, use trial-and-error until tomorrow when you go buy one.
--
Kyle Accardi

fingerprint should be good, I think.

On Sun, Nov 02, 2003 at 10:50:16PM -0800, AthlonRob wrote:
> To sign a key, we just need to know that you're the owner of the key in
> question and that you are who you say you are.  I don't know what folks
> constitute showing proof of identity these days - the DMV needs what, a
> piece of picture ID and two pieces of non-picture ID?  Is that
> overkill?  Suppose we could google to see what's standard.

A photo-ID (most commonly a license you're surrendering within 30 days
of moving into the sate (since you're only allowed to have one, and
they're automatically invalid after 30 days of moving into a new
state, no matter what the expiration date is, just like license
plates) or a student ID), and a birth certificate.

The Keysigning Party HOWTO recommends two pieces of official photo
IDs, like a passport and a driver's license, but I generally have
skimped with just a driver's license since I haven't known the
location of my passport for years now...

From chris-plug at maybe.net  Mon Nov  3 09:38:02 2003
From: chris-plug at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Mon Nov  3 09:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: key signing (was: test)
In-Reply-To: <20031103144554.18241.41462.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20031103144554.18241.41462.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20031103173703.GC28777@maybe.net>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

The few keysignings I've had (one Intel, one Debian) basically went like
this: I see your driver's license and you give me a printout of your
thumbprint (including hashid and email id). And vice versa. Then
afterwards, I download your key based on the hashid and compare it to your
email id and thumbprint (gpg --fingerprint [hashid]). If it checks out,
I sign it authoritatively and upload it to the key server.

If one had a laptop, was a student, and had access to pubnet, one could
do this interactively, I suppose, but it would be rather time consuming
past a few signatures.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Nov  3 09:44:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon Nov  3 09:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] top posting vs. bottom posting
Message-ID: <20031103174225.GA4651@gate.kl-ic.com>

Russ Johnson admonishes us:
> Top post? http://www.caliburn.nl/topposting.html

... which makes an unproven and irrelevant statement:
  "Smit/DeHan: The majority of Usenet-users prefer bottom-posting."

... and quotes RFC1855, which is about a different subject:
 "If you are sending a reply to a message or a posting be sure you
  summarize the original at the top of the message, or include
  just enough text of the original to give a context."

On the other hand, Emerson reminds us:
  "A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds"

Notice the word "or" in the above RFC sentence.  The first phrase
says "summarize" about the top;  the second phrase after the "or"
makes no recommendations about placement.  Apparently Smit and
DeHan are unable to follow the plain meaning of English, and are
thinking in Dutch (where that word order might convey a different
imperative).

The point of any posting is to convey meaning, not to follow some
machinelike format.  We are not compilers.  Sometimes top-posting
is appropriate;  this is the way all printed literature with
footnotes work.  For those of us who do publish in print, the
habits and preferences of the "anti-top-posting" portion of the
email community (a small subset of a small subset) are not holy
writ, much as some would have it so.

There are many useful points in RFC1855 (Category: Informational)
that are well worth considering.  There are statements about line
length, when to post, how to post, etc. that are worth reading by
many people here.  But RFC1855 puts its references at the bottom,
and many writers and readers have come to expect the same.  

Probably the main focus of RFC1855 is "write for your audience"
which is the main focus of any good writing.  I have top posted
here, because the statement Russ made was concise and to the 
point, albeit wrong.  In other cases, where I feel the quoted
material is excessively verbose, I will summarize and top post.
Anything else is a waste of reader's time.

Keith

P.S.:  And please, when replying to this, configure your mail
program to emit straight ASCII, please.  My own personal gripe
is emails that are laden with MicroCruft like "=2D --=20" .

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993

Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon Nov  3 10:35:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Nov  3 10:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] top posting vs. bottom posting
In-Reply-To: <20031103174225.GA4651@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Mon, 3 Nov 2003, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> Russ Johnson admonishes us:
> > Top post? http://www.caliburn.nl/topposting.html
>
> ... which makes an unproven and irrelevant statement:
> ... and quotes RFC1855, which is about a different subject:

Ooh!  Flamewar! Flamewar!

> On the other hand, Emerson reminds us:
>   "A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds"

Oh yeah?  Well, "Little hobgoblins is the consistency of foolish minds."

> The point of any posting is to convey meaning, not to follow some
> machinelike format.  We are not compilers.

I've been thinking for a while on how to implement a universal quoting
format, such that the MUA can intelligently handle quoting and attribution
per the user's needs.  Wouldn't it be great if your MUA could follow the
discussion and do the dirty work of formatting it so it's easy for
everyone to follow, however they like to read?

> Probably the main focus of RFC1855 is "write for your audience"

Indeed.  F'r instance, if you're writing for Outlook users, they often
want you to top-post because they use the "message preview" feature, which
shows the first few lines in the message list.  Unfortunately, Outlook
isn't smart enough to realize that the reply is often the stuff without
'> ' in front of it, at the bottom.  (And no, I don't get the point of
Message Preview.)

For another instance, bottom-posting is common with Usenet, mailing lists,
Internet old-timers and *nix users.  There are aesthetic and structural
reasons for this, but IMO the most useful reason is simply that, like
choosing to drive on the right side of the road, any consensus is better
than none.  MUAs are adapted to it, discussions all flow the same
direction, things like that.


This is way more fun than that *other* flamewar,
  Aaron

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Nov  3 10:52:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Nov  3 10:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] test
In-Reply-To: <20031103181759.GB8307@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <200311021820.18297.russj@dimstar.net>

On Mon, 2003-11-03 at 10:17, Russ Johnson wrote:
> * Russ Johnson <russj at dimstar.net> [2003-11-02 18:21]:
> > -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
> > Hash: SHA1
> > 
> > Should be pgp-signed. 
> > 
> > Now... where to upload my key... 
> 
> OK, now is this one signed properly? 
> 
> I think I have it working in both kmail and mutt. 

Yes.

It's worth mentioning, I think, that the two emails were signed very
differently.  The one you quote was signed plainly.  The signature
itself was part of the text of the message.  The one I quote was signed
using PGP/MIME, so the signature is a separate MIME part.

There are, unfortunately, many broken MIME-capable mail clients that
simply are unable to decipher PGP/MIME.  When a PGP/MIME message comes
through, they see a blank message with two attachments; one the body of
the message itself, and the other the PGP signature of the message.

OE is likely the most popular of those broken mail clients.

However, Evolution takes a different stance, quite opposite from
Microsoft's OE in this respect.  PGP/MIME messages are *very* easily
verifiable.  I only have to click on a lock at the bottom of the message
to receive the signature information.  If the message is signed
plaintext, however, I have to save the message and verify the saved
message.  Copying and pasting seems to take out the linebreaks.

IIRC, KMail is smarter than Evolution here.  KMail, I believe, is able
to easily (and automagically) verify the integrity of an email no matter
how it is signed.  I guess KMail signs in plaintext, too, as I know mutt
signs using PGP/MIME because some folks who use mutt as a news client
tried to sign their usenet posts but were unable to get it to work
plaintext without just using a pipe to gpg.

I stopped signing messages to PLUG several months ago simply because the
only way Evolution (my favorite mail client currently) is able to sign
posts automatically is using PGP/MIME, and there *are* folks on this
list who use OE and the like who can't easily read PGP/MIME signed
messages.

I see in the last few months, though, that PGP/MIME on the list seems to
be more popular than it was a year ago, so I may just end up signing
posts again...

Rob

A: Because it messes up the order in which people normally read text.

 A: Top posting is an easier read through when the answer is complete

a screen or two.  But that's mostly because such extended quoting is a drag.

in ... no way at all (the "support" you get with the purchase is
worthless).

But this move will inconvenience many Linux users. I am surprised that no
distribution stepped up with a "migration installer" similar to the
upgrade installer which installs newer RedHat over the older one. If a
distribution which is reasonably good by itself released a product like
that they could sweep 90% of (would be ex-)Redhat install base overnight.

RedHat the company seems to be completely sure that they don't need the
support of Linux enthusiasts anymore, that they can get into businesses
through the front door instead o being "smuggled in" by programmers and
engineers as used to be the case. Time will tell if this confidence is
justified or they are committing suicide.

Fedor

On Monday 03 November 2003 11:33 am, Michael Rasmussen wrote:
> On Mon, Nov 03, 2003 at 11:20:45AM -0800, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:
> > I just got an email from Red Hat, stating the "end of life" of Red Hat
> > 9 will be April 2004. After that, there will be no more "Red Hat Linux"
> > distributions.
>
> The memo didn't say anything about the Fedora distribution.  That would
> seem to be the direction for those who like RedHat and want  or need a
> free version.

I don't see a problem here. Fedora for free-beer free, Red Hat Enterprise for 
paid, and Free. Here is what Red Hat told me when I asked for clarification 
of license terms:

"With Red Hat Linux 9 and Fedora, you may install from single disk set on 
as many systems as you like.

"With Red Hat Enterprise Linux, you must purchase the technology as part 
of a yearly subscription that includes maintenance and support. ?At the 
end of the subscription, if you choose not to renew youor subscription, 
you are free to use Red Hat Enterprise Linux on your own (unsupported). 
Binaries and source code are freely available for Red Hat Enteprise 
Linux, but users who roll their own versions are not able to be 
supported by Red Hat.

"More info on our licensing can be found at http://www.redhat.com if yuo 
search under 'GPL'.

If you want to get torqued about commercial Linuxes, take a look at Lycoris 
and Lindows. Their licenses are quite restrictive, and they provide no 
obvious method of obtaining sources, as they are supposed to. SuSE charges 
per-seat licenses on some of their servers.

I don't know of any Linux distribution that supports their entire line 
indefinitely, all the them cut off the old stuff eventually.

>
> If ease of installation is a criteria the recent porting of RedHat's
> Anaconda installer to Debian might make Debian more interesting.
> See http://lwn.net/Articles/56010/

IMO, Debian is unnecessarily difficult to install. Both Libranet and Knoppix's 
hardware detection are phenomenal. The Knoppix installer is Kudzu-based, with 
tweaks by Klaus Knopper. I believe Anaconda uses Kudzu. Which I don't know if 
I actually have a point to make here, except a better installer for Debian 
would be loverly. :)

> On Mon, Nov 03, 2003 at 11:20:45AM -0800, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:
> > I just got an email from Red Hat, stating the "end of life" of Red Hat
> > 9 will be April 2004. After that, there will be no more "Red Hat Linux"
> > distributions.
> 
> The memo didn't say anything about the Fedora distribution.  That would
> seem to be the direction for those who like RedHat and want  or need a
> free version.  
> 
> Not that you don't have an overwhelming amount of choice in case you do
> decide to switch distributions.
> 
> If ease of installation is a criteria the recent porting of RedHat's 
> Anaconda installer to Debian might make Debian more interesting. 
> See http://lwn.net/Articles/56010/
> 

It will be interesting to see how the Fedora project evolves. The general
idea is to turn it in to a community-driven project like Debian. If that 
happens then support (of the OSS unofficial variety) could be better 
compared to the soon-defunct plain Red Hat Linux. For example what's to 
keep the Fedora community from releasing security patches for Fedora Core 
releases beyond the one-year cycle envisioned by Red Hat? It all depends 
on how much of a real community develops, who's in it, and what their 
priorities are.

Terry

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Nov  3 14:52:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon Nov  3 14:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat changes, fedora
Message-ID: <20031103225051.GA4886@gate.kl-ic.com>

Yes, Redhat is changing how they do business.  As I mentioned here
a couple months ago, I am concerned that with this step they are
losing the newbies, who are a PITA in the short term, but are where
Redhat's growth comes from in the long term.  OTOH, there is plenty
of opportunity to convert more corporate customers, and if Redhat
achieves their corporate goal (reducing a 5 billion per year
operating system market to a 500 million per year market - RH CEO
Robert Young) they will indirectly serve all of us.

That said, Redhat is handling this decision in a reasonable way, with
the Fedora project.  I am running Fedora Test 3 on one machine, and
though there are issues they are not showstoppers.  Fedora bugs posted
to bugzilla.redhat.com get prompt and intelligent responses from Redhat
employees and others.   By being a downloadable but tested release,
Fedora is reducing the lead time between application appearance and
general availability, and getting people up to date with tested versions
of applications is the fastest way to get open source out there.

The way this may work out is that we do the newbie support ourselves.
There may be some money in it, so maybe it isn't bad that Redhat has
left this to us.

The general release version of Fedora was originally due today (Nov 3),
but their website mentions a delay for a respin.  I hope the minor
bugs I posted aren't responsible for that delay :-)

Keith

From jason at vancleve.com  Mon Nov  3 16:52:01 2003
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Mon Nov  3 16:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] top posting vs. bottom posting
In-Reply-To: <25E622D843625C40BE0EEC150B437C1B0173F071@cnfqe029.cnf.prod.cnf.com>
References: <25E622D843625C40BE0EEC150B437C1B0173F071@cnfqe029.cnf.prod.cnf.com>
Message-ID: <20031103174957.79dce447.jason@vancleve.com>

Can I play too? . . .

Thus spoke Anderson, Robert H - MWT, on Mon, 3 Nov 2003 12:51:54 -0800:

> This was a really F@#$%ed up email to read, until I resized the window
> it was in. Then it was only difficult to get any meaning from.

It's considered bad form to end a sentence with a preposition, as in your last sentence there.  Is that worth complaining about every time I see it in this list?  Not really.

Top posting and bottom posting are matters of form and convention, but they are also about human language, not computer code.  Regarding the former, I admonish that we try to follow the rules but be very careful about making them.  This is distinct from computer languages, for which standards are essential whether good or bad.

There are some who feel justified in trying to mandate bottom posting, but historically, human language simply doesn't evolve by mandate.  (It is precisely for that reason that we aren't debating this in French.)

--Jason Van Cleve

Better-designed MUAs (including Pine) display sanitized HTML already.

> It'd be pretty cool if you could edit how much of each previous post you'd
> like to quote in your message, but not alter how that is displayed on the
> other end.  Then other folks would do the same and each would view it in
> their own way/direction.
>
> However, that'd take a massive email overhaul and it wouldn't be terribly
> backward compatible<snip>

How 'bout a QuoteInfo header or attachment saying,
 Lines 3-5 and 12-14 are oldest, indented with '>> ' and written by Alice;
 lines 7 and 15-20 are next-oldest, indented with '> ' and written by Bob;
 the rest are the sender's.
Heck, that way quoted text would even wrap nicely.

But if this info were lost because Alice replied again and her MUA didn't
include it, my mailer would have to regenerate it when I replied to her.
So until everyone supports QuoteInfo (IE never), it'd be no different from
having an MUA that just reformats email for the reader.

Huh.  Another instance of David Isenberg's Stupid Network/Smart Periphery
paradigm winning out.

Well, 'Thin-clients' or whatever term you want to use (I think we called
them 'Earth Stations' or some such)  is a concept they are still trying
to push.  Claiming it's only a matter of bandwidth, but I'm not so sure
it'll ever take off (Just a guess of course).  

I tend to believe we'll have a mixed system, everyone will have their
own personal server, and a myriad of client systems that run off it
(TV's, alarm clocks, coffee makers, refrigerators, as well as the
terminals scattered throughout every room of the house (TV again??))
We're kind of seeing this happen now.  I wonder if it'll stick.

And 'peer to peer' was actually the buzz-word of the time.  With the
inception of thin Ethernet (aka 10base-T), and Novell-lite and I think
Lantastic (Tho I got little play time with it).  And actually, this was
12 years ago *winks* I had the fortune to be the first tech in our
company to play with 10base-T. Which thankfully, made me the 'go-to guy'
when people started asking for 10base-T and peer-to-peer based networks.

I do agree about the IT landscape being dominated by mainframes.  But my
field of expertise at the time was small business networks.  Not large
corporate solutions, so my thoughts, and memories are most likely
colored a bit.

> and there were lots of interesting projects that just died.

True, But I think even this is still common place, one only need to look
at the long list of great ideas on source-forge to find many a good idea
sitting idle and/or dead.

Who? What? Huh?  Never heard of them! *Chuckles*  So true!

> token ring networks were going to be hot,

When I came into the networking field (Again in '91), Token ring was

> floptical discs too, etc.  and who would have thought we'd still
> be using plain SMTP for email instead of X.400 or whatever?

Again, Very true! (X.400?  Isn't that an OS?)  I'm getting the feeling
you've been doing this a bit longer then I, and on a much larger scale.

> ten years ago, you couldn't have planned for the shape of the
> Internet today.  it's _hard_ to guess which technologies will
> become important and which ones will disappear without a trace.

Also true. My point was more that these things follow an evolutionary
tract.  There is no way to say what the net will be like in 10 years.
But I can say with certainty that if you get a good grip on what is, and
watch what happens, one should be able to at least stay with the wave.

> and that's true for any stage of the game we're in.  perhaps the
> future ten years from now is going to be based on something
> that's here today, but who has time to follow the hundreds of
> things that are going to die, just so you don't miss the one
> thing that doesn't?

You don't need to watch everything, unless you're trying to get ahead of
the game.  Trying to latch onto that one thing that is going to make you
rich and famous.  If that's your goal, I say Good luck.  But if all you
want is to stay good at your job, and stay current. There isn't too much
guess work involved, and you can limit your time and resources to what
needs to be done.

> if you want to "play it smart" and go with the clear winners, ten

From miken at hotsushi.com  Tue Nov  4 09:16:02 2003

In-Reply-To: <200311040900.43638.guy1656@ados.com>

Hi,
It is not nearly the problem that exists in Windows.  ext2/3 writes files
with unused space between them so growth in a file is less likely to be
fragmented.  As the space used approaches the capacity of the partition,
fragmentation increases and disk I/O degrades.

Here is one tool:

http://rpmfind.net//linux/RPM/contrib/libc6/i386/defrag-0.73-5.i386.html

Cheers,
Mike

> software developer SuSE Linux AG of Germany for $210 million in a major
> expansion of its Linux strategy, sending its shares up 33 percent.

Did Novell somewhere along the line become Evil? I think Novell Netware is the 
best network OS, by a country mile. (I don't know how lameass winduhs crowded 
out Netware- bribery? threats?) Businesses and other users who want 
ready-to-go products and support aren't going to mess with Debian, or 
Slackware, or Gentoo, or Fedora. They don't want to roll-their-own, they want 
a nice package with all the pieces already assembled and ready to go to work. 
Both Red Hat and SuSE have put together some nice packages, including 64-bit 
servers and workstations, and preinstalls on IBM hardware. I gloat over Linux 
being the first and best with 64-bit. (on x86)

For the market they're targeting, it's a good match. Sure, us lil 
do-it-ourselfers aren't going to be interested. That's the beauty of FOSS and 
Linux- it's endlessly adaptable. Something for everyone.

And don't forget that no matter how much they pretty up GPL'd code, and how 
much they charge for binaries, they still have to fork over the sources for 
free, or a minimal media charge.

From felix.1 at canids.net  Tue Nov  4 11:16:02 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Tue Nov  4 11:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Contiguous? 
In-Reply-To: <200311040900.43638.guy1656@ados.com> 
    on Tue, 04 Nov 2003 09:00:43 PST
    from guy1656 <guy1656@ados.com> 
Message-ID: <20031104191506.A4EF91592A5@kanga.canids>

guy1656 <guy1656 at ados.com>:
> /dev/hdc1 xx/nnnnnnn files (7.8% non-contiguous) ...

if it's ext2/ext3,
if you have large files,
then you'll always have some fragmentation,
because the filesystem divides the disks into 'groups',
and each group is split into file inodes and file blocks,
the idea being that you can sometimes get better performance if a
  file's inode and a file's blocks are physically near each other,
which means the disk alternates between inodes and blocks,
which means the filesystem has to split any file bigger than one
  group (size varies, 128M seems typical),
which shouldn't have much impact on performance,
since you can't read files that large in one chunk anyway.

I don't remember if there are any unix filesystems that benefit
  much from defragging.
my general feeling is it's a waste of time.
but go ahead and try it.
(make a backup first)
--

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Nov  4 13:31:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Nov  4 13:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix ESMTP authentication
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311040959580.9995@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <000101c3a29a$b9b36170$0a00a8c0@PORTLAND> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311040959580.9995@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20031104213009.GB21984@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> [2003-11-04 12:32]:
> The problem is that I can't send mail outside the local domain from remote
> locations.

And that's how it is, by design. To do something else would be to make
yourself a relay. (Stand by for more.)

> I just can't seem to find which commands to issue for user and pass for
> plaintext or CRAM authentication.

I don't know that postfix offers those as options. Have you read this
how-to: http://postfix.state-of-mind.de/patrick.koetter/smtpauth/

You see, postfix doesn't know about passwords. It checks the IP
Address to see if the sender is local or not.
If the IP isn't in the list of locally known places, then it only
delivers.

Of course, this can be over-ridden for specific circumstances, but I'm
not aware of postfix actually authenticating. 

The how-to I listed above is one way to use smtp-auth with postfix,
which uses a third program for the authentication duties. 


I hope that helps.

From ehem at m5p.com  Tue Nov  4 14:40:03 2003
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Tue Nov  4 14:40:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Contiguous?
In-Reply-To: <20031104192003.23785.28334.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200311042238.hA4McqSv000502@m5p.com>

> From: guy1656 <guy1656 at ados.com>
> So, I'm rebooting, and along the way I see
> 
> /dev/hdc1 xx/nnnnnnn files (7.8% non-contiguous) ...
> 
> ...and this reminds me an awful lot of 'defrag' in the Windoze world.
> 
> Is there a file-manglement tool in KDE or something which will 
> re-contigous-ness that drive, and is this a good thing to do from time to 
> time?

As was mentioned a tool exists. I must advise against using it though.

e2defrag did the advertised job fine, without problems. Unfortunatly
during defragmentation it packed files closely together, without any
space between them, as a result things got worse quickly. The FS I ran it
on reached about 4-5% fragmentation prior to the use of the tool,
directly after using e2defrag the drive did have 0% fragmentation, within
a month the drive hit 8% fragmentation.

Okay, two important notes. First, the close packing is only a theory, it
matches the symptoms and seems the most likely explaination. Second, this
was a couple years ago so this problem may of been fixed by now.

Until the drive hits 10% fragmentation, I wouldn't do anything.

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Nov  4 15:28:01 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Nov  4 15:28:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat changes, fedora
In-Reply-To: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A07FD42AE@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
References: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A07FD42AE@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <20031104232733.GD21984@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Daggett, Steve <Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com> [2003-11-04 13:56]:
> Red Hat's chief executive has said that Linux needs to mature further before
> home users will get a positive experience from the operating system, saying
> they should choose Windows instead. 

Well, he has a point. Despite it's crashes and some problems (which in
all honesty have gotten better over the last 3 years) Windows IS more
user friendly to the average user.

Now. Let me qualify that. I would venture to guess that NO ONE IN THIS
GROUP is an "average user".

Case in point. I have a digital camera. Here's the two methods:

1> Linux.
Configure the system to see USB devices as drives. This involves
configuring SCSI emulation support, and sometimes a kernel rebuild. Once
that's done, I write a shell script to mount the camera as a drive,
download the pictures and rename them. That means finding a third party
utility that can read the jpeg image and rename the image appropriately.
Tweak files in /dev so that *I* as a user can do this. I don't want to
su to root everytime I copy pictures to my system. 

2> Windows.
Put CD that came with camera in drive. Install drivers. Install other
programs that came with camera. Plug camera in. It works. 

In this situation, both systems do nearly the same task, with equal
ease, once the configuration part is done. 

The problem is that the configuration part is beyond the capabilities of
the "average user".

I have mostly given up on Windows because I get frustrated with it. But
most folks don't have the technical skills to take up *nix. 

"Just do it" you say? Learn while you play? That's nice to do when you
have an extra machine, or when you are younger and their are fewer
things claiming your time. Most people I know have things they want to
get done on their computer, and get off the thing. As foreign as that
sounds to you and I, that's how most people use computers.

I don't carry a hammer in my back pocket for exactly the same reason. I
don't need it often enough to warrent carrying it around. 

Many of us here in this forum will say that it's not hard to use
Linux/*BSD/etc. It's not... FOR US! For someone that has always used
Windows, any *nix platform has a steep learning curve. The first lesson
being that you don't go to the store to get your software. 

I personally know many people that I would not suggest linux to. At
least, not at this time, unless they decided to hire me to take care of
their systems. :) It's a hell of a lot closer now than when I
started using it (1996), but, as Matthew Szulik said, it has a ways to
go before it will be ready for primetime with the vast majority of
computer users. 

-- 
Russ Johnson

http://www.dimstar.net

From m at pdxlug.org  Tue Nov  4 15:46:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Tue Nov  4 15:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] web dev question
In-Reply-To: <20031103180017.48a273d1.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <56568.68.107.223.201.1067895910.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org> 
     <20031103180017.48a273d1.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <55754.68.107.223.201.1067989528.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

Jason Van Cleve said:
> Thus spoke Matt Alexander, on Mon, 3 Nov 2003 13:45:10 -0800 (PST):
>
>> Is there any way to avoid the little popup window and just have the
>> Perl DBI script do its thing in the background without constantly
>> interrupting the user?
>
> I can suggest only that you use a (little tiny) frame, as I've always had
> to open a page in order to call the server using JS.
>
> However, this sounds like a poor design to me, updating your database on
> every little edit.  For one argument, people are used to thinking nothing
> happens until they click "Submit".  Plus it seems like a lot of work to be
> doing, but that may not be an issue for you.

It's a web database front-end on a corporate Intranet.  People work on a
"page" at a time and these pages can be quite large with many fields to
update as well as each field itself being quite long.  I originally had a
"Save changes" button at the bottom of the page and I collected all the
changes into one long string that was passed to my Perl script for
updating the database.  For reasons I haven't yet figured out, the script
would hang permanently after the query string reached a certain length.  I
did some testing and found that updating each field after it changed was
acceptible performance wise until I could find a better solution.  On the
web, people are used to clicking a "submit" button to save changes, but
I've found that they prefer having things change immediately instead, just
like in a regular stand-alone app.
I'll create a tiny iframe for the Perl script call.
Thanks,
~M

Subject: [PLUG] top posting vs. bottom posting
In-Reply-To: <E1AH40r-0000Ci-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <003e01c3a331$8c774ea0$0a00a8c0@PORTLAND>

Hi *Smiles*

Personally, I can see a use for all three forms of quoting.  

My favorite is the third, and mostly undisguised, method.  Breaking the
quoted text into logical bits and responding to each.  However this
method is best used with long, multipart posts.

Bottom posting is good in environments, such as this list, where many
threads of conversation are taking place simultaneously.  One sometimes
needs a reminder of what's going on in that particular discussion.

Top posting is handy in situations where there is only a few discussions
occurring, and the messages are relatively short.  Situations where
there's really no need to reread what has already been said, except just
to know which message it was in response to.  In all fairness, I am a
member of several mailing lists that specifically request top posting.
And it works very well in those places.  

-- Chris Healy

  What's wrong with this for every message, in all mail lists? It's what
I've always done (from the days of BBS messages to current use of the 'Net).
It makes sense.

> Bottom posting is good in environments, such as this list, where many
> threads of conversation are taking place simultaneously.  One sometimes
> needs a reminder of what's going on in that particular discussion.

  As you can see, there's better communications when your replies are
specific to the part of the message to which they apply.

> Top posting is handy in situations where there is only a few discussions
> occurring, and the messages are relatively short.  Situations where
> there's really no need to reread what has already been said, except just
> to know which message it was in response to.  In all fairness, I am a
> member of several mailing lists that specifically request top posting. And

  How about those winduhs users (e.g., users of AOL) who "top post" because
none of the original message is included in the response? Try figuring out
what's going on when you sent your message a day or so ago.

  Or, those who interweave their reply with your message. I have a
professional colleague who manages to do this with his Lookout! Express MUA.
It takes a _long_ time to figure out where his text is embedded.

  If folks were to think of how their reply is perceived by the recipient(s)
and they're interested in clearly and efficiently communicating, they'd pay
attention to what they're doing. I think that would happen some time after
folks use turn signals when changing lanes and don't cut off other drivers
as they chat on their phones. :-) In other words, "Ha! Don't hold your
breath, Richard".

> From: Russ Johnson
> 
> * Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> [2003-11-04 12:32]:
> > The problem is that I can't send mail outside the local domain from
> > remote locations.
> 
> And that's how it is, by design. To do something else would be to make
> yourself a relay. (Stand by for more.)
> 

You can tell Postfix to only relay for specific accounts.  

A Snippit from one of my own main.cf files:

smtpd_recipient_restrictions  = 
            permit_mynetworks
            check_sender_access hash:/etc/postfix/sender_access
            check_relay_domains

It would need modifying for the MySQL interactivity of course, but I
would look here.  That's about all that comes to mind at moment.

-- Chris Healy

and have concluded what this means.

1.  This is a great business solution for RH.  They can focus on a solid money
making venture and not have to deal with all the calls that people have about
wanting support for the end-user product. In the long run this will affect MS more
then anyone else.  It perhaps will see one company trying to actually produce a good
Linux solution.  Yes, it cost but Business's want the support and you have to pay
for that.  I hope they do really well.

were even visable to people but seeing copies in the stores always is a good thing
for future sales.  When Linux was starting to get big on the shelves with everyone
putting out a copy I stoped and read as did others.  That is fading fast.

This is a very bad thing.  As it will not help RH in the long run.  They will not
have all the new College kids who have been running RH at home promoting their
products at work.  This has been a great thing for many companies.  Give it away to

Linux alternative server solutions out there that RH can overcome this lost.

for XP(I'm lucky I don't), I would buy it once and keep it for years w/o having to
pay again.  Yearly subscriptions to the OS is something I hope I never have to do.

I hope the Fedora project is something I like.  I would hate to see such a huge
change and have to learn again another Linux distribution.  Yes, all are similar,
but there are enough differences that you become annoyed.

On Tue, 4 Nov 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Case in point. I have a digital camera. Here's the two methods:
>
> 1> Linux.
> Configure the system to see USB devices as drives. This involves
> configuring SCSI emulation support, and sometimes a kernel rebuild. Once
> that's done, I write a shell script to mount the camera as a drive,
> download the pictures and rename them. That means finding a third party
> utility that can read the jpeg image and rename the image appropriately.
> Tweak files in /dev so that *I* as a user can do this. I don't want to

> Put CD that came with camera in drive. Install drivers. Install other
> programs that came with camera. Plug camera in. It works.

Woah.

So many issues to address here, I don't know where to begin.

First, you're not talking about what you have to do with every GNU/Linux
distribution.  Get that clear, first.  Some are already configured
properly for this sort of thing.

Second, what you've done in your "Linux" example above is far more
interesting and flexible than what you've done with the Windows example.
There was a presumed level of interaction on your part and you went for
it; it's a whole different paradigm.  It's just as difficult (or perhaps
moreso) to do exactly what you did on the Linux system in Windows.  I, for
one, would have to check many references to write useful script in Windows
that would arbitrarily copy and rename files according some predefined
standards of naming based on date and time and file type.  Multiply that
by a ten thousand if you want it to happen every time you connect your
camera.  The approach you described in 1 assumes this is easy and
straightforward.

However, if you just want your GNU/Linux system to do what the Windows
system does in your example 2 above, then it's more like this:

apt-get install gphoto (or your favorite gui apt utility). Plug in camera.
It works.

You've got your gphoto icon on your applications menu.

And that's that.  The software does everything you can do with the
comparable Windows software (and maybe more) and has a common and simple
interface.

If we compare apples with apples, the differences vanish.

J.

>   If folks were to think of how their reply is perceived by the

The concept of "stealing slack" is appropriate here.

If your convenience means someone else has to take more time and effort to
interact or react to you, then you've "stolen their slack".  That is to
say, your slack takes away their opportunity to slack.

Valuing laziness means being vigilant and mindful and careful so that
others may be lazy.

> I think that would happen some time after folks use turn signals when
> changing lanes and don't cut off other drivers as they chat on their
> phones. :-) In other words, "Ha! Don't hold your breath, Richard".

If people truly stopped to think about the negative impact of their
actions on others, they wouldn't be driving at all.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Tue Nov  4 18:01:01 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Tue Nov  4 18:01:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] top posting vs. bottom posting
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311041621260.6064@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <003e01c3a331$8c774ea0$0a00a8c0@PORTLAND>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311041621260.6064@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1067997589.3752.7.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Tue, 2003-11-04 at 16:27, Rich Shepard wrote:

> > Top posting is handy in situations where there is only a few discussions
> > occurring, and the messages are relatively short.  Situations where
> > there's really no need to reread what has already been said, except just
> > to know which message it was in response to.  In all fairness, I am a
> > member of several mailing lists that specifically request top posting. And
> > it works very well in those places.
> 
>   How about those winduhs users (e.g., users of AOL) who "top post" because
> none of the original message is included in the response? Try figuring out
> what's going on when you sent your message a day or so ago.

To be fair... AOL defaults to bottom-posting.  If you highlight the text
you wish to reply to, and hit the reply button, the text is quoted (HTML
blockquote style) and the cursor is set at the bottom of the message.

It makes it difficult to respond point-by-point, breaking up the message
(as I generally prefer)... but not impossible.  IMHO, it's still much
better than lookOut Express which quotes the whole message and puts the
cursor at the top, where everybody wants to type (Evolution does the
same, but with a different header message that encourages
bottom-posting).

My take on the whole thing:

A: Top-posting
Q: What's the most annoying thing on usenet?

Top-posting doesn't allow you to logically follow the flow of the
conversation.  In a high-traffic list (or on usenet) this is important
because folks simply don't remember what you're responding to, and don't
want to scroll all the way to the bottom of a post to find out... or
look back to the earlier (referenced) message.

For mailing lists, I'm really ok with both (although not together ;-)...
which is good, as I really have no say at all in how you quote messages
you're responding to.

For casual email, I often will top-post.  If I bottom-post, it confuses
some computer illiterates when they open the email and just see what
they already sent you.

For technical support emails when dealing with long lists of
instructions or whatnot, I almost always top-post, and encourage others
to do the same.  That is, if I email my parts supplier about an odd
motherboard problem I'm having, I top-post to their responses.  Unless
breaking it up makes sense... which it rarely does.  This lets the tech
support dude (sometimes me) easily glance back to an unbroken display of
what exactly was suggested, what the initial problem was, etc.  You
don't have to go look at some support database, or look up the old
emails you sent; it's all there at the bottom of the email if you need
to look at it.

My nickel (I'll collect change Thursday, I'm out of pennies)

Rob
