>      they could never accomplish by just selling applications and system
>      add-ons for Windows. The acquisition of Ximian gave Novell a cache
>      of great Linux products, but that doesn't really help them out of
>      their funk. Novell still has a large installed base of NetWare
>      customers that they need to migrate to something with a future or
>      lose to Microsoft. Now they've got a server they can use to
>      backfill Netware. They can't do that with a Linux server that they
>      don't have pretty tight control over, so buying a Linux company is
>      a natural choice: it gives them a product, lots of Linux expertise
>      to tap, and some credibility.
> 
>      This is probably a good thing for Linux users in general because
>      there's likely to be some good work done on making Linux work well
>      inside the corporate IT shop. Most large IT shops don't have the
>      luxury of being a pure Linux or Microsoft shop. They have to be
>      both. Linux has made some great strides toward being a good
>      corporate citizen. This provides more pressure in that direction.
> 
>      I guess it's hard to find a downside.
> 
>    Dave Aiello, president of CTDATA:
>    http://ctdata.com/ (a Linux-savvy company that builds database-driven
>    Web sites for companies in the New York Metro area) sees the buy as an
>    Open Source community play:
> 
>      I think you have to look at the SuSE acquisition in the same light
>      as the release by IBM of Eclipse as a free product. A network
>      effects calculation is being done here. I think IBM looked at
>      Eclipse and said, this product has greater value to us if it's in
>      the hands of [the] Open Source community than if we keep selling
>      it. If we keep total control of it, we have to enhance it, market
>      it, and provide for the development of ancillary products from our
>      own resources.
> 
>      If the product is backed by an Open Source community, the founders
>      get the benefit of free labor, free product enhancement ideas, and
>      ancillary product branches that they don't have to support unless
>      the company has an overwhelming interest.
> 
>      I think this is what's happened with Netscape->Mozilla and
>      WebSphere Studio App Developer -> Eclipse. It is what Red Hat hopes
>      will happen with Fedora, and ultimately, what IBM is hoping for
>      with SuSE. I think IBM's ultimate interest is in having a credible
>      alternative to Red Hat that they have substantial influence over,
>      without having the overhead of developing internally.
> 
>      This is more about addressing customer CIO level concerns about not
>      repeating the Wintel single source market than about the fact that
>      IBM doesn't like Red Hat's Enterprise Linux strategy, per se.
> 
>    Allen Harrell, an IT outsource specialist in Arizona, says this:
> 
>      If Novell can make Linux work across the enterprise regardless of
>      size, this is a good thing. After all, Novell was the first company
>      to get print services running across the network. Novell 6's client
>      for Windows machines is a slick piece of software. Letting you
>      access all the files on your network regardless of type -- an area
>      where Windows fails at miserably. I have a Red Hat 6 drive in my
>      machine right now that the BIOS picks up but Windows doesn't even
>      list it.
> 
>      NetWare also logs off all the clients and notifies you, which
>      allows them to keep running while it reboots, which is an area
>      where Windows gives you the blue screen of death.
> 
>      With Red Hat getting out of the personal OS biz:
>      http://www.theregister.co.uk/content/4/33760.html, Lindows will get
>      some more traction. I mean, hell, if you can buy a Lindows computer
>      at Wal-Mart, those folks who were afraid of 'trailer trash' showing
>      up on the Net have a real good reason to fear now.
> 
>    One upbeat response I've been hearing is this deal will be good for
>    Debian. So I asked Debian co-founder, Ian Murdock CEO of Progeny:
>    http://www.progeny.com, for his take. Here's what he said:
> 
>      My initial reaction is that this is very good news for Linux, both
>      [the] industry and community.
> 
>      Industry-wise, the distribution world has started to head down a
>      dangerous road this past year, and this move certainly promises to
>      shake things up quite a bit. My hope is it will shake things up
>      enough to allow a course correction. I'm optimistic, because from
>      what I've seen, Novell is doing all the right things. They seem to
>      understand that what's truly unique about Linux is the ecosystem
>      and community around Linux, and they seem genuinely interested in
>      building a symbiotic relationship that benefits both Novell and the
>      larger community of which Novell is now part.
> 
>      Community-wise, the bigger our community and the bigger our
>      friends, the more we as a community can accomplish.
> 
>    I also asked Ian about Red Hat's recent decision to discontinue Red
>    Hat Linux, leaving Fedora:
>    http://fedora.redhat.com/ in its place. He responded:
> 
>      This is another case of Red Hat leaving a void in the market, and
>      voids equal opportunities. We're still assessing what opportunities
>      might exist for Progeny as a result of this latest move. I can tell
>      you that we've seen a lot of interest in Debian in the enterprise
>      over the past few months, when people first started to see this
>      coming, as well as a more flexible migration path from Red Hat 7.x
>      than [what] Red Hat is offering.
> 
>    Ian also pointed to his blog, where he wrote:
>    http://ianmurdock.com/archives/000068.html:
> 
>      The IT industry wants to break the chains of single-vendor reliance
>      and proprietary lock-in, whether the lock-in is based on
>      proprietary technology or some clever new scheme. But is the only
>      way to break these chains to bring everything in-house?
> 
>      Actually, no. Progeny provides a third option: We're an outsource
>      provider of Linux distribution maintenance that allows companies to
>      essentially have their own Linux distributions, with a feature set,
>      roadmap, and support model tailored to their needs rather than the
>      vendor's, all without having to bring the distribution management
>      function in-house.
> 
>      It's a non-intuitive business model for an OS company, at least at
>      first, because we're so used to being at the whims of our vendors.
>      We're so used to it that the same model has carried forward from
>      the proprietary OS world to the Linux distribution world. Now that
>      Red Hat is turning the screws on the thumbs that have been so
>      carefully positioned over the last several years, people are
>      starting to realize they moved to open-source operating systems
>      precisely to get away from this kind of screw-turning.
> 
>    Unlike pontificating, we-solve-everything major vendors, however, Ian
>    doesn't pretend to have all the answers--or even close to enough of
>    them.
> 
>      And now, a Cluetrain:
>      http://www.cluetrain.com-inspired question: Progeny's primary focus
>      is on building distributions for what we like to call
>      "Linux-powered products", products that are Linux-based but where
>      Linux is just one layer of the overall stack, and possibly an
>      invisible one at that. Lately, though, we've had a lot of folks ask
>      if we might consider applying our customer rather than
>      vendor-centric approach to Linux to the more general-purpose
>      deployment/enterprise space. Could we provide support for
>      enterprise Debian deployments? Could we keep the updates coming for
>      Red Hat 7.x after they are end-of-lifed at the end of the year?
> 
>      So, market, would this be interesting to you? Talk to me, good, bad
>      or indifferent.
> 
>    Frankly, I'm having a problem even caring about what Novell is up to.
>    That's because I'm fed up with the Cult of the Vendor. And that's what
>    this subject is all about, at least the level of attention we give to
>    it.
> 
>    Linux isn't a vendor product. Never was, never will be. It's not even
>    a product. It's a project by a development community that includes
>    many vendors but isn't driven by any of them. Same goes for other
>    members of the LAMP suite, with the single exception of MySQL, which
>    owns the code (making it, in that sense, proprietary) but locates
>    development squarely inside the community rather than in its own
>    corporate container. In other words, they are very
>    unvendor-like--market-compliant, I'd say.
> 
>    Development communities like Linux's grew out of the need to do what
>    vendors couldn't do or wouldn't do. That doesn't make vendors bad or
>    anything; it just puts them in perspective. They can't do everything,
>    and now they don't have to.
> 
>    It's only natural for press guys like me to look at vendors as
>    leaders. We've been doing that since the dawn of the Industrial
>    Revolution. But there's another kind of revolution going on here, and
>    it isn't happening on the supply side. It's happening on the demand
>    side.
> 
>    Linux and open source are ways that the demand side supplies itself.
>    Of course, in some cases the demand side also supplies--IBM, for
>    example. But it helps to remember that IBM went gaga over Linux only
>    after the OS was already widely adopted inside the company, by
>    technologists who in some cases also were Linux developers. The
>    company wisely got in alignment with the market reality it was
>    experiencing at the cellular level. They did it first (for a big
>    company, anyway), and they deserve kudos for that--but not for driving
>    Linux. They help a lot; but it's not their project to drive.
> 
>    Perhaps Novell is going through the same kind of cell-change thing. My
>    point here is that it doesn't matter as much as all the breathless
>    headlines and analyses say it matters.
> 
>    Here's how Doug Kaye, the author, analyst and Web services guru, puts
>    it:
> 
>      Fifteen years ago the vendors provided the vision. There was no
>      other source. No "community" of users and certainly no Internet by
>      which we could share ideas. The trade shows (Comdex, NCC) and the
>      trade papers (Computerworld) were how we got our vision, and they
>      were controlled by the vendors.
> 
>      High schools and colleges are now all about open source. It's LAMP
>      everywhere. Open source is now also the new source for "vision" for
>      IT managers and CIOs. How do you know what's real and not just
>      vaporware? Go to the bookstore and look at the O'Reilly end cap
>      display. There you'll see the LAMP titles: Linux, Apache, MySQL,
>      and the Ps. These are the technologies from which one can quickly
>      and inexpensively build industrial-strength applications.
> 
>    Bottom line: You're on your own, but you're not alone.
>

From holger at selover.net  Thu Nov  6 09:32:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Thu Nov  6 09:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Database E-R design tools
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311060903260.14328@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311060903260.14328@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1068139919.1595.15.camel@halo>

Hi Rich,

Have you considered using one of the persistence and O/R mapping
frameworks (my favorite is Hibernate, http://hibernate.org)? The
database schema, even the creation of tables is handled by the
framework. But you'll have to subscribe to their object logic. I use
Omondo, http://www.omondo.com/ these days to create the objects in UML
and XDoclet to generate the Hibernate mapping files. 

Otherwise there are a few Eclipse plug-ins for database tasks, you may
want to look at the Japanese Clay,
http://www.azzurri.jp/en/software/clay/

All above mentioned tools are free. 

Holger

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Nov  6 09:55:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu Nov  6 09:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux hardware issues
In-Reply-To: <20031106165502.32517.72028.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20031106165502.32517.72028.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20031106175421.GA7138@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Wed, 2003-11-05 at 20:18, Karol Kulaga wrote:
> Okie dokie. I seem to have a possessed machine that just doesn't seem to
> want any version of Linux on it. Sorry about the length, but I wanted to get
> a lot of details in here.

Two almost identical machines, and one works?  This makes the test pretty
easy, though it may still take a number of tests to narrow down the 
diagnosis.  This will take time, but your chances of success are good.

First, on the balky machine, try running Knoppix 3.3 straight off a CDROM.
This may not help you diagnose the particular failure, and Knoppix may
not run, but if it works it will give you the confidence to keep going.
If KNOPPIX doesn't work, well, you've learned something valuable.

If you can run the machines side by side, bring them both up into CMOS
mode (on some machines, hitting DEL during boot does this ... your startup
screen will tell you).  Look for differences.  Sometimes there is a feature
turned off - or on - and that can make a difference.

If you have your working Linux system set up to autodetect hardware, then
you can swap the different pieces into the working system one by one until
things quit.

You can also swap the hard drives between the machines.  If the working
drive doesn't work in the balky system, you've narrowed it down to hardware.

This should "just work" of course, and most of the time it does, but 
installing Linux is still only a 95% thing, and we need to do more work
with the corner cases.  I wish I had the time to help you debug, because
we could learn important things to improve Linux install for everyone
from it.

In any case, write down what you discover and put it up on a web page
somehere.  Even if - especially if! - it turns out to be "something 
dumb".  There are probably hundreds of people out there on the planet
with the same linux install problem right now, and if your discoveries
help them solve their problems you have done a Real Good Thing.  That
is what is so very cool about Linux, is that there are no laws against
us helping each other!

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Thu Nov  6 10:48:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Thu Nov  6 10:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Winders Security Software Recommendations
In-Reply-To: <1068133850.675.585.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <20031106014438.380212d3.jason@vancleve.com>
	 <1068133850.675.585.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <1068144387.29923.5370.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

On Thu, 2003-11-06 at 07:50, Derek Loree wrote:
> On Thu, 2003-11-06 at 00:44, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> > Sorry if this is a tad OT, but I need some quick advice from you
> network admins.  What are the going recommendations for firewall
> software and virus software, on Windoze boxen.  This is for an
> extremely end-user demographic--farmers on dial-up, in fact--so it has
> to be easy to install.  (And hardware firewalls are out, because these
> people could never be persuaded to buy one.)  Probably around 50%
> Win98 and 50% XP.
> > 
> I still have to recommend dial-on-demand floppy routers, the hardware
> can be found for next to nothing, and once they are set-up nobody has to
> mess with anything.  On a winblowz box, you never know when some popup
> will install a server that will get by zonealarm (or disable it).

I am assuming this is a rollout to many people.  A added box has a
number of new points of failure:

1)  The hardware (Chips, memory, etc.).
2)  The floppy.
3)  Its network card.
4)  The network card in the windows box.
5)  The cable (assuming a crossover).
6)  The power supply to the box.
7)  People believing that the "box" is broken.

1-6 are huge when everything is remote.  

7 is enormous.  People see this "other" box, and it does black magic,
and therefore it is the evil thing.  I am not exaggerating.  I had a
tech savvy client call me 6 or 7 times because the proxies I built were
down.  I would walk them through a process to only discover that the
proxies were clearly blocking only HTTP calls that were routed to the
database, the same database that went down repeatedly.  Each time I had
to explain how difficult it would be for the proxy to suddenly go down
for one type of call over the other when it did no content filtering. 
But each time they blamed the black box rather than run a simple test. 
I finally created an active web page to do monitoring, but that is
another story of human stupidity.

The main advantage of a box approach is with SSH you can log in and
monitor the connectivity and answer questions.

The real problem is the box only protects against direct port attacks
per se.  If you add squid it can filter adware, some malicious code.  If
you add A/V streams it will catch downloaded streams.

It will not catch malware that is not detected in streams.  It will not
protect IE from attacks (unless the filter is updated constantly).

It will not protect if these machines are portable.


 
-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com

Zot O'Connor added:
<<SNIP>>

> 6)  The power supply to the box.

> tech savvy client call me 6 or 7 times because the proxies I 
<<SNIP>>

  These can also be good things.

  We also have a problem with my wireless broadband business with a clueless
customers and old Win machines.  Our basic premise is that we *do not want*
to open the customers case or install software.  We're trying to avoid
playing the blame game over sudden failures on or around the installation
time.  The techs doing the installs carry hardware firewalls (and USB NIC's)
in their trucks.  

  The customer is notified when we schedule the installation to have a NIC
card and firewall installed.  If they fail to do that, we *highly* recommend
that the purchase a hardware firewall from us.  (At a tasty little markup.)
If the case needs to be opened, or software installed, we point them to
local PC service providers.  

  Our service agreement also includes a clause that strongly states that we
*will* disconnect their machine from the network if it becomes a problem.  

Steve D...

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Nov  6 13:06:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Nov  6 13:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Multiple Disks
In-Reply-To: <sfaa3826.022@gwsmtp.ohsu.edu>
References: <sfaa3826.022@gwsmtp.ohsu.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311061300010.15083@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 6 Nov 2003, Steven Shea wrote:

> My server box has two disks: disk a and disk b. I installed Linux and
> Oracle9i in disk a, and created two databases in /u01 and /u02 in disk a.
> Now I want to move /u02 to disk b and create /u03 in disk b. Can anyone
> show me step-by-step how to do this? Thanks.

Steven,

  In linux-speak you have /dev/hda and /dev/hdb. Were both recognized and
partitioned by the Red Hat installer? If you type 'df' you'll see the amount
of free space on every partition and it will show you the mount point for
each hard drive partition.

  Assuming that they're both partitioned and formatted for linux, all you
need to do is edit (as root) /etc/fstab. Unmount /u02 (as root, 'umount
/u02'), change the mount point of /u02 to a partition on /dev/hdb, then
remount it ('mount /u02').

  If you have a free partition on /dev/hdb, you can change its name in
/etc/fstab to "u03"). If not, then you'll need to run 'fdisk /dev/hdb' and
make some space -- and a mount point -- for it.

Rich

From drl at drloree.com  Thu Nov  6 13:37:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Thu Nov  6 13:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Winders Security Software Recommendations
In-Reply-To: <1068144387.29923.5370.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
References: <20031106014438.380212d3.jason@vancleve.com>
	 <1068133850.675.585.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	 <1068144387.29923.5370.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <1068154607.670.701.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Thu, 2003-11-06 at 10:46, Zot O'Connor wrote:
> On Thu, 2003-11-06 at 07:50, Derek Loree wrote:
> > On Thu, 2003-11-06 at 00:44, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> > > Sorry if this is a tad OT, but I need some quick advice from you
> > network admins.  What are the going recommendations for firewall
> > software and virus software, on Windoze boxen.  This is for an
> > extremely end-user demographic--farmers on dial-up, in fact--so it has
> > to be easy to install.  (And hardware firewalls are out, because these
> > people could never be persuaded to buy one.)  Probably around 50%
> > Win98 and 50% XP.
> > > 
> > I still have to recommend dial-on-demand floppy routers, the hardware
> > can be found for next to nothing, and once they are set-up nobody has to
> > mess with anything.  On a winblowz box, you never know when some popup
> > will install a server that will get by zonealarm (or disable it).
> 
> I am assuming this is a rollout to many people.  A added box has a
> number of new points of failure:
> 
> 1)  The hardware (Chips, memory, etc.).
> 2)  The floppy.
> 3)  Its network card.
> 4)  The network card in the windows box.
> 5)  The cable (assuming a crossover).
> 6)  The power supply to the box.
> 7)  People believing that the "box" is broken.
> 
> 1-6 are huge when everything is remote.

Practically speaking, only 2 and 7 are real problems.  4 need not be
considered, network cards are at least as sturdy as win-modems (and more
stable from my experience).  The floppy router will need to be running a
"real" modem, which will make for a much better connection and they seem
to run forever.  As for 5, network cables are at least as sturdy as
phone lines, subject only to physical damage.  Sure there is a chance
that other hardware will fail (you forgot the memory), but most of the
older stuff that is still around is very sturdy.

If you start with a fresh power supply and CPU fan (if it needs one),
then the average time to failure should be at least a couple of years.

So, it really comes down to the floppy as the main weakness.  This can
be solved by using a slightly newer box that will boot a CD-ROM
firewall, or by wrapping the floppy drive in a plastic bag.  It looks
tacky, but it does solve at least two of the most common problems.  Dirt
collecting on the media as it sits waiting for a power outage and people
ejecting the disk because they have been trained to think that a
computer shouldn't be booting the floppy disk.  Heat build up is not an
issue, because the floppy drive is run so rarely.
>   
> 
> 7 is enormous.  People see this "other" box, and it does black magic,
> and therefore it is the evil thing.  I am not exaggerating.  I had a
> tech savvy client call me 6 or 7 times because the proxies I built were
> down.  I would walk them through a process to only discover that the
> proxies were clearly blocking only HTTP calls that were routed to the
> database, the same database that went down repeatedly.  Each time I had
> to explain how difficult it would be for the proxy to suddenly go down
> for one type of call over the other when it did no content filtering. 
> But each time they blamed the black box rather than run a simple test. 
> I finally created an active web page to do monitoring, but that is
> another story of human stupidity.
> 
The beauty of these black box's is that they just work.  When the end
user gets used to this idea, they learn to start their trouble shooting
elsewhere.  I have a feeling (but no concrete evidence) that supporting
a herd of floppy routers (essentially configured the same) would be much
less expensive than supporting a herd of winblows machines directly
connected to the web, just from a man-hours required point of view.

> The main advantage of a box approach is with SSH you can log in and
> monitor the connectivity and answer questions.
> 
Not if it can't dial out.  But, you can have the customer log in (this
could be over a null-modem) and follow instructions from tech support.
 
> The real problem is the box only protects against direct port attacks
> per se.  If you add squid it can filter adware, some malicious code.  If
> you add A/V streams it will catch downloaded streams.
> 
> It will not catch malware that is not detected in streams.  It will not
> protect IE from attacks (unless the filter is updated constantly).
> 
I will have to admit that this is true, but this is not part of the
firewall function, it is a function that MUST be run on winblows to make
up for the lack of careful design, independent of the firewalling
technique.  There is a difference between network intrusion and software
intrusion, the firewall should be responsible for stopping network
intrusion, and software on the local host should be responsible for
stopping software intrusion.  You can't get away from running software
intrusion stoppers on each winblows box.
 
> It will not protect if these machines are portable.
> 
This is also true, and short of running a reasonable OS on the portable,
I don't have a good answer to this one.

I know this will probably never fly, but it sure is fun to imagine an
ISP that will provide linux boxes as a firewall solution.

Derek Loree

From raanders at acm.org  Thu Nov  6 17:27:01 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Thu Nov  6 17:27:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Database E-R design tools
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311060903260.14328@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0311061739590.29853-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Thu, 6 Nov 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I've just looked on freshmeat.net and the only two CASE tools for database
> design are a year or two since the last news on their home pages. I'm
> looking for a tool that will allow me to set up a database schema by drawing
> entities and relationships and then produce the sql that can be used by
> PostgreSQL.
> 
>   Anyone have suggestions?

	http://gborg.postgresql.org/browse.php?84


I should look at more rigorous design practices but stick with the
rock-throwing design method.  Put something together, give it to the
users, and have them throw rocks at parts they don't like.  Well actually
I usually can't get them to sit down and _really_ analyze/describe what
they want done.  So I put something together that I think is right and 
they throw rocks at it - I fix the broken parts and we restart the cycle.  
The rocks do get smaller and fewer as we go along.

   So I can't say which of the above is good, bad, or ugly.


Rod

somewhere.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Thu Nov  6 19:04:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Thu Nov  6 19:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Boot screen decoration
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311061743531.17610@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311061743531.17610@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <32818.131.252.202.59.1068174152.squirrel@mail.axpr.net>

>   On the new laptop, the Emperor Linux folks replaced the simple,
> distinguished Tux with a banner across the top of the entire screen that
> screams, "I got mine @EmperorLinux.com". Ugly. And, if they want me to
> advertise for them I need to be paid for the service.

AFAIK, that's in the kernel itself, and is all built-in.

If you take their .config (they did provide you one, right?)... you should
be able to just rebuild the kernel and get rid of that nasty thing.

However, if they patched other things in the kernel, as well, you're
probably going to be looking at needing to locate which patches they
applied and where.

Then again, there may be a boot-time switch you can pass to lilo (or grub,
I like grub myself) to tell the kernel to turn that nasty buggar off.

Rob






From carla at bratgrrl.com  Thu Nov  6 19:11:01 2003
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Thu Nov  6 19:11:01 2003

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311061743531.17610@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

Message-ID: <200311061910.48540.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Thursday 06 November 2003 5:49 pm, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   When my Slackware machines boot -- using the frame buffer display
> -- there's a small image of Tux sitting in the upper, left corner of
> the screen. Looks almost 3D and is a nice addition to the information
> scrolling by.

Are you booting with GRUB? Look for something like this in grub.conf:
splashimage=(hd0,0)/boot/grub/splash.xpm.gz

Then all you need is to find the image you want displayed, and edit GRUB 
accordingly.

> by.
> 
>   On the new laptop, the Emperor Linux folks replaced the simple,

>

> have a custom kernel and I'm wondering if this banner is a binary built in
> somewhere.

It's built into the kernel.  The tux image data normally lives in
  include/linux/linux_logo.h
Since they changed the size, you may have to unpatch their kernel to
take it out.  Alternatively, you could get the fblogo program and create
your own linux_logo.h.  It would need to have the same dimensions as
their logo.  Another option would be to hack their logo file to something
simple, like a solid color.

It looks like the dimensions for the logo are in fbcon.c.

galen

I was thinking about getting another hard drive for
either internal or external use, so I wandered into
Circuit City. My eyes nearly popped when I saw a WD
160G drive, $90 after rebate. Oh, boy! What a steal!

So I open the box, and out slides this controller
card. Except for the lastest systems, they say, you
need to use this controller because the drive is
larger than 137G, Drivers are included for Windows, of
course.

Does Linux suffer from the same limitation? If so,
does it have its own drivers? If not, can the drive be
used without the card, merely sacrificing some of the
drive's capacity, which is gargantuan? At least, by my
standards? BTW, the PCI card is for 2.1-compliant
systems. My HP Pavilion 7950 is fairly new, so can I
be pretty confident that this requirement is met?

With hard drive capacity increasing continuously, I'm
sure that many potential upgraders would be interested
in the answers to these questions.

Oh, yes. If it doesn't seem suitable for installation
inside the computer, could it be used in a FireWire
enclosure without the controller?

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Thu Nov  6 23:12:11 2003
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Thu Nov  6 23:12:11 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux and >137G IDE Drives
In-Reply-To: <20031107060628.2866.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20031107060628.2866.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200311062311.40110.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Thursday 06 November 2003 10:06 pm, Robert Kopp wrote:
> So I open the box, and out slides this controller
> card. Except for the lastest systems, they say, you
> need to use this controller because the drive is
> larger than 137G, Drivers are included for Windows, of
> course.
>
> Does Linux suffer from the same limitation? If so,
> does it have its own drivers?

The 137G limit is an ATA/IDE limit. LBA24 (large block addressing) can't 
go any higher.  The controller card probably supplies LBA48, whether it 
works with Linux I guess you'll be finding out. But any limitations in 
the Linux kernel are probably up in the terabytes.
 
Oh, and that 137G is the usual inflated fakey gigabyte- 137 billion 
bytes. Which is about 128 "Real" gigabytes,  2^28 bytes, or 268,435,456 
sectors of 512 bytes. (I just happened to be looking at this my own 
self...)

From chris-plug at maybe.net  Thu Nov  6 23:18:01 2003
From: chris-plug at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Thu Nov  6 23:18:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux and >137G IDE Drives

Message-ID: <20031107071716.GE11145@maybe.net>

On Thu, Nov 06, 2003 at 10:06:28PM -0800, Robert Kopp wrote:
> Does Linux suffer from the same limitation? If so,

(I had a bit in here about how I boot my 240GB volume just fine. But
then I realized it's probably because of the RAID controller's BIOS.
Nonetheless, Linux doesn't have limitations -- your BIOS may.)

> does it have its own drivers? If not, can the drive be

Need more details on the chipset of the add-in card. I've used off-board 
HPT and CMD controllers in the past without much hassle. Just have to be
sure you get all the drive lettering straight ahead of time. :-) Early
on many of the chipsets either had no support in Linux or had serious
hardware bugs. These days everything is pretty much a non-issue.

(Side note: The only tricky bit these days is the pseudo-RAID ATA
controllers that are shipping more and more with popular mainboards.
Either don't use the board's RAID [Linux's md is usually faster anyways],
or be very careful about which drivers work in the kernel or don't.
Why is this an issue? These controllers aren't really RAID. They
facilitate the OS booting and then pretty much leave all the legwork to
Windows drivers.)

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Fri Nov  7 07:53:02 2003
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Fri Nov  7 07:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] linux issues, identical hardware, one works with linux,the other just with windows. Solar flares? 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 07 Nov 2003 04:39:36 PST."
             <E1AI5ta-000882-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> 
Message-ID: <20031107155214.1BF1A8F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Karol Kulaga <root at loraksus.org> wrote:

> -To totally reset the partition information, write zero's to the drive, 
> dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/hda bs=512
> 
> Ok, cool, did. Took bloody long (like 3 hours for a 60gb drive), putting a
> task in the background in a console is just so damn cool though ;)

The person that posted that forgot to add the count argument.
dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/hda bs=512 count=1

Without the count argument, the dd command will write to the entire
disk, thus the 3 hours to complete.  With a count of one, dd will just
wipe the initial boot code and partition table, which should be
sufficient.

galen




From ed at alcpress.com  Fri Nov  7 08:00:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Fri Nov  7 08:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Flash cards and linux...
In-Reply-To: <1068212941.2237.46.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1068212941.2237.46.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1068220954.28177.128.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Fri, 2003-11-07 at 05:49, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> Has anyone used one for the swap partition?  If pcmcia slots are
> installed to a desktop system it seems like 128 meg pc flash
> cards can be had fairly cheap.  I've at least spotted some four
> meg ones.  Many require a USB device to read them, but not all
> the ones I've seen just poking around on E-Bay.
> 
> I guess Linux can be installed to flash card.  This would be
> a nice way with an older computer to build a cheap router,
> wireless access point, etc.
> 

Flash memory is far too slow to be useful as swap storage. It's
better to spend your money adding fast memory to avoid swapping
or a hard disk to have fast swap storage.
Flash memory also has a finite (but large) number of writes before
it fails (you can no longer write to its storage).

It reminds me of the time I demoed a RAID5 array of USB flash
memory drives. It's cool that we can do it but ultimately not
practical.

Ed

From ed at alcpress.com  Fri Nov  7 08:30:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Fri Nov  7 08:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux and >137G IDE Drives
In-Reply-To: <200311062311.40110.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <20031107060628.2866.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>
	 <200311062311.40110.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1068222751.28463.148.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Thu, 2003-11-06 at 23:11, Carla Schroder wrote:
 
> Oh, and that 137G is the usual inflated fakey gigabyte- 137 billion 
> bytes. Which is about 128 "Real" gigabytes,  2^28 bytes, or 268,435,456 
> sectors of 512 bytes. (I just happened to be looking at this my own 
> self...)

fakey gigabytes - I love it. You could also call them "ordinary
people gigabytes" or "luser gigabytes" since it's based on the
normal base 10 system we're all taught in school, where
1 gigabyte = 1000 megabytes.

Instead of "real" gigabytes to describe situations, such as
memory, where 1 gigabyte = 1024 megabytes, we can call them
"computer geek" or "elite" gigabytes since ordinary people
don't normally think in these units.

Or we can use the more boring international system (SI) of units
where 1000 megabytes is called a gigabyte and 1024 megabytes
is called a Gibibyte, where the "bi" part stands for binary
or base 2. This system has been in place for years but has
never caught on. My publishers have always 86ed these terms
in my books, so the old system of confusing base 2 and base 10
units is assured a long life.

Ed




From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Fri Nov  7 08:50:02 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Fri Nov  7 08:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux and >137G IDE Drives
In-Reply-To: <20031107060628.2866.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0311070836480.24035-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On Thu, 6 Nov 2003, Robert Kopp wrote:
> So I open the box, and out slides this controller
> card. Except for the lastest systems, they say, you
> need to use this controller because the drive is
> larger than 137G, Drivers are included for Windows, of
> course.
If your motherboard is recent enough, you don't need the new card, i
so try it first. If your motherboard IDE controller supports UDMA/100,
it'll almost certainly handle large disks, and if it supports UDMA/66
the odds are good it will too (these features are not related, they just
usually go together).

The card is most likely supported by Linux out of the box, it'll probably
be recognized by the same IDE module, if you have a recent 2.4 kernel.
I tried the cards which come with Maxtor and WD drives, they all work.

> Does Linux suffer from the same limitation? If so,
Linux supports large drives just fine. It does not even need the BIOS
support (of course it does need LBA48 from the controller, otherwise the
bus just does not have enoug bits to address the disk and it cannot be fixed
in software).

> Oh, yes. If it doesn't seem suitable for installation
> inside the computer, could it be used in a FireWire
> enclosure without the controller?
It should work fine inside, I have a 250G disk in my PC and a 160G one,
no problem. But if you want to go external, you can get an enclosure
which converts IDE to USB2 or Firewire. They are about $60 at Fry's or you can
get them from the net for half of that (newegg sells USB enclosure for
$30 now). You need to make sure they have large disk support, most new ones
do but if you buy from ebay you should ask.
Now we get to really interesting stuff, whether that will work with your
Linux box.
I obviously haven't tried ALL distributions, but I know that stock Linux
kernel has a problem with USB-2 and if you try to copy several GB of data
onto external USB2 disk it'll lock up. RedHat patched their kernels, since at
least 2.4.18 they work just fine, I often write out over 150GB of stuff on
USB disk in one command.
I don't have a firewire disk, I do use Firewire-to-SCSI module (sbp2), and
it works for stuff like scanners, I just don't know how stable it is for
large disk (on the other hand, my scanner can send several GB of data when
it scans a roll of film, and I never had problems with it).
--

From chris-plug at maybe.net  Fri Nov  7 09:06:01 2003

On Fri, Nov 07, 2003 at 05:49:01AM -0800, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> Has anyone used one for the swap partition?  If pcmcia slots are
> installed to a desktop system it seems like 128 meg pc flash
> cards can be had fairly cheap.  I've at least spotted some four
> meg ones.  Many require a USB device to read them, but not all

I wouldn't recommend it. Writing to flash isn't fast enough to justify
it and flash has a limit to the number of times it can be rewritten
(granted it's pretty high, but if you use it as swap on a small system,
you're going to hit it *much* faster).

> a nice way with an older computer to build a cheap router,
> wireless access point, etc.

That it would, very much so. To help answer the above question in the
context of this one, you *can* run Linux without a swap partition. This
is particularly done in these kinds of scenarios.

On Fri, 7 Nov 2003, Robert Kopp wrote:

> Is there a comprehensive listing of supported hardware anywhere?

The problem is that every kernel version has a different set of
hardware support. That, and distributions often backport or import
from CVS newer hardware support into their kernels. So any
supported-hardware list would have to be keyed to every single
possible kernel -- a daunting task!

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri Nov  7 10:57:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Nov  7 10:57:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Fedora Core 1 'Yarrow' Bittorrents
In-Reply-To: <1068230064.1186.51.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <20031106231109.5bcf0d94.dzl@frenetic.com>
	 <1068230064.1186.51.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1068231361.3708.41.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Fri, 2003-11-07 at 10:34, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> On Thu, 2003-11-06 at 23:11, Daniel Logghe wrote:
> > 
> > Torrents for the ISOs are available at
> > 
> > http://torrent.dulug.duke.edu/
> > 
> Interesting. 
> 
> Is this a kind of "distributed ftp" project? it looks like the client is
> bidirectional.

That's pretty much exactly what it is, just it doesn't use FTP itself.

It's a distributed application that allows one master server to control
a bunch of clients, so you share and download whatever it is you're
working on getting.  The end result is a system that doesn't get clogged
up when a new release happens.  If 50-million folks all started
downloading something via BitTorrent, the only place you might run in to
a bottleneck would be at the controlling server.  There may even be a
way around that, I haven't looked in to it enough.

If 50 million folk start downloading something via BitTorrent, it has 50
million sources, too.

This is the way Pat decided to distribute the slackware 9.1 ISOs. 
BitTorrent was the only way to get them for a few days, until the
mirrors grabbed and put up ISOs themselves.  Bandwidth at slackware.com
has always been such an issue, I think it was the perfect solution.

Rob

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Nov  7 10:58:12 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri Nov  7 10:58:12 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Big Hard Drives (>137GB) on Linux
Message-ID: <20031107185700.GA17741@gate.kl-ic.com>

I use a number of large hard drives under Linux, with the 2.4.20 and
later kernels.  Here's the scoop:

The new LBA48 drives can sometimes be jumpered down to an 8GB drive
(uh, who cares?) but other than that you need an LBA48 driver card.
The good news is that Alan Cox has written drivers for these, and
these drivers are in the recent kernels (and in Fedora, Redhat 10,
and probably the most recent Suse distros).  The first drive will
probably show up in your system as /dev/hde .  The second drive on
that cable would be /dev/hdf, on the second connector on the card
/dev/hdg, etc.

Most of the boards that come with the drives are rebranded Promise
boards.  I have also seen HPT chipsets.  A.C. built drivers for both.

Them's the good news.  However, it gets weird if you get exotic. 
With one of my motherboards, *two* drives on these cards gets confused;
the motherboard doesn't quite figure out which drive to boot from.  On
another motherboard, boot works fine.  That is with any combination of
one or more large and zero or more "small" drives.  (120G is "small" :-) )

USB2:
You can also talk to these large drives with some of the USB2 interfaces.
I do this because I use the big drives for backup and want to hot swap
them.  A.C. has written IDE hotswap drivers that work with the regular
cards, but these have not found their way into the mainstream kernels
yet.  Probably by spring 2004.  So, more about USB2:

You take a speed hit.  The big drives are ATA-133 - that is a theoretical
raw 133MB/second, while the USB2 is theoretical raw 40MB/second.  I have
never seen either interface reaching those speeds.

I have a SanDisk InClose removable drive swap rack, driven off USB2 - 
this will talk LBA48.  However, the card appears to suffer from buffer
overrun or something, and when I move large quantities of data very fast
(like 1GB/minute for 5 minutes) it sometimes locks up.

Today I will be trying out some ViPower IDE to USB2 swap racks;  I want
to see if they suffer from the same overrun problem.  They have a different
chipset.  According to ViPower tech support, their cages work with the
large drives.

On external USB2 to IDE enclosures, the ADS LI5-USBX-804 enclosure will
not talk to LBA48 drives.  The GWC Technology UD-200 USB to IDE adapter
cable will not talk to larger drives, but by Q1 2004 the UD-200A will
(according to email from their tech support).    

There are a lot of other options out there.  I hope I have conveyed the
impression that most things work with large drives most of the time, but
expect a little hassle, mostly hardware problems and not Linux problems
per se.

Most of the LBA48 solutions are described as "up to 300GB", while LBA48
has a theoretical maximum of 144,115,188 GB;  however, I suspect that
by the time we get to those capacities we will be talking to the hard
drives very differently!  At full ATA133, such a drive would take more
than 30 years to write.  The 300GB limit is probably because the interface
makers don't have any larger drives to test with.

And yes, the new big drives ARE cool.  But consider how you are going to
back them up!

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

Mode 5 is Ultra ATA/100, according to information
found elsewhere.) 

They should flat-out say whether it works with drives
larger than 137 GB, as some other manufacturers do.
FireWire enclosures cost about $100, a little more
than those for USB 2.0, but FireWire seems better
supported by Linux, at least at the present time.  

Does Ultra DMA Mode 5 mean that it supports LBA48? I
might prefer to go this route instead of the dealing
with the problems involved in installing it
internally.

From john at johntelford.com  Fri Nov  7 12:30:03 2003
From: john at johntelford.com (John Telford)
Date: Fri Nov  7 12:30:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Novell and Linux
Message-ID: <r02000200-1030-1CA37112116111D8B389000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>

My take on Novell/SuSE/Linux/IBM/etc... is every once in awhile
something happens that may alter the course of the Information
Technology industry.  I'm going out on a limb and saying I think this is
such an event.

The Linux kernel and distributions have come a long ways on the road of
maturity in the last couple of years.  Many of the behemoths in the
industry, except Microsoft, are betting big bucks on the technology.

At the same time, it looks like choices Microsoft seems to have made
early on about security and reliability are now coming home to roost.
During Microsoft's most recent conference call, Chief Financial Officer
John Connors said earnings are already being hampered by corporate
buyers who are holding back on purchases because of security fears. 

The Novell services stack is mature.  Running it on Linux offers
Corporate America a way to begin weaning themselves from Microsoft.
Starting with eDirectroy and then possible NetMail are big wins.  As the
Linux desktop matures, there may be more incentive for Corporate America
to get out from under Microsoft's thumb.

The confluence of these events is what I think is altering the course of
the Information Technology industry.

Fortunately, this time around trying to re-invent its self, Novell has
bought Linux and Open Source expertise and products.  It's up to Novell
to make it work.

....John

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Nov  7 12:58:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri Nov  7 12:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Novell and Linux
In-Reply-To: <r02000200-1030-1CA37112116111D8B389000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
References: <r02000200-1030-1CA37112116111D8B389000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311071244240.9995@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 7 Nov 2003, John Telford wrote:
> The Novell services stack is mature.  Running it on Linux offers
> Corporate America a way to begin weaning themselves from Microsoft.
> Starting with eDirectroy and then possible NetMail are big wins.  As the
> Linux desktop matures, there may be more incentive for Corporate America
> to get out from under Microsoft's thumb.

But does it just put them under a different thumb?  And is that a good
thing?

I might argue that a lower price point (due to less monopolistic
aggression) is NOT a good thing... decreasing the monetary cost of being
oppressed does not decrease the oppression.

> Fortunately, this time around trying to re-invent its self, Novell has
> bought Linux and Open Source expertise and products.  It's up to Novell
> to make it work.

Novell is still a software company in the old-school sense.  They sell
bits.  I've always considered SuSE to be something of an interloper in the
world of Free Software.  Sure, they do pay some developers to work some
public stuff, but that's just the "smart business" angle.  They're still
getting way more out than their putting in, then using what they get out
for their private gain.  Their number one goal is not making a better
world for anyone but SuSE.

The situation begs the question of what it means for for-profit software
company to get involved in Free Software.

Will Novell continue to sell bits and, if so, can their commitment to
Free Software and the GPL can be trusted?

This can only be answered in the fullness of time, but unless there are
serious changes to the business model at Novell, I don't see this as a
particularly good thing.

The bigger the software company, the greater the damage when our system is
exploited.  IBM works alright because they are emphatically NOT a software
company.  They sell physical goods.  The software is becoming what it
originally was -- a value-add.

J.

On Fri, 7 Nov 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:
> How do I enable underlined words in the console? When I read
> man pages in an xterm, certain words are underlined. But opening the
> same man page in a console, the underlines are not there. (for
> additional amusement, the underlined words are called "italic")

If you haven't figured this out already, you might want to take a look at
the settings in the system's app-defaults directory.  E.g., here are 3
relevant lines from /usr/X11R6/lib/X11/app-defaults/XTerm on my
system:

! Uncomment this to use color for underline attribute
!*VT100*colorULMode: on
!*VT100*underLine: off

From felix.1 at canids.net  Fri Nov  7 13:09:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Fedora Core 1 'Yarrow' Bittorrents 
In-Reply-To: <1068230064.1186.51.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com> 
    on 07 Nov 2003 10:34:09 PST
    from Mike De La Mater <mikedela@theplatinumrule.com> 
Message-ID: <20031107210850.444AA1592A5@kanga.canids>

Mike De La Mater <mikedela at theplatinumrule.com>:
> Is this a kind of "distributed ftp" project? it looks like the client is
> bidirectional.

with bittorrent, everyone collaborates to distribute a large file
throughout the net.  the large file gets split into pieces, and
you ask a couple neighbors, "do you have piece X yet?" and in
turn you offer any pieces you already have to neighbors who want
it.  by requesting pieces in random order, the work of
distributing the file gets spread across the network, more
efficiently than simple mirroring.
--

It's no great life-changing deal, just one of those funny little Linux 
things that's going to drive me nuts until I figure it out. As it says 
in man man:

"The following conventions apply to the SYNOPSIS section and can be used 
as a  guide  in
       other sections.

       bold text          type exactly as shown.
       italic text        replace with appropriate argument.
       [-abc]             any or all arguments within [ ] are optional.
       -a|-b              options delimited by | cannot be used 
together.
       argument ...       argument is repeatable.
       [expression] ...   entire expression within [ ] is repeatable."

When reading a man page in an xterm, there are lots of underlined words 
(which may not show up in a mail reader), so they are rather important 
to understanding the man page.

Man pages are not so great as teaching tools, they're better for command 
references. http://transamrit.net/docs/rsync/ is a good quick n dirty 
rsync guide.

If you're just doing a one-time copy, scp is good. See the 'Copying over 
the network' section in http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/linux/
library/l-knopx.html for the quick n dirty scp guide.

I suspect you'll need to look into fbcon. Although I can't offer any
more details than that.

As a side note, underlining was introduced in the era of typewriters as
a way of representing text that should otherwise be italicized, as
typesetting italics on a typewriter would be impractical. Strictly
speaking, anywhere you see underlining you should consider it to be
italicized. Of course, years of ignorant high school English teachers
have colored our own perceptions of this issue. ;-)

> That's a great tip, thanks- for Xterm. :) I'm trying to figure out how 
> to make the underlines appear in a console- no X. Or italics, or 
> however they are supposed to be displayed.

Without using some sort of display altering software, I believe you are
stuck with the characters that are represented by the 256 ASCII codes. 

I know in DOS, you can change the locale, and get different characters,
but your still limited to that, except where multi-byte characters come
into play. 

The catch to that is that when you change the locale, all the existing
characters on the screen change too. So, if you change to an italic
character page, all the capital 'A's become italicized capital A's.

I believe it's the same with the linux console.

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Fri Nov  7 16:17:02 2003
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Fri Nov  7 16:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] rsync
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311071325330.2853@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311071325330.2853@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <45266.10.129.0.28.1068250619.squirrel@webmail>

Rich Shepard said:
>   This weekend I want to copy all user files from my current
> workstation to
> the new workstation, and I know that rsync is the way to go. I've
> not used rsync before.
>
>   Is the man page the only (or best) resource for learning the
> intricacies
> of this tool, or is there a more comprehensive document I should
> read first? I do know that for many tools, the man page is a great
> resource for syntax and reminders of specifics when you know what
> you seek but it's a poor resource for learning.

I've found the magic phrase (for me) is:

$ rsync -avP -e ssh user at source:/stuff /stuff

or to go the other way:

$ rsync -avP -e ssh /stuff user at destination:/stuff

-a is archive mode and does a lot of stuff, check the man page. -v is
verbose. -P is --partial and --progress, meaning it will won't delete
partially transmitted files if interrupted and it gives you a purty
progress bar. -e ssh uses ssh as the remote shell; good for obvious
reasons. This covers 95% of all my non-anonymous rsyncing needs. If
ou're feeling gunshy, use --dryrun to see what you _would_ do.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Nov  7 18:48:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Nov  7 18:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] rpm woes
In-Reply-To: <20031107175713.A29557@defiant.ncplus.net>
References: <20031107175713.A29557@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311071845250.3552@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 7 Nov 2003, Bruce Kingsland wrote:

> Now, I'm confused. The query says it's there, but it can't be
> uninstalled. I also ran "rpmdb --rebuilddb" (syntax?) to be sure that
> the db was correct, and re-ran the above sequence, and got the same
> results. How do I fix this confusion so that I can get on with my
> original task (getting quanta installed)?

  Common error, Bruce. When installing a package the full _package_ name
needs to be provided on the command line. However, when erasing the package
only the _file_ name is to be provided on the command line.

  What you want is:

[root at auger whatHere]# rpm -e rpm-4.0.3-1.03

From chris-plug at maybe.net  Fri Nov  7 19:19:02 2003
From: chris-plug at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Fri Nov  7 19:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Figuring out jumpers on one of my new Fujitsu LVD Ultra 2 drives...
In-Reply-To: <1068255724.5166.35.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1068255724.5166.35.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <20031108031805.GH11145@maybe.net>

On Fri, Nov 07, 2003 at 05:42:04PM -0800, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> It's model MAE3043LP.  On the sticker I have ID0 through ID4, must be
> the scsi id's but shouldn't there be eight of these?  I also have

No, they're binary. ID0 = 1, ID1 = 2, ID2 = 4, etc. So if you want a
drive at 5, you'd jumper ID2 and ID0.

> WRITE PROT, START CMD, SINGLE/WIDE, DIFFSENS, SP SYNC, IDD RESET,
> LED, and TERM PWR EN.

For a standard LVD setup you shouldn't need to set any of these, IIRC.

>  I think the jumper block is on the front

Usually.

> I've never set up raid before, I'll have five of these jobbers
> soon and an Adaptec 2940U2W to hook em up to.  Can you put five
> drives on a high desity 68 pin scsi bus? 

You can hook up 15 on LVD if you want. If you have heavy traffic, you'll
see a lot of bus contention, so beyond 5 or so isn't recommended per
channel. (And a 2940U2W only has one channel.)

> I've only seen a cable
> for two.

SCSI cables are really expensive. Generally.

>  Is there a special trick in the form of an adapter or
> something to hook up devices that have the same interface as the 
> Jazz 2 gig drives to this scsi card? 

Yes, but you don't want to. Kinda like ATA33, putting an SE (single
ended) device like that onto an LVD channel will cause the entire
channel to come out of LVD mode. Which means your drives will negotiate
at 40MB/sec, not 80MB/sec.

Fortunately...

> I have an Onstream SC50 to
> hook up to it. 

The 2940U2W has a multi-headed channel, so you can actually connect
single-ended devices on the 50-pin connector on the card. (I'm trying to
visualize the 2940U2W's I've seen, and I think it has one. Should have
an SE 68-pin connector, too.)

> What would really be cool is an LVD scsi to LBA48
> ATA/ATAPI6? tray for the 137gig drives that plugs into my scsi
> card and can be removed hot.  I've got firewire on my Athlon, I'm

Connectors do exist. Search for Addonics. Typically, your overall cost
for a RAID will add up to be more expensive than just going and buying
a 3ware card, though. Plus 3ware makes hot swap ATA enclosures certified
for use with their cards.

BTW-Wanna buy my Jaz2 drive that's collecting dust? :)

strobe light, and play a horrendous sound. It never took more than
about a minute for some schmuck to see it, look around, press a key,
then panic as the "alarm" went off!

: Scott Van Hoosen wrote:
: Way back in the '80s, when Commodore 64's were popular and sold at
: Sears ....
: -Scott


Naww, naww: In the Commodore 64 days you used to SAVE programs with a shoe-box 
cassette player/recorder:

Press 'Record' and 'Pause' on the tape player, cable up from the 1/8" audio 
jack on the back or side of the chassis, and into the tape player.

Then type SAVE with the cursor, release 'Pause,' and hit a carriage return.
(You'd load from tape using LOAD command plus 'Play.')

This could lead to two kinds of fun: (a) record programs over your older 
brother's Hendrix tapes, or pop one of said tapes into the player, LOAD it 
and see what 'All Along the Watchtower' looks like translated into BASIC.

-- GLL

Message-ID: <1068384967.654.4.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Fri, 2003-11-07 at 07:52, Galen Seitz wrote:
> Karol Kulaga <root at loraksus.org> wrote:
> 
> > -To totally reset the partition information, write zero's to the drive, 
> > dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/hda bs=512
> > 
> > Ok, cool, did. Took bloody long (like 3 hours for a 60gb drive), putting a
> > task in the background in a console is just so damn cool though ;)
> 
> The person that posted that forgot to add the count argument.
> dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/hda bs=512 count=1
> 
> Without the count argument, the dd command will write to the entire
> disk, thus the 3 hours to complete.  With a count of one, dd will just
> wipe the initial boot code and partition table, which should be
> sufficient.

I did that on purpose, that way the extra FAT at the end will be wiped
out too, making very sure that the old partitions cannot be recovered.

Derek Loree

When I downloaded the Slackware 9.0 ISOs, I was pulling 50KB/sec, which

(Midnight-6AM, I'd say), I let it go, full speed ahead, until my upload
count was twice the amount I had downloaded... to make me feel like less
of a leech. :-)

I think you can throttle back the upload speeds quite effectively
without risk of being throttled back yourself.

On Sat, 8 Nov 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:

> Now, I've had over 50 a day for the past 4 days, and my mail server is now
> rejecting 60%+ of the attempted connections on an ongoing basis. I had a
> high of 87% last week. It seems my problem is getting worse, not better.
> I'm spending a couple of hours a day dealing with spam.
>
> I have other things that I'd rather be doing.
>
> Is this typical?

  With regard to having other preferred things to do, yes. To have spam
increase, no.

  I filter very aggressively with postfix and average 6 or fewer spam per
day that come through. Some I report directly to the originating ISP, others
I report via spamcop.

  My reject proportion has gone from about 30% of incoming messages to about
60% of incoming messages over the past month or two. But, I don't believe
that has anything to do with how I report spam. It has a lot to do with a
few types of Microsoft virii that come in floods.

David Weston and I finally got ours done.  We lost Jiah.  I hate to see
people fall out, but I suppose there are many reasons for it.  

I tried to talk to my ex's older sister, she was very friendly but the
friend wasn't.  I might have been dumped because of pressure from the
friend on my ex explaining her we shouldn't see each other attitude. 
Still, I'd take back comments about my friend's sister being rude even
though she is.  If I could do it over again, I wouldn't talk about PSU
at all either.  Then again, maybe crashing the party is a blessing, it's
wishful thinking to say I'd be happy if things had worked out.  I hope
if this is the explanation that my ex matures at some point.  One of the
things I love about her so much is how kind she was being only nineteen
years old.  With this friend of mine, his personality can be deceptively
friendly.  I think it's part of it is ego where the other part may be a
filtering mechanism.

Being a young newlywed with probably the first guest isn't easy either.
Perhaps it would have been a lot better if I had met the bride before
the wedding.  I guess I looked kinda needy especially with couples
smooching all over the place.  The wedding was the first time I got to
wear a new double breasted suit getting to try out a flashy red suit
shirt. This shirt kinda changes in the light from red to green.

My dad wanted me to march in a parade today, but the friend complaining
I don't deserve to, I didn't feel like it.  I'm near the bottom of my
family, not the middle or the top.  I'd say the top people are usually
red hots, the middle red hot wanna bes, and the bottom, at least in my
experience, are not well known at all.  For my friends the average age
seems to be fifty five.  Women who like my mother mostly.  I kinda got
set up with Lucy by a couple of mothers.  My dad tried to entice me to
march in my new tux with "some single gal you might like is back from
Iraq."  I agree with the organizations work, but to me right now Knights
is a married men's club where I'm neither married nor at all capable of
changing that at this time.  I'm not even certain I should shoot for
marriage, only the mothers seem to know ;-)  

Still, I've kinda grown up with the knights.  Maybe someday it will be a
lot more fun to be a knight.  Right now, it seems like wearing gold just
makes my dad go all over the place.  The Knights aren't well liked in a
lot of places even among Catholics, sometimes you just want to say I'm
Catholic and not mention Knights membership even though one of the major
points of the organization is to make that statement. It was set up to
protect widows and priests in the old days which it still does today
after nearly 100 years.  It's a large insurance organization, very
large.  The pomp and ceremony it has among male members is unique
though, we'll among the ones who participate in that anyways.  I imagine
it's nothing like San Diego anywhere in this State anymore except
perhaps remote places in eastern Oregon.

In some ways I'd say that the breakfasts and going to dinner is more fun
than ceremonial stuff.  Especially when a friend says you don't deserve
to be in the ceremony where sword, feathers, cape, and suit are worn... 
The costumes are really fancy.  It's as close to the look of a uniformed
military officer as one can get without being military.  One of the
requirements for gold is that my dad is a retired navy commander.  My
father says he's concerned about peoples' fears of the ceremonials of
the organization highly influenced by a time when the knights protected
Catholics physically where noone else would in this country.  That
function is gone in a physical sense, there's no swordsmanship anymore
and no defensive arts training, etc.  In some cases, the organization
has simply decided to abandon the swords at ceremonies.  You can't form
a nice arch without them, they really add something.  It's better to
leave the swords behind than it is to be kept out of the churches in
some cases.  Security for the D.C. event was so high there was no way
anyone could be armed in any manner, even for the sake of ceremony. 
It's not a real military organization.  I shudder to think what the
insurance runs for a group of armed men, especially where popular
culture shuns the group.

As far as the soldier gal back from Iraq, I don't deserve to date a
potential war hero!  I haven't been in this war or any other war for
that matter.

     --  Michael Robinson

On Sat, 8 Nov 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:
> OK, for the last two weeks, I have diligently reported my spam to
> spamcop.net.
[snip]
> It seems my problem is getting worse, not better.
[snip]
> Is this typical?

I've heard lots of folks with this complaint (i.e., spam rising quite a
bit once they start reporting to a centralized authority).

My spam load has been pretty steady for about the last six months (before
which it did jump dramatically, all at once).  Certainly no change in the
past few days.

I would say I also get 50 or 60 spam messages per day.  I reject no mail
at connection time and I would say unsolicited commercial/scam mail
accounts for about 30-50% of my daily message count.

I use spamassassin and it catches all but maybe one message every other
day and is yet to catch a message that I wanted to read.

Personally, I think all that business of blocking and reporting is a waste
of time and energy and just makes the problem worse, but you know that.

From holger at selover.net  Sat Nov  8 17:50:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Sat Nov  8 17:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Spam
In-Reply-To: <20031109000253.GA1661@patch.com>
References: <200311081420.58441.russj@dimstar.net>
	<1068334629.1597.8.camel@halo>  <20031109000253.GA1661@patch.com>
Message-ID: <1068342558.1597.28.camel@halo>

On Sat, 2003-11-08 at 16:02, Michael Rasmussen wrote:
> My problem with spamassassin when I last used it was too many false positives.
> What's your experience there?

Almost none. Mails with score between 5 and 8 are moved into a special
folder to check. It contains app. 5% of all spam. I find a false
positive less than once a month. Everything with a score of over 8 I
never look at. I send out a response telling about a keyword that can be
put into the header to get around the filter. Nobody did this so far. Of
course spammers don't even receive it. 

I almost exclusively receive spam mail on one account that I used as
administrative contact for domain registration. That seems to be
harvested heavily. My private address is only used for direct
correspondence. When I post to newsgroup I use an address that I change
every other month. After an address becomes invalid sendmail will return
an error message that tells about the current one. Again, spammers only
care if it worked on the first shot. 

Lastly, I use dedicated email addresses for eBay and alike. It is just
interesting to see how they are handed around. If the spam level
increases for a given account I change the address with my subscription.
With these dedicated accounts I wouldn't even need SpamAssassin.

I suspect it works like the soups my father used to cook. No recipe and
when one was especially tasty he couldn't tell what he put in. 

Holger

On Sat, 8 Nov 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:
> On Saturday 08 November 2003 05:28 pm, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > Personally, I think all that business of blocking and reporting is a
> > waste of time and energy and just makes the problem worse, but you
> > know that.
>
> Wasn't it you that said something about not reporting it to be passively

I don't recall.

If I did, it was a LONG time ago and I hadn't given the situation serious
thought.

I can see how a person might think that on first blush, but any real
consideration of the mechanics and circumstances immediately reveals that
anti-spam action outside the recipients' mail system counteracts the
network's ability to make us more free, individually and collectively.

I certainly wouldn't EVER condone reporting to a self-appointed authority
like spamcop.net which uses bullying to shut down other people's
connections on other people's networks.  Very ugly.

  I added a second hard drive to my new system and now need to prepare it

  However, I cannot find the appropriate 'mkfs' syntax. The man page is from
1995 and does not include reiserfs. Using apropos I find references only to
minix and sco in addition to ext2.

  I'd greatly appreciate a pointer to a reference that will tell me just how
to format this drive using the reiserfs.

From gcrary at involved.com  Sun Nov  9 09:09:02 2003
From: gcrary at involved.com (George Crary)
Date: Sun Nov  9 09:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Preparing a new hard drive
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311090718340.20149@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

Rich Shepard :
>  I added a second hard drive to my new system and now need to prepare it
> ----
>  However, I cannot find the appropriate 'mkfs' syntax. The man page is from
>1995 and does not include reiserfs. Using apropos I find references only to
>minix and sco in addition to ext2.
>
>  I'd greatly appreciate a pointer to a reference that will tell me just how
>to format this drive using the reiserfs.
>


OK, I guess you found it.  I was going to suggest;

	This looks like a good starting point  --

	http://www.linuxplanet.com/linuxplanet/tutorials/2926/1/

If the reiserfs utilities are available (see below) 'mkreiserfs /dev/hdc1' should create 
the fs, and options are applied with mount.

>From page 5 of same:
"Once the new kernel is built and tested, you can use the mkreiserfs utility to format 
partitions as Reiserfs filesystems. As with the regular mke2fs command, this will erase 
all the data on the partition! (By the way, after you build the kernel you have to go into 
a subdirectory of the kernel source and separately build the Reiserfs utilities, which 
include the mkreiserfs command. Instructions for doing this are found on the Reiserfs web 
site.) Once the desired Reiserfs partitions are formatted, you can use the mount command 
(with -t reiserfs options) to mount them just as you would with regular ext2 partitions. 
You can even put Reiserfs filesystems in the /etc/fstab file to have them mount 
automatically during system initialization."

g

----
 gcrary

Now, it also looks like my doom and gloom is not quite as bad as I thought. 
You can reproduce and distribute SuSE linux CDs. You just can't make any 
money off of them, if they include the YaST program. 

Section 3 of the license states: 

Dissemination 


It is forbidden to reproduce or distribute data carriers which have been 
reproduced without authorisation for payment without the prior written 
consent of SUSE LINUX AG or SUSE LINUX. Distribution of the YaST programme, 
its sources, whether amended or unamended in full or in part thereof, and the 
works derived thereof for a charge require the prior written consent of SUSE 
LINUX AG. 


All programmes derived from YaST, and all works derived thereof as a whole or 
parts thereof may only be disseminated with the amended sources and this 
licence in accordance with 2b). Making YaST or works derived thereof 
available free of charge together with SUSE Linux on FTP Servers and 
mailboxes is permitted if the licences on the software are observed.

> > sufficient.
