<snip>

> 
> Rob

As someone who runs Mandrake in a heavily stressed multi-server
environment (CPU is normally at least 50% during the workday), I
would have to respectfully disagree. Mandrake has been quite stable
for me for the last two years running 8.1, 8.2 and 9.1 in production.

Sure, I've had it crash on me, but normally only on my home systems
running a mixture of weird obsolete junk hardware and lots of
experimental software installs. The one time in recent memory I had
it crash at work was due to a flaky generic motherboard that seemed
to overheat after a while. New motherboard, no problems. On certified
Dell server hardware, it has not crashed for me.

Speed issues are questionable. It seems that you have to be very
careful making remarks like this, because of the wild variety in
distribution setups. Redhat 8 crawls on some of my machines, and 9
isn't much better, but Mandrake seems pretty snappy on the majority.
Subtle things like video driver settings make huge differences in
perceived system response. Plus, if you are going to use a hardware
optimised version of linux for a server, you had better have some
idea of what you are doing and know enough to customize your install
to disable or remove unneeded services. I agree that enabling
services by default may not be the best choice, but Mandrake offers
their 'security level' choices to mitigate that. If you choose to
install a honeypot, set the security to none, if you want to lock it
down, set the security to maximum and let the scripts fight it out.
If you don't trust the scripts, do it manually. It's all about
choice, but I am really careful about what I choose to bash on in
public. (pun intended) :^P

Sean Harbour

issue. Can you map a drive to the problem box from a windows client
reliably using the IP address instead of the name? net use J:

If that works, start looking for wins troubleshooting on google or
hit the books.

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Wed Nov 12 16:00:02 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Wed Nov 12 16:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] homegrown WAP
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A07FD42F0@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Aaron Burt:
> On Wed, 12 Nov 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > On Tue, 11 Nov 2003, AthlonRob wrote:
> > > Something I didn't see mentioned was concrete.  It seems 
> six inches of
> > > concrete might as well be two feet of lead when you're 
> > > dealing with WiFi.
> 
> Which leads me to ask, how bad are cinderblock walls for WiFi?  I'm
> considering moving into a slab 'n' cinderblock 4-plex and 
> hoping I might
> be able to share a connection with a neighbor or two.  Heck, 
> even dialup's
> expensive when you gotta get a phone line to use it.

  You have to remember that WiFi is meant to be a Line-of-Sight or
Near-Line-of-Sight system.  Industrious WiFi operators have pushed the specs
*way* past the intended design.  

  That said, a concrete block wall will throw a lot of loss into the link
budget.  You can try to blast a signal through the wall... or you can try
going through the window and bounce off the neighbors house.  The best
signal may not be a straight line between two points.  Use diversity
antennas to help sort out the multipath signals.  

Sometimes multipath is better than no path at all.  

Steve D...

> I'd be willing to be your refresh rate or screen resolution is set too high

If it is the refresh the way to fix it would be with VertRefresh in
/etc/X11/XF86Config.  Read your monitor docs and find out what the
VertRefresh rate is and the HorizSync rate is as well.  Set them and
hopefully it'll work.

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed Nov 12 17:30:02 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Wed Nov 12 17:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Evil IDE problems fixed
Message-ID: <1068684195.4805.3.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

I have been having odd ide problems on my dual Athlon uber-machine since
I bought it.

I finally figured out what the problem was.

The drive cables were 1" too long.

I bought ata-133 cables that were within spec. I forgot to add in the 1"
of cable in the drive tray for the primary drive.

I removed the drive tray, added shorter cables and everything works MUCH
better now.

The thing that was confusing is that the error messages looked more like
a DMA problem than a cable problem.

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Wed Nov 12 17:55:02 2003
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Wed Nov 12 17:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Tuning MySQL
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0311120823570.12538@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0311120823570.12538@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <200311121754.39643.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Wednesday 12 November 2003 08:31, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> We recently deployed a new set of (contractor-built) web apps at work
> that use MySQL as the backing store. According to top, mysqld is using
> about 75% of the cpu on our web server, a uniprocessor Sun V120
> running Solaris 9.
>
> That seems high to me, and vmstat/iostat indicate that most of the
> work is cpu-bound, not i/o stuff.
>
> If I were to start looking for mysqld options to tweak, what SHOW
> STATUS variables are likely to provide good clues? I haven't done any
> performance tuning with mysql, so don't feel bashful about making
> suggestions that would seem obvious to anyone with a clue. :-)

Normally, a DB is fairly IO-bound.  

Questions:

- how big are the tables?  Please give both tables and indexes (if MyISAM 
format) as % of RAM.

- how much RAM?

- what kind of disk subsystem?   RAID?  I'm assuming SCSI...

- how many simultaneous queries?  SHOW STATUS will tell you this.
Look for max_used_connections.

- what is the ratio between SELECT and mutation operations (DELETE, UPDATE, 
INSERT, REPLACE INTO etc.)?

- what version of MySQL.  4.x will do better caching of some kinds of query.

- are you pulling a lot of data back and sorting it by fields that don't have 
indexes?

- do you have some nasty cartesian joins happening?

- what table types are you using?  MyISAM?  InnoDB?  

- You do have Paul DuBois' "MySQL", right?

My gut feeling is that you have insufficient indexing and your tables are all 
small and sit in the RAM disk cache.  However, you're still doing a lot of 
table scans.  That's my guess.  If handler_read_rnd is pretty high compared 
to the other hander_read_X counters then you may be table scanning.  This is 
in the output of SHOW STATUS.

MySQL performance comes down to just a few parameters most of the time:

- if you have about 50% or more of your indexes in key cache, you'll be OK.  
It can be less if most of your queries hit the part that is in the key cache.  
When the index stops fitting in the key cache, you start to hit the knee in 
the MySQL performance curve (at least with MyISAM tables).

- if you have carefully made sure that the per-thread caches and buffers are 
fairly small, you can handle a lot of simultaneous connections.  If not, you 
will find yourself swapping.  Then you die.  I've had desktop PCs that handle 
over 500 simultaneous connections without a problem, but that was after a 
little (not much) tuning.  

These are extremely rough rules of thumb.  YMMV.  Use with caution.  Do not 
operate heavy machinery while using this product.  Etc. Etc.

Best,
Kyle




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Nov 12 18:35:03 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Nov 12 18:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Seagate SCSI Documentation
Message-ID: <19633-17048@sneakemail.com>

I recently ran across some excellent documentation on the Seagate site.
They do not have it indexed well at all, but the document is a complete
discussion of the SCSI commands that Seagate drives use:

http://www.seagate.com/support/disc/manuals/scsi/38479j.pdf

I noticed this referenced in the documentation for a 5 year old SCSI drive
I'm thinking about buying.  Funny how 5 year old 47GB drives tend to be
built a bit more stout than new drives...

The manual for that drive is excellent and reminiscent of "old school"
documentation.  I was surprised that there wasn't a schematic in the back
of the PDF.

http://www.seagate.com/support/disc/manuals/scsi/29280a.pdf

This is the first drive document that I've seen that details everything
that goes into the MTBF calculation.  In particular, the duty cycle of the
drive, whether a SMART warning counts against MTBF, etc.

I may have to buy a couple of these antiques just because the
documentation is so good.  They'd be good replacements for my 11 year old
2GB drives.

  -- Steve



From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Nov 12 19:27:01 2003
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed Nov 12 19:27:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Evil IDE problems fixed 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 12 Nov 2003 16:43:15 PST."
             <1068684195.4805.3.camel@zontar.clueserver.org> 
Message-ID: <20031113032644.5E48E8F05@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Alan <alan at clueserver.org> wrote:

> I have been having odd ide problems on my dual Athlon uber-machine since
> I bought it.
> 
> I finally figured out what the problem was.
> 
> The drive cables were 1" too long.
> 
> I bought ata-133 cables that were within spec. I forgot to add in the 1"
> of cable in the drive tray for the primary drive.
> 
> I removed the drive tray, added shorter cables and everything works MUCH
> better now.
> 
> The thing that was confusing is that the error messages looked more like
> a DMA problem than a cable problem.

The problem was more likely due to the impedance discontinuity introduced
by the connectors associated with the drive tray.  IOW, if your connection
was just a plain cable of the equivalent length, I bet it would have
worked.  Of course, its a miracle that the IDE interface works at all
at 133 MHz.

galen

Thus spoke Sasha Romanosky, on Wed, 12 Nov 2003 19:37:14 -0800:

> I've been curious about Gentoo. I know nothing about it, aside from
> its debian like package management. Do you know this well enough to
> elaborate on its benefits?

A few things to begin with, if I may.

1. Nothing is installed automatically, except of course dependencies of the packages you install; and (as you've probably heard) everything is compiled, using your own optimizations (defined globally in /etc/make.conf).  So you get lean, speedy operation.

2. Updates are cake.

3. You can run pretty much any kernel you want, depending upon whether you want stability, speed, cutting-edge, etc.  Below is my output from "emerge -s sources", which should include all the kernels currently available through the portage system.

--Jason

In-Reply-To: <20031112125714.3ea8d968.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20031112070806.31379.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>	<Pine.SOL.4.58.0311121008010.3776@asteroids.gpcc.itd.umich.edu> <20031112125714.3ea8d968.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <3FB328BF.6070902@spek.org>

Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> but then, you can't patch a .deb binary at all, can you?

Why not?  I patch binary files every day with xdelta, it's quite handy. 
  It has the ability to produce freakishly small patch files for 
gargantuan binaries - which always mystifies me.

It looks like somebody else is using it on .debs too:

from: http://sourceforge.net/project/shownotes.php?release_id=6688

* The new ``pristine'' option (-p, --pristine) disables
   automatic uncompression of compressed input data, and is for use
   when data integrity is being externally verified.  This enables a
   tool written by Manish Singh (yosh at gimp.org) to compute deltas
   between the Debian dpkg utility's .deb format.

--Brent

On Wed, 2003-11-12 at 13:24, Sasha Romanosky wrote:

> What is it exactly about Mandrake that makes you say its unstable, bulky
> and not geared towards a server setup

They use devfs, which is not ready for general use.

They use the grsecurity patches, which tend to have problems. 
(Especially with devfs.)

Trying to work with their programmers is an experiment in abuse and
torture.  (Having done it more than once.)

Some good ideas.  Implementation is lacking though.

And its advantages, if any, over gentoo?

> -----Original Message-----
> From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org 
> [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Jason Van Cleve
> Sent: Wednesday, November 12, 2003 10:06 PM

> 
> 
> Thus spoke Sasha Romanosky, on Wed, 12 Nov 2003 19:37:14 -0800:
> 
> > I've been curious about Gentoo. I know nothing about it, aside from 
> > its debian like package management. Do you know this well enough to 
> > elaborate on its benefits?
> 
> A few things to begin with, if I may.
> 
> 1. Nothing is installed automatically, except of course 
> dependencies of the packages you install; and (as you've 
> probably heard) everything is compiled, using your own 
> optimizations (defined globally in /etc/make.conf).  So you 
> get lean, speedy operation.
> 
> 2. Updates are cake.
> 
> 3. You can run pretty much any kernel you want, depending 
> upon whether you want stability, speed, cutting-edge, etc.  
> Below is my output from "emerge -s sources", which should 
> include all the kernels currently available through the 
> portage system.
> 
> --Jason

Thus spoke Brent Rieck, on Wed, 12 Nov 2003 22:46:23 -0800:

> Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> > but then, you can't patch a .deb binary at all, can you?
> 
> Why not?  I patch binary files every day with xdelta, it's quite
> handy.  It has the ability to produce freakishly small patch files for
> gargantuan binaries - which always mystifies me.

Curious.  So these are binary patches to prebuilt packages, correct?
Interesting concept, but I shouldn't think it very useful to someone who
wants to use a diff from a mailing list, or who has written their own
patch, as I have done sometimes.  Sounds like you need the source to
create these binary patches (and probably to rebuild the .deb); so from
an end user perspective, it should be much easier to just build from
source and be done with it.

Now in the gentoo world, instead of distributing a binary patch (if I
understand the xdelta process), an updated "ebuild" is distributed with
an added source patch.  Then the source tarball, which is normally kept
on the user's system, can be rebuilt with the new patch.

Well, different strokes, naturally. . . .

--Jason

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Nov 13 00:57:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Nov 13 00:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Debian metapackages
In-Reply-To: <200311122257.16745.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200311122257.16745.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311130055220.9995@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 12 Nov 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:
> Is it correct to think of metapackages as 'fakey' packages?  For
> example, I've been experimenting by removing individual games from
> KDEgames, using dpkg --force-all. It doesn't seem to break any real
> dependencies. Otherwise, trying to remove any individual game means
> apt-get wants to remove the whole works.

Err, a meta-package IS a fakey package.  It has no data, only
dependencies.

Personally, if I ever use a meta-package, I always remove it immediately.
That is to say, install the meta-package and its dependencies, then remove
the meta-package and the dependencies stay.  Now you can deal with them
all independently.

Work like bear-bone charm.

J.

From Trench-Shoring at gmx.net  Thu Nov 13 02:39:02 2003
From: Trench-Shoring at gmx.net (Trench Shoring)
Date: Thu Nov 13 02:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Batteries and UPSs
In-Reply-To: <20031111202211.GA10415@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20031111192901.2570.53157.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
 <20031111192901.2570.53157.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <5.0.0.25.2.20031113023240.021d19e0@mail.gmx.net>

A few years ago I asked a similar question on a solar / wind power list.
Could I use a car battery for my UPS. The answer I got back stunned me. The 
person who responded wrote that after a few months after installing a car 
battery in his unit, his children got sick with a mysterious symptoms. His 
spouse was getting ill and after a few more months of torturous diagnosis 
someone did a lead test that came back positive.
A UPS uses SEALED lead acid batteries for a good reason.

TS

At 12:22 PM 11/11/2003 -0800, you wrote:

>Concrete floors or not, the question was whether car batteries work
>on UPSs.  I tried it, with a Topaz charger/discharger meant for car
>batteries, using some brand new marine deep-cycle batteries. They were
>continuously being trickle-charged in a room temperature room.  They
>were sitting on a few sheets of corrogated cardboard (in case they
>leaked) in the unused fireplace in my office (in case they vented
>anything lighter than air, like H2).
>
>I had 4 batteries in parallel - I had earlier tried some experiments
>with a UPS that used 48V, so I had the batteries.  The lower impedance
>of 4 batteries made no difference to the UPS;  all good UPSes limit
>current during charge and discharge, so it does not matter if the
>battery looks like 12V with 0.1 ohms in series, or 12V with 0.00001
>ohms.  Of course, it does matter if something shorts out in the UPS,
>which is why I was no longer experimenting with the 48V UPS, it would
>have died regardless of the battery feeding its failure, but the failure
>was "more spectacular" with 4 marine batteries than 4 gel cells.
>
>I was careless;  I forgot to monitor the fluid level and the batteries
>dried up.  Refilling with distilled water and appropriate battery acids
>did not help - they apparently sulfated or something.  I had to
>recycle the batteries about a year after I bought them.
>
>My "take home" lesson is that batteries need maintenance, and that
>lead-acid open batteries need more maintenance than UPS batteries.
>My UPSes are now running on standard sealed UPS batteries, which I
>assume are designed to last a lot longer in this kind of application.
>They kick in about once a month when the power glitches, as it does
>in the fall out here in the 'burbs.  Horny squirrels romancing the
>insulators on the transformers - BANG,  Rocky the Frying Squirrel -
>out goes a branch line, and the circuit breakers flip to alternates.
>But I digress.
>
>If I had to store a LOT of power for UPSes, for example a data center
>with a lot of computers that needed to stay up until the emergency
>generator started, then lead-acid batteries with a monthly maintenance
>check would probably be just the thing;  I would rather pay the tape
>monkey to check cheap batteries instead of buying more-expensive
>batteries. But for home and small business use, a good UPS that uses
>sealed long-life batteries might be more convenient and less expensive
>for careless people like me.
>
>Keith
>
>---
>Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
>KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
>Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

On Thu, 2003-11-13 at 09:41, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> Trench Shoring wrote:
> > A few years ago I asked a similar question on a solar / wind power list.
> > Could I use a car battery for my UPS. The answer I got back stunned me. 
> > The person who responded wrote that after a few months after installing 
> > a car battery in his unit, his children got sick with a mysterious 
> > symptoms. His spouse was getting ill and after a few more months of 
> > torturous diagnosis someone did a lead test that came back positive.
> > A UPS uses SEALED lead acid batteries for a good reason.
> 
> Wonder how the lead got out since its melting point is over 600F and boils 
> at 3180F.

Even as a solid, it still has a small vapor pressure.  That is caused by
random energy distributions, and some of the atoms receive enough
kinetic energy to leave the surface of the material. Heavy metals cannot
be processed by the human body very well (if at all), and can build up
over time if the exposure is consistent.

Derek Loree

contact to get enough lead to poison children, like a favorite pewter

my kids hang out in, next to my server.

On Tue, 2003-11-11 at 00:19, Robert Kopp wrote:
> I am continuing with another aspect of using Linux
> with large drives and offboard controllers. RH8 and
> Mandrake 9 are two distros known ot work with such
> controllers.
> 
> As at least one member of this list reported, hda and
> hdb can appear as hde and hdf when the drives are
> attached to the offboard controller. So I suppose that
> if the Linux installation is cloned from a smaller
> drive, fstab should be modified to reflect the
> anticipated changes, prior to grabbing the
> screwdriver. Any other potential problems?

Under Redhat 7.x and probably other 2.4 systems as well there
was a changed in fstab.  Boot labels supposedly allow absolute
device references to be replaced with labels.  I have never 
been able to get it to work with custom kernels though where
having two drives installed with the same labels on their 
partitions would result in a conflict.  The other problem 
is that even unmounted, unplugging or plugging in an Inclose 
PMD9i drive bracket while the system is running will crash 
the system.

What is needed to make hot swapping of drives into and out of
ATA brackets work?

: some chemical reaction that removed the lead, I'd understand it, but
: lead consumption is not a normal part of regular battery operation,
: IIRC. Maybe his charger was doing something hinky?
:
: I'd suspect a source other than a battery in an area that I wouldn't let
: my kids hang out in, next to my server.

Could it have been the electrolyte, rather than the lead?

- GLL




From mikedela at theplatinumrule.com  Thu Nov 13 10:37:01 2003
From: mikedela at theplatinumrule.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Thu Nov 13 10:37:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] floppy disks @#$!!
In-Reply-To: <200311131017.43824.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200311131017.43824.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1068748574.1175.51.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

On Thu, 2003-11-13 at 10:17, Carla Schroder wrote:
> Is there some trick to using floppy disks on Linux? Or are floppy disks, 
> in general, just poo? I'm trying to save docs from Open Office on 
> floppy disks, and the darn things fail as often as they work.

I've gotten spoiled with CDs and network connections, because floppies
are, IMNSHO, just this side of two tin cans and a string. I think the
cassette method mentioned on the list recently was more reliable.

Floppy issues I know about:
Cleanliness- since nobody uses them any more, they get pretty dirty as
an air inlet. I tape them shut on machines I admin.

Calibration- There are issues with tolerances on FDD's. Not knowing the
technical terms, some seem to be set on the "wider" and others toward
"narrow" and of course they do not play well. A work around that I use
for this is:
If you are trying to put data onto a specific destination machine, try
formatting the floppies on the dest and then putting the data on with
the source machine. Sometimes that works. Other times I have to use a
third machine to format them. Sometimes I can't get one to format for my
life. I have a case of unformatted, blank plain label 1.44 floppies from
the days when Software Pipeline was in Gresham that work for me most of
the time. I'll send you a few if you can wait for them.

Small Business Networks and Computers

From griffint at pobox.com  Thu Nov 13 10:46:02 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Thu Nov 13 10:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] sustained ping attack
Message-ID: <20031113184433.GA14808@aracnet.com>

Hi all,

The topic is firewalls, in this case running Linux. There's an outer
firewall an an inner firewall in a typical DMZ configuration.

What sort of attack involves sustained pinging of the inner firewall (or 
any other box behind the outer firewall) over a period of at least 24 
hours?

The pings are coming from seemingly random sequences of IP addresses. The 
outer firewall is blocking the ICMP traffic, so other than a very busy 
syslogd process there are no ill effects from this attack, so far anyway.

Given that the attack doesn't seem to be achieving anything, why would
it continue for so long? Is there still some potential for the attacker
to gain something from it? The only thing I can think of is the potential
to fill up the /var partition and whatever might come from that.

Much thanks,
Terry
-- 
Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Nov 13 10:50:03 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Emacs
In-Reply-To: <1068705478.28298.10.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1068705478.28298.10.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311131047040.1659@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 12 Nov 2003, Bill Spears wrote:

> I'm using RH 8.0 and the default desktop.  What is the trick for cutting
> and pasting between Emacs and say an HTML form? The simple texteditor
> works as expected, and copy to Emacs works, but going from Emacs doesn't
> work. I'm aware that copying something from Emacs puts it into the X kill
> ring, I just don't know how to exploit that.

  Hold down the shift key and left rodent button while you highlight the
desired text in emacs' window. Go to the X application in which you want to
paste the buffer. Place cursor in the proper place and press both rodent
buttons (or button #3 if it's available) and the text should paste.
Sometimes I need to hold down the shift key when pasting (as I do in another
virtual terminal), then the two buttons without the shift. Shrug. It woiks.

From michael at robinson-west.com  Thu Nov 13 10:55:03 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Thu Nov 13 10:55:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Attempted dd copy, ran into problems...
Message-ID: <1068749466.27726.19.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I had two 40 gig hard drives, one ATA-133 and the other ATA-100.
I was trying to dupe one to the other because a system didn't seem
to be working with the ATA-133.  The first thing I noticed when
I opened the case is that the shop installed high density 80 wire
cable to the onboard ATA-33 controller.  It seems the drives are
slightly different sizes.

I tried dd if=/dev/hde of=/dev/hdf bs=512k which seemed to work except
I got a out of space or something error on the target and the Windows
system that's supposed to be on there gave an error about the drive 
not being LBA formatted or something about problems with the end of
the partition.  One drive appears to 41 gigs and the other 39.  The
data doesn't come anywhere near to filling up the source.  Maybe
I should /dev/zero the target, partition it manually as FAT32, then
do the same dd command with a count=something argument.

From michael at robinson-west.com  Thu Nov 13 11:01:01 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Thu Nov 13 11:01:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] sustained ping attack
In-Reply-To: <20031113184433.GA14808@aracnet.com>
References: <20031113184433.GA14808@aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <1068749847.27726.26.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Thu, 2003-11-13 at 10:44, Terry Griffin wrote:
> Hi all,
> 
> The topic is firewalls, in this case running Linux. There's an outer
> firewall an an inner firewall in a typical DMZ configuration.
>

> 
> The pings are coming from seemingly random sequences of IP addresses. The

> 
> Given that the attack doesn't seem to be achieving anything, why would
> it continue for so long? Is there still some potential for the attacker

> to fill up the /var partition and whatever might come from that.
> 
> Much thanks,
> Terry
> -- 
> Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>

I'd try writing a specific REJECT without logging rule if you know
what's being pinged so that you can protect your logs.  Seems like
there are a lot of port 135, 137, 139,and 445 probes.  When doing
DENY in iptables I think it logs, there must be a way to disable
logging.  Some say REJECT is more polite because the attacker, 
someone who may just be someone making a mistake, gets an error.
I think slammer, SOBIG.F, etc. are sending massive streams of data
from infected computers where this process starts by finding an
open port of a vulnerable application.  I've run into tons of 
attempts against my apache server to overwrite DLL's and .exe 
files, course it's not a Windows box so until someone sends a
Linux virus I'm not prepared for I'm fine.  Log pollution is a
major issue though.  Noone wants to know about a problem that
doesn't have an affect and in fact isn't a concern.

> > Is it correct to think of metapackages as 'fakey' packages?  For
> > example, I've been experimenting by removing individual games from
> > KDEgames, using dpkg --force-all. It doesn't seem to break any real
> > dependencies. Otherwise, trying to remove any individual game means

> Err, a meta-package IS a fakey package.  It has no data, only
> dependencies.
> 
> Personally, if I ever use a meta-package, I always remove it immediately.

> the meta-package and the dependencies stay.  Now you can deal with them
> all independently.
> 
> Work like bear-bone charm.

And, btw, Karla, even if you do --force-all, they'll all come back in
the next upgrade/dist-upgrade. Jeme's got the right idea.

From ehem at m5p.com  Thu Nov 13 12:57:03 2003
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Thu Nov 13 12:57:03 2003
Subject: Sluggish Mandrake WAS RE: [PLUG] Fedora change...
In-Reply-To: <20031113070302.19159.79899.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200311132056.hADKuFwY040435@m5p.com>

> From: Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com>
> Thus spoke Sasha Romanosky, on Wed, 12 Nov 2003 19:37:14 -0800:
> > I've been curious about Gentoo. I know nothing about it, aside from
> > its debian like package management. Do you know this well enough to
> > elaborate on its benefits?
> 
> A few things to begin with, if I may.
> 
> 1. Nothing is installed automatically, except of course dependencies of the packages you install; and (as you've probably heard) everything is compiled, using your own optimizations (defined globally in /etc/make.conf).  So you get lean, speedy operation.
> 

<cough>

You get speedy operation if you know what you're doing. There were some
tests done using various installations of Linux. *ALL* of the
distributions with binaries optimized for Pentium outperformed Gentoo. In
some cases Debian, which still builds for i80386, outperformed Gentoo's
custom builds.

The guess was that though the other distributions weren't specially
optimized, they still had people who knew more about the packages and
could simply choose the build options better.

In the general case doing your own build of programs/packages is silly.
The cost in time and electricity needed is quite large, and mostly for
not very large gains.

	<20031113003839.4ea25354.jason@vancleve.com>
	<3FB3ADEE.7010707@spek.org>
Message-ID: <20031113142414.05c8caed.jason@vancleve.com>

Thus spoke Brent Rieck, on Thu, 13 Nov 2003 08:14:38 -0800:

> they'd distribute.  But it seems so dramatically easier to just
> download the pre-patched version.

So where are you using xdelta, then?

> Does Gentoo also distribute the pre-patched source in addition to the 
> patch, or does it make everybody apply the patch?

I believe when a new version of the source is released, that is distributed (along with a new "ebuild" without the old patches); but if only a patch is added, that is simply applied to the last official source tarball (which is usually already there on the client's machine).  This way the sourceballs can be downloaded from any number of servers.  It would be a bad idea to distribute a new tarball for every patch, some of which are written for gentoo specifically.

Note that applying patches is something emerge handles.  The user should never have to worry about it.

--Jason

I use xdelta to create diffs between large hourly backups on a remote 
server.  I then distribute the diff around to a few machines and can 
recreate any of the backups w/o having to download gigabytes per day, 
  another bonus is that the space required to store the diffs is tiny 
compared to the original files.

> Ok, I've been futzing with this and aren't quite getting it- how do you
> remove the metapackage?

apt-get purge metapackagename

That's how I'd do it... it perhaps just use aptitude or even dselect?

Just remove it.  Take it away.

> It certainly sounds like a better way than force-removing things, if I'm
> going to have dependency messes then using Debian is rather pointless.

Right.  So you just use the metapackage to get the dependencies, then
remove the package.

I don't really use the front-ends anymore, but I remember in dselect that
you could select a meta-package and go to a dependency resolution screen
where you could pick and choose dependency-meeting packages.  On that
screen, you leave the required/recommended dependencies selected, but
remove the meta-package itself.

Pretty sure apt will do the right thing and not remove the dependencies.

Are you sure, I would verify the source first.  Theoretically there's
nothing wrong with USB devices except that there's such a resistance
by manufacturers to make them work under Linux or anything other
than Windows it seems.  This could be solved by companies establishing
themselves on a model that only produces OSS friendly USB devices so
that the cost of doing business with Microsoft is avoided which I'd
say has been the major factor keeping non Windows alternatives down 
for years.  Forced purchase of MS-dos OEM agreements come to mind,
otherwise DR-Dos probably would have won.

I think the incompatibility of digital technologies with non Windows
systems on top of the complexity for Windows begs the question why
not just live with an old style cameras instead.  Right now I'd say
the trouble using technology compared to the benefits can be
improved dramatically.  Computer independent digital photography
techniques for this reason are becoming very popular.  What a 
waste that so many people will buy a special printer for doing
photographs because using a standard computer is such a hassle.

From chgenly at verizon.net  Thu Nov 13 16:56:53 2003
From: chgenly at verizon.net (Chris Genly)
Date: Thu Nov 13 16:56:53 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Worms that attack Linux...
In-Reply-To: <1068460056.4173.5.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <20031110101852.59499158D68@kanga.canids>
	 <1068460056.4173.5.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1068691746.6218.52.camel@gimli.genly.us>

Writing a bug free software system is a daunting task.  For any real
world commercial program I think it is impossible.  There has been a lot
of research into formal proofs of correctness to show that the code
implements the spec.  But the techniques are not practical.  Also, when
you are done, all you know is that the program matches the spec (a very
big achievement).  You don't know if the spec is correct.  Often a
system is specified and built, and then it is not quite what the
customer wanted.  But in the real world the spec is informal, and often
quite incomplete.

So the problem of writing a correct program is left to the skills of the
architects and programmers and the processes which support them, such as
iterative programming.  Unfortunately architects and programmers are
humans.  They have good days and bad days and they have all the
frustrating limitations that come with a human mind.  To a large extent,
programming is the process of managing complexity (using the techniques
you mentioned).  Even the best minds can't keep constant vigilance for
all bugs all the time.   Often a programmer is working on getting a
function or method to work in the common cases, then comes work on the
more rare edge conditions.  But what happens if you forget to work on
one of the edge conditions.  Or what if you worked on it, but you made a
mistake.  You got the general idea right, but the code is in fact
wrong.  Another programmer reading your code may understand your
intention, but machines do not.  As in civil engineering, if you get it
wrong and the bridge falls down, good intentions don't count.  Some
small fraction of this erroneous, missing or extraneous code may present
vulnerabilities which are accessible to a clever and evilly intentioned
virus writer or system cracker.  

Code reviews can help.  But this is not done everywhere. 
(Interestingly, for popular open source software, the code may be
reviewed in a totally informal and opportunistic way without the authors
knowledge).  But even in code reviews not everything is flagged. 
Programmers are often very busy and often find it hard to begrudge time
for a code review.

I like languages which support the quest for correctness. C and C++ are
not among those languages.  Pointers, arbitrary casting, lack of array
bounds checking, the ability to clobber arbitrary memory, and not
flagging memory problems when they occur are some of the problems.  C
and C++ rely heavily on the programmer for correctness.  A language like
Java or C# gets rid of these low level problems by requiring type
safety, garbage collection, bound checking, etc.  This still leaves a
lot of complexity for a programmer to deal with.  But it does lighten
the burden.  

I view the features of C# and Java devoted towards correctness like a
spell checker in a word processor.  The spell checker reduces spelling
errors enormously.  But that doesn't mean you writing a good novel.

I'm a Java fanatic.  But even I realize that Java is not appropriate for
every situation.  I can't wait to see what the languages of the future
will do to help the quest for correctness.

P.S.  I wrote this during compile times while debugging a Java program.
:-)

On Mon, 2003-11-10 at 02:27, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> It depends on how affectively I use modularization, functional
> abstract, in some languages classes.  It helps to program 
> piecewise.  This is where a statement of what code does 
> can be nicer than the looking at the code itself.  Where 
> such a statement is concise, accurate, and covers what's 
> needed to depend on that code safely it can be satisfactory
> to skip direct code inspection.

Quoth Elliott Mitchell, on Thu, 13 Nov 2003 12:56:15 -0800 (PST):

> You get speedy operation if you know what you're doing. There were
> some tests done using various installations of Linux. *ALL* of the
> distributions with binaries optimized for Pentium outperformed Gentoo.
> In some cases Debian, which still builds for i80386, outperformed
> Gentoo's custom builds.

Well, that's just remarkable.  Why would 386-optimized software outperform that compiled for, say, a pentium4 right on it's host machine?  It's right counterintuitive. . . .  Do those tests use the same kernel?

> The guess was that though the other distributions weren't specially
> optimized, they still had people who knew more about the packages and
> could simply choose the build options better.

So when you say "if you know what you're doing", you really mean, "if you know how to strip down your system and your binaries were built well".  Then again, gentoo builds include a default set of options (which can be tweaked by users as needed but aren't usually).  Does this imply those default options are not well chosen for performance?  Is it just a matter of gentoo's developers not yet knowing all the build tricks?

I should like to understand this.

> In the general case doing your own build of programs/packages is
> silly. The cost in time and electricity needed is quite large, and
> mostly for not very large gains.

Especially if it results in slower binaries!  On the other hand, being able to build in new patches easily is a nice way for us modem users to keep up to date.  There seem to be only a few distros which really facilitate that.  (But that was my second point.)

--Jason

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Nov 13 17:45:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Nov 13 17:45:02 2003
Subject: Sluggish Mandrake WAS RE: [PLUG] Fedora change...
In-Reply-To: <20031113180851.350de8eb.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20031113070302.19159.79899.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
 <200311132056.hADKuFwY040435@m5p.com> <20031113180851.350de8eb.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311131722240.22235@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 13 Nov 2003, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> Why would 386-optimized software outperform that compiled for, say, a
> pentium4 right on it's host machine?  It's right counterintuitive. . . .

It's counter-intuitive if your intuition is only the most simplistic kind
of understanding.

I don't mean to say you're simple or anything, just that there are lots of
things that contribute to fast performance and default gcc optimizations
for a particular processor is just one small part.

> > The guess was that though the other distributions weren't specially
> > optimized, they still had people who knew more about the packages and
> > could simply choose the build options better.
>
> So when you say "if you know what you're doing", you really mean, "if
> you know how to strip down your system and your binaries were built
> well".

I think that "if you know what you're doing" means "if the package
managers carefully tune their makefiles and compiler options for
application-specific performance boosts".

That is to say, the package management in Debian (or the like) is very
specific.  I think Gentoo tries to set system-wide compilation options
instead of application-specific compilation options.  That last bit could
very well be coming out of my ass.

> Then again, gentoo builds include a default set of options (which can be
> tweaked by users as needed but aren't usually).  Does this imply those
> default options are not well chosen for performance?  Is it just a
> matter of gentoo's developers not yet knowing all the build tricks?

I think this is closer to it.

There are some intelligent choices that must be made when conflicting
system and application compilation options can be chosen.

I think it's something like this:
Binary distributions:  Each application is carefully tuned for a generic
system.
Gentoo:  The system is carefully tuned for generic applications.

The result, at this point in time, is faster performance in the former.

Perhaps if a system like Gentoo could be built where compilation options
are deduced by some intelligent process that merges application
considerations with system considerations, a source-based distribution
could be really fast.

I've never used Gentoo, but I've built plenty of systems from scratch and
the performance of each application varies (in comparison with, say,
Debian) depending on how much effort I put into tuning it at compile time.

> > In the general case doing your own build of programs/packages is
> > silly.
>
> Especially if it results in slower binaries!

Word.

> On the other hand, being able to build in new patches easily is a nice
> way for us modem users to keep up to date.  There seem to be only a few
> distros which really facilitate that.  (But that was my second point.)

Well, hopefully we can get some of this monopolistic bullshit out of the
way and bring broadband capability to every household like they do in
first-world nations like South Korea.

Natural monopolies should be public endeavors and copyrights need to be
cut way, way down in either scope or time (I prefer to limit scope a whole
lot and time a bit).  Until you call this crazy non-sequitor talk, I
should probably point out that I believe the "entertainment" industry is
the biggest reason for a lack of broadband technology roll-out.  We should
be able to put 100Mbit internet connections in the home... just not at a
profit.

J.

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Thu Nov 13 18:19:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Thu Nov 13 18:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Palm USB question
In-Reply-To: <1067065836.2863.39.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0311131816010.24035-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

Check if usbserial and visor modules are loaded. For Treo you may need to
get the latest pilot-link and compile it yourself. Then after usbserial is
loaded you'll get ttyUSB devices (btw, usually you need ttyUSB1 not 0,
there is a HOWTO on that, Palm opens two channels and USB1 is the one you
want).

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Thu Nov 13 18:38:01 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Thu Nov 13 18:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux training
In-Reply-To: <1068632933.29923.5702.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0311131804200.1178-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

A number of local people have tryed to give commercial grade Linux
training over the years.  This includes several of the well known
computer training companies and a number of smaller companies and
consultants.  Some of them did ok for a while, but not in the longer
run - at least not yet.  Of course, the corporate training market
doesn't do well in recessions and we are indeed in a high-tech recession.
On the other hand, people go back to school during recessions and
there is a good demand for Linux classes in career schools, community
colleges, etc.  Unfortunately, the public schools don't seem to have
money to hire instructors to satisfy the needs - but they exist all
the same.

                                              Dave Mandel

Message-ID: <1068778127.5501.19.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Thu, 2003-11-13 at 08:14, Brent Rieck wrote:

> Does Gentoo also distribute the pre-patched source in addition to the 
> patch, or does it make everybody apply the patch?

When you emerge a package with Gentoo, it downloads the tarball if it
isn't already on your system, then it downloads any patches the ebuild
dictates.

If you have, for instance, gaim-0.69 and want to upgrade to gaim-0.71,
you don't just download a patch... when you emerge gaim-0.71, it
downloads the whole gaim tarball.  The same is true with the kernel or
anything else - there are some big source packages out there.

It would sure be neat if they provided a patching system so you didn't
have to download the whole thing again, only a compressed patch, if you
already had the original tarball....

Gentoo does deliver the pre-patched source, as well as the patches, when
you emerge something.  If you want to not patch something, you simply
comment out the patch lines in the ebuild.

Rob

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Thu Nov 13 19:45:02 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Thu Nov 13 19:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Palm USB question
In-Reply-To: <20031114032251.GB17596@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0311131941130.24035-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On Thu, 13 Nov 2003, Rogan Creswick wrote:
> With my visor the /dev/ttyUSB* devices aren't created until I hit the
> hotsync button on the cradle (I am using devfs), and I think I had to
> manually create /dev/pilot to point to the correct one.
>
> I never bothered to get it working "right" since it wasn't worth the
> time to me, but this may at least get it so you can sync.
No, you got it working "right". ttyUSB* is created when usbserial is loaded,
and, unless you have some other device which loads it first, it'll happen
for the first time after you press hotsync. /dev/pilot is not a "standard"
device, merely a convenient symlink, so you do need to create it manually,
but only once (it does not go away), and you can point it to ttyUSB1 even
if you don't have ttyUSB1 yet.

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Thu Nov 13 19:49:01 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Thu Nov 13 19:49:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Patents
In-Reply-To: <024301c3aa4a$810dc150$4901a8c0@mango>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0311131929320.31361-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>


On Thu, 13 Nov 2003, Steven D. Coffman wrote:

> I have a question if anyone is familiar with this subject:
> I am doing "contract work - no specifics" for a start up company.
> Another contractor and myself developed some Intellectual Property that
> the Start up wants to get the patent on as it is now their new direction
> (it's a Business Intelligence Software design).
> We know they must include our names on the patent as the Inventors, but
> the CEO also is adding his name (did none of the work), and wants us to
> sign it over to the company stating that the company "owns it". 
> We have only signed a non-disclosure agreement and nothing else. We have
> not been compensated for the invention. Do we have anything to stand on
> to just keep it in our names?

I'm not a lawyer and I don't play on on TV...

You're sure that the NDA didn't cover things you might come up with during 
the course of your work with the company?  I recall that the NDA I signed 
when I was contracting covered this issue.  You say you haven't been 
compensated for the invention, but have you been compensated at all for 
any of the contract work?  That may be an issue.  Of course if they don't 
pay you they would be violating the contract and maybe that means you can 
tear up your side of it too.

BTW: I heard recently (from an IP Lawyer) that the law in Washington and 
California limits what ideas companies can claim from their employees.  
In Oregon we apparently don't have that protection - here they can draw up 
sweeping employment contracts where they can claim the idea you had while 
in the shower this morning.  So, if the company you're working for is in 
Washington (or perhaps if you live in Washington) you might have more 
leverage than you would if it's in OR (especially if you can show that you 
came up with the idea at home and not on the company's premises.)

<digression>I sometimes wonder what it would be like if patents were only 
issued to people, not companies.  You come up with the idea and your name 
is on the patent and it 'travel's with you even if you go to a different 
company... Wouldn't that be interesting.  After all, it's 
supposely 'intellectual property' - the product of someone's intellect.  
When you think of it this way, how can a corporation have intellectual property?
</digression>

Phil




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Nov 13 20:30:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Nov 13 20:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Compiling Packages: Which Directory?
In-Reply-To: <20031114030256.GC2330@nellump.net>
References: <20031114030256.GC2330@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311132025270.5080@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 13 Nov 2003, Paul Mullen wrote:

> When building software packages from source, is there any convention as to
> which directory the compilation actually takes place in? I've read in some
> places that it's recommended to un-tar the source package to a src/
> directory, and then move to a complementary build/ directory before going
> through the 'make' steps. In my experience, though, that doesn't always
> work. Some packages barf completely when you attempt to build them in a
> directory other than that which contains their source tree. Any thoughts?

  I use two top-level directories for building from source: /opt and
/usr/local. I'll untar in one or the other, cd to that directory, then run
./configure, make and checkinstall from there.

  Others like to build in the /home filesystem. I suppose you could do it
all in /usr/src, too. The end result is determined by $PREFIX in the
configuration step: the executable will be installed in /usr/bin or
/usr/local/bin.

Rich

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Nov 13 20:45:03 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu Nov 13 20:45:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Compiling Packages: Which Directory?
In-Reply-To: <20031114030256.GC2330@nellump.net>
References: <20031114030256.GC2330@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <86llqjmud3.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Paul" == Paul Mullen <pem at nellump.net> writes:

Paul> When building software packages from source, is there any
Paul> convention as to which directory the compilation actually takes
Paul> place in? I've read in some places that it's recommended to
Paul> un-tar the source package to a src/ directory, and then move to
Paul> a complementary build/ directory before going through the 'make'
Paul> steps. In my experience, though, that doesn't always work. Some
Paul> packages barf completely when you attempt to build them in a
Paul> directory other than that which contains their source tree.  Any
Paul> thoughts?

Yes, sometimes it barfs.  In barfing cases, you do what works.  In
lazy cases, you can usually build in the source directory anyway.
Some packages recommend against srcdir==objdir (e.g. gcc):

 ``First, we highly recommend that GCC be built into a separate directory
   than the sources which does not reside within the source tree. This is
   how we generally build GCC; building where srcdir == objdir should
   still work, but doesn't get extensive testing; building where objdir
   is a subdirectory of srcdir is unsupported.''

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Nov 13 21:31:01 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu Nov 13 21:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Patents
Message-ID: <20031114052930.GA4540@gate.kl-ic.com>

S.C. writes:
> We know they must include our names on the patent as the Inventors, but
> the CEO also is adding his name (did none of the work), and wants us to
> sign it over to the company stating that the company "owns it".
> We have only signed a non-disclosure agreement and nothing else. We have
> not been compensated for the invention. Do we have anything to stand on
> to just keep it in our names?

I am leaving your name off of this, and I would suggest you discuss
this under a pseudonym.  Every employer you hope to have from now on
will have a search engine, and your mail to this group is on the web
forever.  Yes, being careful about public statements sucks.  But dissing
your current employers or the expectations they share with many future
employers is a career limiting move.  Be very careful.  Freedom of speech
means you can say damned near anything you want, without getting beaten
or jailed.  Freedom does NOT exempt you from consequences.

That said;

I have my name on 7 patents.  One made a trickle of money, the rest
prevent me (and almost everyone else) from ever developing my own
inventions further;  I don't work at those places anymore.  

Patents are typically worthless.  A very small fraction actually make
money for the patent holder.  If you want to fight this thing, be
prepared for a lot of grief with a small chance of reward.  

That said, if you signed an NDA then you are stuck - the idea that you
developed on your client's dime may be "yours", but you aren't allowed
to disclose it without their permission.  So you can refuse to sign the 
assignment form, and lose the job of course, but you will not be able
to develop the idea yourself.  You can develop and patent *improvements*
of the idea, but you if you file before your former employer's application
goes public, then you are violating the NDA by revealing the information
you agreed not to reveal.  And they don't get to keep their patent if
your name isn't on the patent and assignment, so why should they file? 
Meanwhile, if somebody else files for the same idea in the meantime
(very likely) then both you and your former employer are screwed.

Have you done a patent search?  www.uspto.gov .  There are over 6 million
patents out there, about 500K are currently in force in the areas of 
electronics and computation, and chances are pretty good that somebody
has already come up with the same idea and already patented it.  It will
take about 100-200 hours of search to find this out.  But wouldn't it be
really awful if you quit over this, and it is all for nothing? 


If, by some miracle, you do get a chance to apply for this patent
yourself,  you will be paying between $20K to $100K to actually file
it, and at the end of an arduous process you will have what amounts 
to a license to sue somebody.  I write most of my own patents, and
do the drawings.   My patent attorney cleans it up, writes the claims,
and jumps through all the hoops of filing.  My patents typically sail
through in a couple of years.  About half of all patents applications
never make it through the process, and a large fraction of those 
remaining won't survive a court battle.  The Nolo Press book "Patent
it Yourself" tells you just about all you need to know to work with a
helpful lawyer.  Trying to do it all on your own will be frustrating
and risky.

Morality:  You were paid by your current employer to do things that will
make them richer.  If you feel they must compensate you extra for being
brilliant, you should have warned them ahead of time and they would have
instead hired someone less brilliant - or less demanding.  If you don't
like working that way, then by all means employ yourself.  Many do.  
But giving yp "your ideas" is the nature of working in a technical
enterprise.  They take the risks, and they get the big rewards.  You
get a regular paycheck, and if you cause a patent to happen you get
another bullet on the resume.  Your bullet item will not be less
valuable if the boss also gets a bullet item.  And if the CEO has 
done patents before, don't minimize his contribution to the process;
patents by veterans are better than those by newbies.

Intellectual Property:  I am writing an article about this, so I won't
go into detail here.   "Intellectual Property" is a metaphor applied
to an arbitary class of law, it is not a real thing.  The term first
appeared in the name of a U.N. Committee in 1967 (!!), and was seized
by the legal community as a way to improve their image and make more
money.  It worked, and now people are thinking that they "own ideas",
and paying lawyers billions to attack other inventors rather than serve
customers.  You can see what a mess that stupid concept is making of
technology in general, and is about to make of your career in particular.

This is a major reason for the dearth of Linux hardware drivers;  
manufacturers hide the source for their Windoze drivers because the 
sources reveal too much about the architecture of their chips.  Why
not reveal?  Because patents are so thick on the ground that any time
you design a chip you inadvertently violate dozens of them.  This is
very expensive to detect and prove by tearing down a chip, but very
easy to detect by looking at code structures and variable names.
Safer to shut up and join a pack of thieves doing closed source.

I won't advise you to roll over on this;  the relationship is poisoned
and you probably should move on, leaving the position for someone with
different expectations.  You should think long and hard, before taking
the next position, about what relationship you are willing to accept
with your next employer.  If you don't want to lose control of your 
ideas, you probably need to start your own company.  After 10 years of
that, you will find out how it looks from the other side of the desk.

If you do decide to stay, you can patch things up with your current
employer by helping them write up a "yellow dog" contract.  This gives
them ownership of the ideas you develop on their paycheck.  That is 
hard to swallow.  But if you can help, and research things properly,
you can limit the time period and the scope of the agreement, and that
will give you and others the freedom to move to new jobs, or invent
independently on your own time.  I've walked out on contracts that came
with stupid yellow dogs, and stayed with others that were more reasonable.
Help the next contractor out by clearing this up, hmm?


Personally, I think the idea of "owning ideas" is evil.  Because 90% of
my fellow citizens haven't realized this yet, I have to tread lightly
and compromise an awful lot.  I do patents, not to claim ownership,
but to make specific things happen, most good, some bad.  But sometimes
there is no upside beyond the evil itself, and it is time to walk.

Keith

Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs



From chgenly at alum.mit.edu  Thu Nov 13 21:32:02 2003
From: chgenly at alum.mit.edu (Chris Genly)
Date: Thu Nov 13 21:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs
In-Reply-To: <1068705478.28298.10.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1068705478.28298.10.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1068787881.14195.19.camel@gimli.genly.us>

Hi, Bill.

I run in to cut/paste problems all the time in X. You are right, there
are two places to save text.  I don't know the official names, but I'll
call them the clipboard and the kill ring.  Windows only has a
clipboard.  You use the X clipboard using the keys ^X to cut, ^C to copy
and ^V to paste.  The same is true in many X programs.  You use the kill
ring just by selecting text to load it, and the middle button to paste
it.  You can also emulate the middle button by pressing the left and
right buttons at the same time if you have middle button emulation
enabled.

The model of kill ring and clipboard seems fine to me.  The problem is
that some programs implement one, but not the other.  So you end up
having to get something from the kill buffer to the clipboard and the
other way around.  Under KDE there is a tool bar tool called Klipper
which will do this for you.  I use it frequently.  The other problem
with this two buffer model is when a program implements only of these
methods its not always obvious which method it uses.  You have to play
with it.  

It seems to me the kill buffer method is almost always implemented.  The
clipboard may or may not be.

Chris

On Wed, 2003-11-12 at 22:37, Bill Spears wrote:

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Nov 13 21:59:01 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu Nov 13 21:59:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Hot swap IDE in Fedora Core 1
Message-ID: <20031114055809.GA5203@gate.kl-ic.com>

I have been using USB2 cages for hotswap and backup.  Just so you know,
the new Fedora Core 1 (kernel 2.4.22-1.2088.nptl) has Alan Cox's new
IDE hotswap mods.  This means that, if you have the right chipset, you
can now hotswap drives IDE on a running system:

Alan Cox wrote:
> Providing the hw supports it (and if software bits are needed and
> present) then
>
> hdparm -b0 /dev/hdfoo
> remove
> swap
> hdparm -b1 /dev/hdfoo
>
> Note that IDE hotswap (from the physical layer itself) doesn't support
> master and slave operation with hotswap (1 drive per cable only). Also
> doing it with a controller that doesn't support hotswap, or not following
> the controller manual rules about order of power and control cable
> insertion can be expensive.

You will of course need to unmount and mount the file systems before and
after, and you will need an IDE chipset that works with the driver, and
you will need a proper hotswap cage with a proper power controller, and,
and, ...

I am using a Promise TX133 board, rebranded as a Maxtor ATA-133, and it
seems to work fine.  After I get my server converted to Fedora Core this
weekend, I can toss out all that balky slow USB2 stuff.  Then I will 
post the technique far and wide.

Keith

On RH9:
# rpm -q --whatprovides libcrypto.so.4
openssl-0.9.7a-5

On RH8 I only have libcrypto.so.0.9.6b, provided by openssl-0.9.6b-33.
I'd say you'd have to install OpenSSL from the sources to get the .so.4.
Or try a symbolic link to the older version:

ln -s /lib/libcrypto.so.0.9.6b /lib/libcrypto.so.4

and see if that works. 

Or wait until real help comes from the gurus here. ;)

From root at loraksus.org  Thu Nov 13 23:49:02 2003

Date: Fri Nov 14 08:56:01 2003
Subject: Sluggish Mandrake WAS RE: [PLUG] Fedora change...
In-Reply-To: <20031113180851.350de8eb.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20031113070302.19159.79899.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
 <200311132056.hADKuFwY040435@m5p.com> <20031113180851.350de8eb.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <20031114104453.C97792@grond.sourballs.org>

>> In the general case doing your own build of programs/packages is
>> silly. The cost in time and electricity needed is quite large, and
>> mostly for not very large gains.

For what it's worth, here is the FreeBSD handbook position on compiling
from source vs. installing binary packages:

"Package Benefits [i.e., installing binaries]

* A compressed package tarball is typically smaller than the compressed
tarball containing the source code for the application.

* Packages do not require any additional compilation. For large
applications, such as Mozilla, KDE, or GNOME this can be important,
particularly if you are on a slow system.

* Packages do not require any understanding of the process involved in
compiling software on FreeBSD.

Ports Benefits [i.e., compiling source]

* Packages are normally compiled with conservative options, because they
have to run on the maximum number of systems. By installing from the port,
you can tweak the compilation options to (for example) generate code that
is specific to a Pentium IV or Athlon processor.

* Some applications have compile time options relating to what they can
and cannot do. For example, Apache can be configured with a wide variety
of different built-in options. By building from the port you do not have
to accept the default options, and can set them yourself.

* In some cases, multiple packages will exist for the same application to
specify certain settings. For example, Ghostscript is available as a
ghostscript package and a ghostscript-nox11 package, depending on whether
or not you have installed an X11 server. This sort of rough tweaking is
possible with packages, but rapidly becomes impossible if an application
has more than one or two different compile time options.

* The licensing conditions of some software distributions forbid binary
distribution. They must be distributed as source code.

* Some people do not trust binary distributions. At least with source
code, you can (in theory) read through it and look for potential problems
yourself.

* If you have local patches, you will need the source in order to apply
them.

* Some people like having code around, so they can read it if they get
bored, hack it, borrow from it (license permitting, of course), and so
on."

http://www.freebsd.org/doc/en_US.ISO8859-1/books/handbook/ports-overview.html

FreeBSD generally tries to make both paths available, but the impression I
get is that most users compile from source to update their systems (I do).


--
David Fleck
david.fleck at mchsi.com

  su

  chmod -R 777 /mnt/flash

On Thu, 2003-11-13 at 21:31, Chris Genly wrote:
> Hi, Bill.
> 
> I run in to cut/paste problems all the time in X. You are right, there
> are two places to save text.  I don't know the official names, but I'll
> call them the clipboard and the kill ring.  Windows only has a
> clipboard.  You use the X clipboard using the keys ^X to cut, ^C to copy
> and ^V to paste.  The same is true in many X programs.  You use the kill
> ring just by selecting text to load it, and the middle button to paste
> it.  You can also emulate the middle button by pressing the left and
> right buttons at the same time if you have middle button emulation
> enabled.
> 
> The model of kill ring and clipboard seems fine to me.  The problem is
> that some programs implement one, but not the other.  So you end up
> having to get something from the kill buffer to the clipboard and the
> other way around.  Under KDE there is a tool bar tool called Klipper
> which will do this for you.  I use it frequently.  The other problem
> with this two buffer model is when a program implements only of these
> methods its not always obvious which method it uses.  You have to play
> with it.  
> 
> It seems to me the kill buffer method is almost always implemented.  The
> clipboard may or may not be.
> 
> Chris
> 
> On Wed, 2003-11-12 at 22:37, Bill Spears wrote:
> > I'm using RH 8.0 and the default desktop.  What is the trick for cutting
> > and pasting between Emacs and say an HTML form? The simple texteditor
> > works as expected, and copy to Emacs works, but going from Emacs doesn't
> > work. I'm aware that copying something from Emacs puts it into the X
> > kill ring, I just don't know how to exploit that.
> 
> 

Chris, that's the way I remembered.  My problem was that I set my mouse as 
5-button, rather than emulation, and I didn't know about or think to try the
the wheel as the 3rd button.

Thanks one and all.

From ed at alcpress.com  Fri Nov 14 10:28:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Fri Nov 14 10:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux kernel ties to the filesystem
Message-ID: <1068834755.9988.295.camel@localhost.localdomain>

The Linux kernel makes certain assumptions about the filesystem
directory hierarchy. For example, it assumes that there's a
/dev directory (let's ignore devfs). Obviously it knows about
the root (/). I'm wondering what other assumptions _it_ makes.
Note that I'm not talking about daemons or init.

Does the kernel know about /lib or is there another mechanism
that tells the kernel about it?

Is there anything in /etc that the kernel is aware of?

What about /var?

I know this is a difficult question given all the functionality
in the Linux kernel these days.

Ed

> the root (/). I'm wondering what other assumptions _it_ makes.
> Note that I'm not talking about daemons or init.

I didn't know it made any assumptions about the filesystem at all. 
AFAIK, you can put /dev wherever you want to (although it would likely
break other programs which rely on /dev being at /dev)....

I know you can put /proc wherever you want to, although not having /proc
where it normally iswill break programs left and right.

> Does the kernel know about /lib or is there another mechanism
> that tells the kernel about it?

Why does the kernel need to know about /lib at all?

For modules?  It'd be the module (init) tools for that.

> Is there anything in /etc that the kernel is aware of?

I certainly don't know of anything..

> What about /var?

Maybe if you used the old kernel httpd thingy?

> I know this is a difficult question given all the functionality
> in the Linux kernel these days.

I don't think the kernel itself is really all that functional as far as
the filesystem is concerned... it's almost entirely user-space
applications and daemons that write or read from files on the
filesystem, which in tern have an effect on the kernel.

I could be mistaken, though... I just didn't think the kernel cared much
at all about the filesystem.

Rob




From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri Nov 14 11:05:03 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Nov 14 11:05:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] eth0 message
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F64HV6J83jWKjY0001183f@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F64HV6J83jWKjY0001183f@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <1068836631.7921.27.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Fri, 2003-11-14 at 10:37, Vincent Yau wrote:

>   eth0 NIC link is up 10 Mbps half duplex
> 
> I actually think that I should be getting more than 10Mbps.
> I need to verify with my network support but just wondering
> if there is something that I can do to set it higher on my end?
> And why is it half duplex?  Shouldn't it be full duplex?

I think there are tools available for specific network cards to force it
to 100/Full duplex, although I've never had a need to play with such
things, so I haven't.

What kind of network card is it?

10Mbps means you're on a 10BaseT network, not a 10/100 network.  At
least, that's what the network card thinks.

The half-duplex means, more or less, you're using a hub instead of a
switch.  I suppose there are hubs out there that support full-duplex, as
there are hubs that support 100Mbps connections, they're just both
somewhat rare, since switches are so darned common these days.

It looks, to me, like you're using a 10BaseT hub between your computer
and the rest of the network.

One way to test for a hub might be to start using tcpdump or something
similar and watch for packets coming in for other hosts.  If it's a
regular occurance, then odds are you're using a hub rather than a
switch.  If, on the other hand, you're just seeing packets for your
host, then it's probably a switch (or a very very quiet network).

I'm sure there are other ways to test that out... I just don't know of
them as I've never had a need to test such things - I always know what
kind of network hardware I'm using at the time.  :-)

Rob

Verizon has cleaned up the bizarre user names.  You can now pick a real
user name.  The user name is used to access your Verizon web account
(for billing and so on), and your mail pop3 or web mail.  You can also
have five sub accounts for family members.  Each with their own password
and pop3 account.

pop3.

So far I've been pretty pleased with Verizon.  I don't need their
support, so that hasn't been an issue for me.  There have been the
occasional dropouts.  But typically they last less than a minutes. There
was also a problem with their DNS servers being dog slow for a few
weeks.

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Fri Nov 14 13:53:01 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Fri Nov 14 13:53:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] USB-to-serial/parallel port adapters
In-Reply-To: <20031114212049.GB691@nellump.net>
References: <20031114212049.GB691@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <3FB54EA6.2070003@pacifier.com>

Paul Mullen wrote:
> I'm planning on picking up USB port converters for both serial and
> parallel in the near future and was wondering if there are any caveats a
> Linux user should bear in mind when selecting make/model. I've noticed in
> the kernel menuconfig that there seem to be a large array of drivers for
> these sorts of devices. Are any known to work better than others?  Also,
> what price point should I expect to encounter for a decent product? I've
> only shopped USB-to-serial converters so far, and have seen upwards of
> $50 (Fry's) and as little as ~$10 (eBay auction, new item).

I've used a Belkin serial converter with success (~$30).  If you dig around 
the kernel source (drivers/usb/serial), the commented .c files, will 
indicate various supported models.  Not all supported makes/models will be 
mentioned but if you can find one still offered retail, it's a good bet.

Belkin seems to be widely available and hence popular and largely supported. 
  Have no experience with parallel devices.

--
Kyle Accardi

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Fri Nov 14 14:41:02 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Fri Nov 14 14:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux CD Burning software
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F46IxNaeJz9YTD000112bc@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0311141438370.23594-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

xcdroast and the rest of this kind are front-ends to cdrecord.
So, make sure you have cdrecord, and run "cdrecord -scanbus". If that does
not find your CD, stop right there, nothing will work until you get it
fixed. There are many reasons for failure, post the output of cdrecord and
we'll see what to do next.

On Fri, 14 Nov 2003, Vincent Yau wrote:

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri Nov 14 15:17:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)

Subject: [PLUG] Linux CD Burning software
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0311141438370.23594-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0311141438370.23594-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <1068851727.16167.1.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Fri, 2003-11-14 at 14:40, Fedor Pikus wrote:
> xcdroast and the rest of this kind are front-ends to cdrecord.
> So, make sure you have cdrecord, and run "cdrecord -scanbus". If that does
> not find your CD, stop right there, nothing will work until you get it
> fixed. There are many reasons for failure, post the output of cdrecord and
> we'll see what to do next.

Just one note.. since things are starting to move towards the
not-yet-released 2.6.0.......

cdrecord -scanbus won't work with 2.6.  2.6's IDE-SCSI emulation isn't
quite right, but that's ok, since we have no use for it any more.  CD
recording works properly with 2.6, no need for the IDE-SCSI emulation. 
I think you just say cdrecord dev=/dev/hdc or whatever.

Rob

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Fri Nov 14 15:35:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)

On Thu, 2003-11-13 at 10:40, Bill Barry wrote:
> On Thu, Nov 13, 2003 at 12:24:12AM -0800, Zot O'Connor wrote:

> > http://www.oregonlive.com/news/argus/index.ssf?/base/news/106858994265430.xml
> > 
> 
> Community computer centers are a good idea. Are there public accounts
> on the systems or does each individual get their own account? What 
> flavor of linux are they running?
> 

To be honest, there a whole lot less planning and forethought then you
might expect here.  This came together way faster than anyone thought,
including the people doing it.  It was "Hey there a bunch of machines
and this Community Center that Hillsboro was to use to help a troubled
complex, and um what about we get parts, teach kids how to put them
together, and um..."  and next thing I know, its "So Pinnacle donated a
bunch of old machines, and we can't use MS without a license, do you
think we can run Linux?"  to "Phil has wired the lab, Verizon has DSL
hooked up, and Phil installed RH8 on the servers and we are thinking
about opening next week." (Phil is retired and has lots of free time).

There were a few more conversations, the buying of a gateway/firewall
server, the installing of Eric's filter, and then the "Do you guys
realize this is next week" shock call for volunteers.

The results are spectacular.  The kids, with no advertising, were lined
up.  They probably do know what they are running, and the city loves the
costs.

Since opening someone else went in to install the flash player, and
wound up upgrading the systems to RH9, and tightening down the gateway
firewall.

We will soon be doing classes on net surfing and Open Office.  We will
likely need more volunteers.  There are background checks involved
(working with children).

-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

Rob,

  I don't think the problem is with cdrecord. When I tried running xcdroast
and scsi emulation was not available in the kernel, xcdroast could not find
the ATAPI cdrom drive with the _source_ cdrom from which to run mkisofs.

  The burning (with cdrecord) is on the scsi-bus cd-rw drive. That has no
problems.

  Interestingly, mkisofs from the command line has no problem seeing the
ATAPI cdrom drive, but xcdroast does. Shrug.
