References: <024301c3aa4a$810dc150$4901a8c0@mango>
Message-ID: <1068874347.8648.1480.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

On Thu, 2003-11-13 at 16:59, Steven D. Coffman wrote:
> I have a question if anyone is familiar with this subject:
> I am doing "contract work - no specifics" for a start up company.
> Another contractor and myself developed some Intellectual Property
> that the Start up wants to get the patent on as it is now their new
> direction (it's a Business Intelligence Software design).
> We know they must include our names on the patent as the Inventors,
> but the CEO also is adding his name (did none of the work), and wants
> us to sign it over to the company stating that the company "owns it". 

The application is filled out by someone, and any name can go on it. 
Whether or not someone worked on it is an ego things usually.  To some
extent the CEO might have to prove he worked on it if someone fought the
patent.

> We have only signed a non-disclosure agreement and nothing else. We
> have not been compensated for the invention. Do we have anything to
> stand on to just keep it in our names?
>  

You actually have quite a bit more.  Read your NDAs very carefully.  If
you do not sign over IP rights in there, then you are good.  Contact an
IP lawyer at that point.

It might be a case of No patent, or His Name on patent.  Likely you
cannot file the patent yourself since the NDA would prevent that, but
they may not be able to file without your permission either.

Avoiding the patent vs. no patent war, I would contact any IP lawyer for
a free consult after reading the NDA.  Find out what rights you have.

MY guess is the following:

1)  You can force them to pay you more money.
2)  You might be able to force them to give you patial ownership of the
patent.
3)  You can use #1 and #2 to negotiate.
4)  You realize its an ego thing from your perspective as well, and come
to grips with maximizing #1 and #2.

> Thanks
>  
>  
> Steven D. Coffman
>  
-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

From drl at drloree.com  Sat Nov 15 01:46:01 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sat Nov 15 01:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux kernel ties to the filesystem
In-Reply-To: <1068834755.9988.295.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1068834755.9988.295.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1068889539.17461.244.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Fri, 2003-11-14 at 10:32, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> The Linux kernel makes certain assumptions about the filesystem
> directory hierarchy. For example, it assumes that there's a
> /dev directory (let's ignore devfs). Obviously it knows about
> the root (/). I'm wondering what other assumptions _it_ makes.
> Note that I'm not talking about daemons or init.

I have to admit, that the line between kernel control and init control
is a little fuzzy in my mind.  But...
> 
> Does the kernel know about /lib or is there another mechanism
> that tells the kernel about it?

Only that the modules are kept there.  If the kernel needs a module to
finish booting (say IDE for instance), it could read it from there. 
>From my understanding though, this is where an initrd image must be
incorporated into the boot cycle.  This image is a compressed file
system of the information that the kernel needs to load modules for
devices that could become the root of the file system.  The boot loader
is responsible for knowing the location of the initrd image.  I haven't
tried to mount an initrd image, so I really don't know what the kernel
sees in them.
> 
> Is there anything in /etc that the kernel is aware of?

Well, if the root designation in /etc/fstab is screwed up, the kernel
will panic and the boot process can not proceed.  Seems like a kernel
dependency to me.

If LVM is enabled in the kernel, it will need to be able to see
/etc/raidtab.  

That is all that I can think of.
> 
> What about /var?

The kernel boot info is written to several files, but I have a feeling
that information is stored in a buffer until something can be done with
it.  On my system, a daemon called "bootlogd" is the first one started,
and then it is stopped at the end of the second runlevel.  Actually, a
start command is used to "stop-bootlogd".
> 
> I know this is a difficult question given all the functionality
> in the Linux kernel these days.

Compared to some other OS's, this is very simple.

I hope that at least sparks some conversation.

Derek Loree

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Nov 15 02:17:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat Nov 15 02:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux kernel ties to the filesystem
In-Reply-To: <1068889539.17461.244.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <1068834755.9988.295.camel@localhost.localdomain>
 <1068889539.17461.244.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311150205170.22235@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 15 Nov 2003, Derek Loree wrote:
> On Fri, 2003-11-14 at 10:32, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> > Does the kernel know about /lib or is there another mechanism
> > that tells the kernel about it?
>
> Only that the modules are kept there.

I REALLY don't think so.  Surely there's a kernel-level device hacker that
would know for sure (Galen, mebbe?), but I'd lay money on the idea that
the module locations are all handled by the modutils which are run by
init.

Think about it, the kernel doesn't even have to load filesystem drivers to
work.  It just takes the parameters handed to it by the boot loader.  Lilo
knows FA about filesystems.

> If the kernel needs a module to finish booting (say IDE for instance),
> it could read it from there.

Now, that just seems like crazy talk.  It's a loopy Catch-22 kind of
thing.

If you need the IDE driver to load the rest of the system, you would also
need the filesystem driver.  I would think all that schnike had to be
handed over to the kernel in some explicit low-level form before
abstractions like the filesystem are addressed.

> From my understanding though, this is where an initrd image must be
> incorporated into the boot cycle.

I don't think it MUST.  I mean, isn't some of this what Lilo's System.map
is for?

> The boot loader is responsible for knowing the location of the initrd
> image.

Right... and initrd seems to be just one way to handle this sort of thing.

> I haven't tried to mount an initrd image, so I really don't know what
> the kernel sees in them.

Well, you know, they have a good sense of humor and can be really sweet at
times.  You'd have to get to know them as well as the kernel does and they
just doesn't let others get that close.  I mean, I really don't think
you're in any position to pass judgment, really.

> If LVM is enabled in the kernel, it will need to be able to see
> /etc/raidtab.

That's not just for LVM, of course.

I'm too tired to wax technical.
J.

From felix.1 at canids.net  Sat Nov 15 03:06:01 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Sat Nov 15 03:06:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Compiling Packages: Which Directory? 
In-Reply-To: <20031113235839.1484f68a.jason@vancleve.com> 
    on Thu, 13 Nov 2003 23:58:39 MST
    from Jason Van Cleve <jason@vancleve.com> 
Message-ID: <20031115110511.9E88B158D68@kanga.canids>

Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com>:
> Never understood why the separate build directory, except in
> cases of building multiple versions (different architectures,
> say) or creating a binary package.  I've never had to bother.

multiple versions is a pretty good reason.  it's not hard to do
objdir!=srcdir, and it makes multiple versions much easier.
there are many ways multiple versions are useful, such as
experimenting with optimization switches.

another reason is: for larger programs, dependencies are hard to
get right, and 'make clean' is also hard to get right.  so if you
use the same srcdir for multiple builds, you can end up with
problems that are difficult to reproduce.  it might happen
rarely, but it's a big waste of time when it does happen.

though now that disk space is so cheap, it's not that important
to get objdir!=srcdir builds right.  (just make a disposable copy
of srcdir for each build.)

(gcc is kind of a special case, because it has complex
interdependencies, since it's intended to bootstrap itself.  it's
possible that some bit of the build process doesn't work right
for srcdir==objdir, and nobody tests that.)
--

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Sat Nov 15 23:03:02 2003

> I want to burn lots of 30 to 100 Meg uniquely named files to a CD on
> different dates, filling the CD in a week. I believe that it's called
> packet writing, like DirectCD does form Adaptec for that "other" OS.

Packet-writing is indeed nifty, if you want to treat a CD-RW as an
ordinary writable disc.  For your application, I think multisession is
more appropriate, and perhaps a bit simpler.  You're basically gonna be
using the -C and -M options with mkisofs.  The manpages should be a nice
starting point.

> It's for a backup routine that I'm using for a customer. I'm mounting a
> Win PC's CD-R right now and just copying them over, but the intrinsic
> Win instabilities are frustrating me. (I just drove for an hour one way
> to un-jam the thing)

Urgh.  Ya know, cdrtools (mkisofs/cdrecord) is available in Win32, in
Cygwin and maybe native as well.  There are tools out there that make
supporting a Windows box merely twice as painful as a *nix box.

Good luck,

I'm getting a lot of spam that isn't even addressed to me...  Anyone
else experiencing this?  I've stopped bouncing off of my server and
redirected to a mailbox I can look at with pine.  My hard drive was
running all day and I got sick and tired of that.  My spam is at
somewhere around 70% or higher on average.  

Has anyone tried locked addresses on all but one email address that
isn't a standard alias, then give out the special address to send an
email to to trusted friends?  This way I don't have to keep lists of
what to deny, just what to accept.  I would retain the ability to have
someone send me their email address via email so I can learn what it 
is.  We should have gone to no content accepted until you are
trusted systems a long time ago only accepting headers with null 
bodies.  I don't think a header can be more than offensive, I've 
yet to see a header alone be a virus or worm.

Russell Senior wrote:

>What is the easiest way to do this.
>

MRTG + Apache + ucd-snmp (renamed to something, but I don't remember what).

The snmp package (on Debian, at least) comes with scripts to make it 
easy to set up. I got it running without any prior experience with snmp 
(in fact, I wouldn't say that I have any now).

Apache is fairly easy to set up.

MRTG is pretty complicated, but fortunately, it also has scripts that 
make it easy to set up.

Check the websites of the packages for details on the scripts... it's 
been a long time since I've done this...





From dgc at easystreet.com  Sun Nov 16 11:31:01 2003
From: dgc at easystreet.com (Dave Clemans)
Date: Sun Nov 16 11:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting email that isn't addressed to me, it's really
 weird...
In-Reply-To: <1069008169.19572.56.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1069008169.19572.56.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <3FB7D254.1010800@easystreet.com>

Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> I'm getting a lot of spam that isn't even addressed to me...  Anyone
> else experiencing this?  ...

There's no requirement in the current mail system that there be any 
relationship whatsoever between the visible header lines To:, Cc:, 
From:, etc. and the envelope info that actually has the destination.

Of the spam that gets past my first level blacklist filters, the 
proportion that doesn't have my email address in the To or CC lines has 
probably gone up the past few weeks;  though all for traditional spam, 
not the virus like msgs mentioned in this thread.

Another spam category that started (for me) in the last couple months is 
spam to you, that's forged like it came from you.  That further breaks 
down into two categories; msgs with just a mime separator and nothing 
else, and a complete spam msg.  From what I've seen on nanae, etc. the 
first category are probably probes the gangs use to try to guess whether 
their garbage will get through.

And (again at least for me) spam traffic has gone up considerably the 
last month or so.  Combining my blacklist logs and the garbage that gets 
past them to spamassassin, etc. I'm now running at 60-100 a week (plus 
whatever is caught by my isp).  Before that for many months it was more 
like 25-50 a week.

Sigh... eventually I may have to give up this public address; email 
addresses that are just your initials are too easy for the spammer gangs 
criminal dictionary attack, etc. tools to guess...

dgc

From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Nov 16 13:00:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sun Nov 16 13:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting email that isn't addressed to me, it's really weird...
In-Reply-To: <1069008169.19572.56.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1069008169.19572.56.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <20031116205938.GC28517@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Michael C. Robinson <michael at robinson-west.com> [2003-11-16 10:47]:
> I'm getting a lot of spam that isn't even addressed to me...

Do you have root and/or postmaster forwarded to your mailbox? If you do,
and you have unknown mail messages sent to root/postmaster, you'll get
every one of them. 

> Anyone
> else experiencing this?  I've stopped bouncing off of my server and
> redirected to a mailbox I can look at with pine.  My hard drive was
> running all day and I got sick and tired of that.  My spam is at
> somewhere around 70% or higher on average.  

All the time, but spamassassin catches 99% of the stuff that gets
through my postfix blocks.

> Has anyone tried locked addresses on all but one email address that
> isn't a standard alias, then give out the special address to send an
> email to to trusted friends?

Jeme is against this, since it tramples on some persons free speech, and
it goes against the free flow of bits. Or, at least, that's what I
understand. He'll pipe up if I'm wrong. 

As far as blocking stuff, I have the following stuff in my main.cf for
postfix:

smtpd_client_restrictions = hash:/etc/postfix/access,
        reject_rbl_client blackholes.easynet.nl,
        reject_rbl_client dynablock.easynet.nl,
        reject_rbl_client proxies.blackholes.easynet.nl,
        reject_rbl_client relays.ordb.org,
        reject_rbl_client sbl.spamhaus.org,
        reject_rbl_client zombie.dnsbl.sorbs.net,
        reject_rbl_client dnsbl.njabl.org,
        reject_rbl_client cbl.abuseat.org

smtpd_sender_restrictions = reject_rbl_client blackholes.easynet.nl,
        reject_rbl_client dynablock.easynet.nl,
        reject_rbl_client relays.ordb.org,
        reject_rbl_client proxies.blackholes.easynet.nl,
        reject_rbl_client sbl.spamhaus.org,
        reject_rbl_client zombie.dnsbl.sOrbs.net,
        reject_rbl_client dnsbl.njabl.org,
        reject_rbl_client cbl.abuseat.org
maps_rbl_reject_code = 571

My reject rate is between 50% an 60%. Sometimes, it spikes up to 80% and
I've see a high of 90%. That's what postfix rejects outright, based on
the lists above. 

After it gets past those lists, postfix hands it off to spamassassin.

--

On Sun, 16 Nov 2003, Marvin J. Kosmal wrote:

> Me too..
>
> From: 	Microsoft Corporation Security Bulletin
> From: 	Net Email Storage System <zmaildaemon at netmail.com>
>
> I get these at least once a day that I am sure of.. My filter is having a
> hard time getting these...

Marvin,

  This started several weeks ago. I was getting several hundred a day; now
it's a couple of dozen. However, I see none of them; they're all rejected by
/etc/postfix/header_checks. Here's what I have there that're pertinent to
this dreck:

/^From: Net .*Service/                                  reject Rule H393
/^To: internet user/                                    reject Rule H394
/^From: .*Microsoft Internet Security/                  reject Rule H410
/^X-Mailer: Internet Mail Service/                      reject Rule H412
/^Subject: Current Network Security Upgrade/            reject Rule H414
/^From: MS Internet/                                    reject Rule H425
/^Subject: Bug Announcement/                            reject Rule H439
/^Subject: Bug Report/                                  reject Rule H441
/^To: "Mail User"/                                      reject Rule H442
/^Subject: .*New Microsoft Critical Pack/               reject Rule H445

  I know there are more sprinkled in there, but this will get you started. I
also reject all attachments that end in .exe, .pif and the others that are
Microsoft specific.

HTH,

Rich

On Sun, 2003-11-16 at 13:25, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   While we're on the subject, has anyone crafted a regex that accepts only
> properly-spelled/formed words? For example, is there a way to reject a
> subject line where a "one" has been substituted for an "ell" or a "zero" for
> an "oh"?
> 
>   As our MTA filters become more efficient the spammers mangle the words in
> the subject; sometimes so effectively that not only does it make it past
> postfix but I cannot figure out what they're writing either.

I wrote a short article on this a few weeks back:

http://panug.org/news/regex.html

Here's an example of a simple regular expression that catches many
of the common variants of viagra - including the misspelling "viagro"
that I sometimes get. The expression can get more complex to cover
more variants.

/^Subject:.*v[-_]*[il1!][-_]*a[-_]*g[-_]*r[-_]*[ao0]/    REJECT


Be careful about putting too many of these in your Postfix header
checks. Postfix will take a lot of time and start generating
timeout-related error messages. Check your logs to see if this
happens.

Ed


> 
> Rich

On Sun, Nov 16, 2003 at 01:25:44PM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   While we're on the subject, has anyone crafted a regex that accepts only
> properly-spelled/formed words? For example, is there a way to reject a
> subject line where a "one" has been substituted for an "ell" or a "zero" for
> an "oh"?

Not strictly a regex, but Bayesian filters work especially well with
words (or spellings) that you only find in spam.  I use Bogofilter, but
SpamAssassin's spamc/spamd work nicely, I'm told.

>   As our MTA filters become more efficient the spammers mangle the words in
> the subject; sometimes so effectively that not only does it make it past
> postfix but I cannot figure out what they're writing either.

Means the filters are working.  When I check my spambox, I notice that
most of the messages contain gibberish, as well.  The actual message is
apparently contained in the many HTML-linked images that unwary email
clients auto-load when the message is opened.

"Outlook not so good."

KDE 3.1 has a few patches from Apple, but 3.2 will have considerably more.

From ehem at m5p.com  Sun Nov 16 22:40:02 2003
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Sun Nov 16 22:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Linux kernel ties to the filesystem
In-Reply-To: <20031115144151.11142.22176.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200311170639.hAH6dC9K091350@m5p.com>

> From: Derek Loree <drl at drloree.com>
> On Fri, 2003-11-14 at 10:32, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> > Does the kernel know about /lib or is there another mechanism
> > that tells the kernel about it?
> 
> Only that the modules are kept there.  If the kernel needs a module to
> finish booting (say IDE for instance), it could read it from there. 

Bzzt! Wrong answer! Thanks for being on our show...

I'm uncertain whether the kernel load files or simply data as modules,
but either way you can attempt to load any file anywhere into the kernel.
All the kernel cares about is that it is in the right format and has the
right symbols inside it. OTOH modprobe (but not insmod) looks in
/lib/modules/<kernver> for kernel modules to load.

> >From my understanding though, this is where an initrd image must be
> incorporated into the boot cycle.  This image is a compressed file
> system of the information that the kernel needs to load modules for
> devices that could become the root of the file system.  The boot loader
> is responsible for knowing the location of the initrd image.  I haven't
> tried to mount an initrd image, so I really don't know what the kernel
> sees in them.

You got this right. The boot loader uses the BIOS to load the initial ram
disk, and the right kernel driver (which skips the BIOS) can be loaded
from the initrd, which since it is already in memory can be accessed
without the driver already present in the kernel.

> > Is there anything in /etc that the kernel is aware of?
> 
> Well, if the root designation in /etc/fstab is screwed up, the kernel
> will panic and the boot process can not proceed.  Seems like a kernel
> dependency to me.

Wrong. The kernel has two paths for root device. First, it can get the
device major/minor directly specified. This specification in turn has two
paths, there is a value built into the kernel itself which `rdev` can
change, otherwise it can be passed on the kernel command line. Second,
once an initrd is loaded the "pivot_root" system call can be used to
specify an arbitrary FS as root (look at the kernel source,
linux/Documentation/initrd.txt for details). /etc/fstab has absolutly no
relevance to this process.

> If LVM is enabled in the kernel, it will need to be able to see
> /etc/raidtab.  
> 
> That is all that I can think of.

Wrong. With new style (autodetect) the RAID devices are specified on the
devices themselves. With the old style RAID devices the
_scripts/binaries_ look at /etc/raidtab to determine what devices to tell
the kernel what to load as RAID devices, but the kernel itself doesn't
care at all.

> > What about /var?
> 
> The kernel boot info is written to several files, but I have a feeling
> that information is stored in a buffer until something can be done with
> it.  On my system, a daemon called "bootlogd" is the first one started,
> and then it is stopped at the end of the second runlevel.  Actually, a
> start command is used to "stop-bootlogd".

Correct. syslogd/klogd reads the buffer and dumps it wherever you want it
to.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Nov 17 14:48:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Nov 17 14:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] file system layout question
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F57iYc34SM4yEm0000937e@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F57iYc34SM4yEm0000937e@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311171443410.1064@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 17 Nov 2003, Vincent Yau wrote:

> So I have 2 partitions on /dev/hda.  But the 2nd drive is mounted using
> LVM as a logical volume, if I am not mistaken.  If I am correct on this, I
> would like to know why it is being formatted this way?

Vincent,

  I cannot address the logical volume question as I don't use 'em. But, a
number of pre-installed linuxes come with just a root directory (/) and
_everything_ is in there. Why? It's easier for them and their automatic
install scripts.

  EmperorLinux normally has / and /home. I asked nicely and they split
/usr/local into a separate partition for me. So on my new laptop I have /,
/usr/local, /home and swap. My preference for servers (and workstations that
function as servers, too) is to also split off /tmp and /var into separate
filesystems. Of course, for an automated installation script they will
probably not have the sizes any one purchaser wants so they roll it all into
one. Yuck!

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>



From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Nov 17 15:14:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon Nov 17 15:14:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] file system layout question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311171443410.1064@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <BAY9-F57iYc34SM4yEm0000937e@hotmail.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311171443410.1064@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311171504430.22235@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 17 Nov 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
> So on my new laptop I have /, /usr/local, /home and swap.

Why?  This doesn't make much sense to me.

/home and /var are pretty sensible to keep on a separate partition if it's
a system that you don't monitor at all and you might run the risk of
filling up the filesystem.  (user disk quotas might remove the need to
split off /home, however.)

But why put /usr/local in a separate partition?  It's not like this is
1982 and we have wacky limitations on the number of addressable inodes in
a partition.

I might split off /var for the above-mentioned reasons and I usually mount
/home from a networked filesystem and /tmp from a memory-based system, but
other than that, I don't think there's much reason to partition everything
out like the old days.

J.

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Mon Nov 17 15:32:02 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)

Rich Shepard said:
> On Mon, 17 Nov 2003, Vincent Yau wrote:
>
>> So I have 2 partitions on /dev/hda.  But the 2nd drive is mounted
>> using LVM as a logical volume, if I am not mistaken.  If I am correct
>> on this, I would like to know why it is being formatted this way?
>
> Vincent,
>
>   I cannot address the logical volume question as I don't use 'em
> But, a number of pre-installed linuxes come with just a
> root directory (/) and _everything_ is in there. Why? It's easier
> for them and their automatic install scripts.

I'm pretty much got the same answers as Rich.
/ /boot /usr /var /home /opt /usr/local /data /tmp
are some of the popular partition names (I probably missed several)
Some of it's just helpful in organization.
On small systems such as my laptop, I just have my / & swap as two
partitions.  My server is split up a bit more, especially since I have
multiple drives.  Is it strictly nessasary? Not really, but having
partitions such as /usr/local & /home make it a lot easier to do a
reinstall when you can just leave those partitions alone without having to
backup & restore (backup is always advised)

From sean at fork.com  Mon Nov 17 15:56:02 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Mon Nov 17 15:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Free Firewall
Message-ID: <1069113306.27368.55.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>

I have a firewall white box server that I built about three years ago
available for free.

It's running debian stable with a 2.2 kernel installed.  It's using
seawall (http://seawall.sourceforge.net/) for it's firewalling.

It has 4 interfaces

eth0 - inside
eth1 - outside
eth2 - dmz
eth3 - wireless

This setup is pretty standard with the exception of the wireless.  This
interface had a 802.11b access point on it and was set up like a normal
inside interface, except that the inside interface and wireless
interface can't talk to each other.  This effectively makes it a free
wireless node.

It's set up to support pppoe on eth1 but this could be modified to
support whatever broadband interface is needed.  It was set up to work
with Earthlink pppoe DSL.

The hardware is a 486x66 with 16MBs of memory, 4 ne2K nic cards (and I
have some extra ne2k cards I can through in as well), Buslogic BT-445S
scsi card, and a 500MB Quantum Maverick 540S hard drive.  Some people
might think that this is underpowered for a firewall, but the opposite
is true, it's greatly overpowered.  Most firewall's don't require much
in the way of CPU and memory.  Pushing packets isn't hard. 

This has been an extremely reliable working firewall.  Never compromised
(that I could tell *grin* ).  The only time if failed me was when I
first set it up.  I did a remote scan against the firewall to see what
vulnerabilities where there, and I filled up the only partition (big
mistake, now fixed) with syslog entries.  It now sends all logging to a
loghost.

I'm only replacing it for the following reasons:

1) I received a Sparc 10 dual proc computer.  This offers a smaller form
factor and fits on a shelf that I have.  It also has a nice qe card for
all the interfaces.
2) I wanted to upgrade the kernel to 2.4 to support iptables and ext3. 
This also required converting from seawall to shorewall firewall. 
Setting up a firewall can be difficult if the information you need to
make it work is on the Internet.  Settting up a different box made more
sense.

If anyone is interested they just need to send me an email and come and
pick it up in Vancouver.  First come, first serve.


Sean
-- 
Sean Whitney <sean at fork.com>

From sean at fork.com  Mon Nov 17 16:00:04 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Mon Nov 17 16:00:04 2003
Subject: [PLUG] passwd fields
In-Reply-To: <20031117233331.GA17415@themontagnes.com>
References: <20031117233331.GA17415@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <1069113550.27368.60.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>

x in the passwd file is a placeholder for the password that used to be
in this field.  Most unix/linux flavors now support /etc/shadow, which
has a better encryption method and limits who can look at the file.

the * or ! in the password field of shadow, means that the account is
locked, and no one can log into the account using a password.  You would
have to su from root to use the account.

Sometimes you will also see the password field in shadow using *LK*
(which is the same as *).  Any password can be disabled by putting a *
or a ! in front of the password.  Reenable the account with the old
password by removing the * or !.


Sean

On Mon, 2003-11-17 at 15:33, Michael Montagne wrote:
> What is the significance of "*", "x", and "!" in the password field of
> /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow?
-- 
Sean Whitney <sean at fork.com>

From kens at kens.cad2cam.com  Tue Nov 18 07:08:02 2003

In-Reply-To: <1288.68.108.203.223.1069133687.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <1288.68.108.203.223.1069133687.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <1069168080.22894.27.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>

On Mon, 2003-11-17 at 21:34, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I would like to add a few additional disks to an existing harware RAID
> array.  The Adaptec controller should handle this fine for me, but what
> effect would this have on a Linux ext3 filesystem that's currently using
> the array?  I'm assuming the Linux filesystem will only know about what it
> had previously been formatted to use.  Or will things crash and burn?  If
> things don't die, is it possible to resize the Linux partition to use the
> new additional space?  Or do I need to copy the data elsewhere, rebuild
> the filesystem at the larger size, and copy the data back?
> Thanks,
> ~M
Adding disks to the hardware RAID will only enlarge the virtual disk
size and does nothing to the existing partitioning.  You still have to
create a partition and make a file system.  The additional disk will
appear as unformatted disk.

Ken Stephens
CAD2CAM.COM

From barryb at proaxis.com  Tue Nov 18 09:17:01 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Tue Nov 18 09:17:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla plug-in won't
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311180831070.5867@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311180831070.5867@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20031118171628.GA25769@edge>

On Tue, Nov 18, 2003 at 08:42:48AM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
>....
>   What am I supposed to do to figure out what's wrong? Better yet, how do I
> get a working RealPlayer plug-in for mozilla?
> 

Find rpnp.so (during realplayer installation it may have gone
into /usr/lib/nsbrowser/plugins/rpnp.so) 
and copy it into one of the plugins directories for mozilla
/usr/lib/mozilla/plugins or ~/.mozilla/plugins

Bill Barry

  So, time to stop futzing and toss the cdrom. I prefer to read on the
processed carcasses of dead trees in any case.

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Tue Nov 18 09:55:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Tue Nov 18 09:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Increasing a hardware RAID size and growing a Linux filesystem
In-Reply-To: <1288.68.108.203.223.1069133687.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <1288.68.108.203.223.1069133687.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <20031118175420.GA11333@bavariati.org>

On Mon, Nov 17, 2003 at 09:34:47PM -0800, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I would like to add a few additional disks to an existing harware RAID
> array.  The Adaptec controller should handle this fine for me,

Wow.  I've never seen a RAID controller that'll add discs to an existing
array without destroying the data.  The Adaptecs I used at my last job
wouldn't do this.  In your shoes, I'd plan the job assuming the data
will be destroyed and back it up before starting.  If I don't have to
restore, then the job's done sooner than expected.

> but what effect would this have on a Linux ext3 filesystem that's
> currently using the array?  I'm assuming the Linux filesystem will
> only know about what it had previously been formatted to use. 

Correct.  

> Or will things crash and burn?  If things don't die, is it possible to
> resize the Linux partition to use the new additional space? 

Yup.  Others have mentioned resize2fs.

> Or do I need to copy the data elsewhere, rebuild the filesystem at the
> larger size, and copy the data back?

Even if you think you don't have to, plan on doing that.  Have a viable,
tested backup, and enough downtime to use it.  Which is a good idea in
any case.  

Big fat IDE discs are cheap, compared to downtime and lost data.

Hot/cold spares, sure.  Safely growing a RAID5 capacity-wise, however,

NetApps use it.  I've heard rumors of one of the volume managers on

And in any case, I was talking about commodity PC HW-RAID controllers on
Linux boxen, not Real Unix Stuff. ;)

From chris-plug at maybe.net  Tue Nov 18 15:50:02 2003
From: chris-plug at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Tue Nov 18 15:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] file system layout question
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F57iYc34SM4yEm0000937e@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F57iYc34SM4yEm0000937e@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <20031118234939.GJ22582@maybe.net>

On Mon, Nov 17, 2003 at 09:30:30PM +0000, Vincent Yau wrote:
> So I have 2 partitions on /dev/hda.  But the 2nd drive is mounted using LVM 
> as a logical
> volume, if I am not mistaken.  If I am correct on this, I would like to 
> know why
> it is being formatted this way?

I wouldn't have set up the logical volume as the entire volume group,
myself. Logical volume management is a really nice way of letting you
shuffle around data and partitions to your hearts content, rather than
being limited to whatever fdisk limits you to. Moreover, you can resize
volumes (although only increasing them is safe if you have a filesystem
on there already; recommendation: use reiser) on the fly. Additionally,
you can add additional hard drives and volumes can be split across
hardware transparently.

From michael at robinson-west.com  Tue Nov 18 16:54:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Rejecting spam at the front door
In-Reply-To: <1069032860.9983.353.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311161323040.25813@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sun, 2003-11-16 at 17:34, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> On Sun, 2003-11-16 at 13:25, Rich Shepard wrote:
> >   While we're on the subject, has anyone crafted a regex that accepts only
> > properly-spelled/formed words? For example, is there a way to reject a
> > subject line where a "one" has been substituted for an "ell" or a "zero" for
> > an "oh"?
> > 
> >   As our MTA filters become more efficient the spammers mangle the words in
> > the subject; sometimes so effectively that not only does it make it past
> > postfix but I cannot figure out what they're writing either.
> 
> I wrote a short article on this a few weeks back:
> 
> http://panug.org/news/regex.html
> 
> Here's an example of a simple regular expression that catches many
> of the common variants of viagra - including the misspelling "viagro"
> that I sometimes get. The expression can get more complex to cover
> more variants.
> 
> /^Subject:.*v[-_]*[il1!][-_]*a[-_]*g[-_]*r[-_]*[ao0]/    REJECT
> 
> 
> Be careful about putting too many of these in your Postfix header
> checks. Postfix will take a lot of time and start generating
> timeout-related error messages. Check your logs to see if this
> happens.
> 
> Ed
> 
> 
> > 
> > Rich

What do you have in mind for a course on regular expressions Ed?
If putting too many header checks in Postfix is a problem, I'd at 
least like to figure out how to post filter so that spammers who
use the same address can't hit me from there again for at least
a few days.  I would also like to filter suspected spam to
get rid of definite spam automatically.  Spam assassin is marking
a lot of it, how can I trim my spam folder of anything that is
marked forged outlook express, etc?  With the definite spam 
dumped instead of merely marked as suspect, I'd only have to 
look at questionable stuff that has a real chance of being 
legit.  My sense is that email advertisers need to be forced 
one way or another to legitimately identify who they are.  Ads 
should be opt-in instead of opt-out for direct mail channels.  
Maybe a new email standard is needed that takes into account 
people who own email servers needing to control what goes out and 
comes in producing few false positives.

Email isn't television where you pay for time, it's someone 
else's property where that someone isn't paid.  Unfortunately, 
I even find television discouraging these days.   It has been
taken over by large national networks with seemingly no 
scruples.  Content that I once thought would be rated X or 
worse can be seen on some ordinary airwave stations now, 
UPN 49 for example.  There was a time you either had to go 
somewhere or buy cable/satellite for that. These days, I run 
into radio ads pushing reality sex on free television stations.

The Internet is just being abused as an extension of sex on TV 
it seems.  Viagra is probably just the tip of the iceberg,
a drug that very few men really need which is in fact dangerous
to those who don't need it.  Maybe the television networks are 
desperate and out of desperation choose to turn the audience 
into addicts instead of introducing better drama.  I guess 
entertainment isn't considered a worthwhile risk anymore.  

My real concern is that the targets are loose values boomers. 
That's pretty disgusting if it's true.  I also worry about
who is after money on the fringe, how do we know terrorists 
aren't taking advantage of the Reality TV craze to get access 
to credit?  It's a smart way to do it, how can anyone
trying this get caught?  Are terrorist assets really frozen?
Maybe terrorists will make money off a sub culture that has
been gaining strength in this country?  Why has hardcore sex
over the past few years become alarmingly visible?  Not only
is it visible online, there are paid television shows. There 
is also a sex shop near PSU and the high school that's right 
behind it.  I noticed one close to OSU driving home 
after seeing an old friend.  It's slipping into every kind
of venue physical and virtual it seems.

As much as it's helpful to catch the Viagra Ads, I think
the public needs to wake up and shut down the growing
trend towards sex everywhere all the time.  It's time
to contact legislator's, write letters to the television
stations, and perhaps even picket at City Halls to get
adult stores closed.  No adult sex shop has any business 
being anywhere, least of all near high schools and 
Universities.  I see this as the next major problem
after tobacco, and to think that our favorite technologies 
are probably at the center of delivering pornography, etc.
The sooner reality TV dies, the less of a problem Viagra 
ads etc. are going to continue to pose.  Somebody is 
sponsoring this, the greatest public weapon is taking 
away the lucrativeness of the sex businesses bankrupting
that sponsor.

---------------------
General News

***Are "How To" Books Archaic?
A reader asked us about O'Reilly's vision for future books given the rate
of change in technology and the growth of the Internet as an information
source. Tim says "how to" books will only become more important as the
paradigm shift that's taking place in computing leads us into uncharted
territory. Read more and share your thoughts on November's Ask Tim.
http://www.oreilly.com/pub/a/oreilly/ask_tim/2003/rateofchange_1103.html

---------------------
Open Source
---------------------
***Open Source at COMDEX Contest Winners
We nominated 21 projects as potential participants in the Open Source
Innovation Area at COMDEX, and you voted for the six that will attend.
Find out which open source projects will go where only commercial software
vendors have gone before.
http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/wlg/3957


***GBA Programming with DevKit Advance
Emulation has opened up game programming to hobbyists. While it's possible
to build amazing games on all sorts of obsolete platforms, it's also
possible to build them on modern ones, including the GameBoy Advance.
Howard Wen explores DevKit Advance and interviews its lead developers.
http://linux.oreillynet.com/pub/a/linux/2003/11/06/devkit_advance.html


***Certification in Linux/Unix System Administration
Learn system administration skills online and receive credit from the
University of Illinois. Courses include: The Unix File System, Networking
and DNS, Unix Services, and Scripting for Administrators with sed, awk,
and Perl. Enroll today at the O'Reilly Learning Lab and save $149 per
course.
http://oreilly.useractive.com/courses/sysadmin.php3

---------------------
Java
---------------------
***"Head First EJB" Author Interview
Kathy Sierra and Bert Bates have just completed the second title in
O'Reilly's Head First series, the recently released "Head First EJB," a
certification book as unique as the series itself. In this interview, the
authors discuss why the Head First series now includes a certification
book, why the book is essential even if you're not planning to take the
exam, how they've used their unique teaching style to help Java candidates
pass the EJB exam, and much more.
http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2003/11/05/HeadFirst_EJB.html


***Inside Class Loaders
Class loading is a topic that separates the Java Jedi from his or her
apprentice. Until you start working with multiple -- and potentially
incompatible -- class loaders, you don't realize the trickiness of keeping
classes straight. Andreas Schaefer's introduction will help expose how
class loading works.
http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2003/11/12/classloader.html

---------------------
Windows
---------------------
***Windows Server 2003: Still Room for Improvement
Windows Server 2003 is indeed an improvement over the earlier Windows 2000
platform, but with just a wee bit more work, Microsoft could have made it
much easier to use. Mitch Tulloch has a few suggestions that he hopes
Microsoft will take to heart. Mitch is the author of "Windows Server 2003
in a Nutshell."
http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/a/network/2003/11/11/winserver2003.html

Windows Server 2003 in a Nutshell
Order Number: 4044
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/winsvrian/


***Shooting the Windows Messenger Service
On November 6, the Federal Trade Commission took the unusual step of
convincing a U.S. District Court to issue a temporary restraining order
shutting down a spamming company for using the Windows Messenger Service
to deliver unwanted pop-ups. In this article, Preston Gralla shows you how
you can permanently solve this pop-up problem in XP by disabling the
Windows Messenger Service, a hack he also covers in his book, "Windows XP
Hacks."
http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/a/network/2003/11/11/winxp_hacks.html

Windows XP Hacks
Order Number: 5113
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/winxphks/index.html

---------------------
.NET
---------------------
***Using the eBay SDK
Unless you've been living in a cave, you probably already know that eBay
enables people and businesses to buy and sell items online. But you might
not have known that you can write software applications that integrate
with eBay through a handy set of .NET components. Jeffrey McManus gives
you an overview of how to write apps using the eBay SDK for .NET.
http://www.ondotnet.com/pub/a/dotnet/2003/11/10/ebay.html

---------------------
Mac
---------------------
***Panther Internet Sharing
A quick look at sharing an Internet connection in Panther with IP over
FireWire, which is now built into Mac OS X 10.3, and AirPort, including
the pros and cons of each method.
http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/2003/11/11/panther_internet.html


***Rendezvous Picture Transfer with Panther
You can show others on a Rendezvous network pictures directly from your
camera using the new Image Capture app in Panther. But that's only part of
the good news. Derrick Story shows you the ins and outs of this handy new
Mac OS X 10.3 trick.
http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/2003/11/10/rendezvous_images.html

Marsee








From michael at robinson-west.com  Tue Nov 18 18:27:22 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Tue Nov 18 18:27:22 2003
Subject: [PLUG] My new wireless card...
Message-ID: <1069208551.32456.315.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I have an SMC EZ Connect card with a PCI to pcmcia adapter.
I thought for the price I might pick up another wireless
card if this one isn't supported.  This thing doesn't 
have an external antenna connector I can spot.  I'm 
wondering what the range etc. on it is?  I doubt it's 
something I can hook up to a coffee can antenna which
I'll need to do if I'm going to go eight miles.  One
thing I'm concerned about is what the transmission
power will cost compared to just buying another
phone line.  Well there's that concern and how fast
the coffee cans will rust out.  I'll also need to look
into making them appealing to people who will see them.

Climbing a tree, a tower can be spotted that's within
half a mile of where I want to beam to.  I don't know 
if that's close enough though.  Short of getting a 
gps unit, I wonder what I'm looking at being at about 
50 feet with a tree to use that goes up at least 
another 50 feet above sea level.  The target is 
along the road that goes between the new Burgerville 
and Winsum Staffing in St. Helens.  It's quite a ways 
from roughly where the Scappoose Fred Meyers is.  
It's a shorter distance than the O'Reilly long shot. 
In my example, my short distance is longer 
than O'Reilly's.  They had a radio tower though.  
Even if I connect two isolated machines over this 
distance with 802.11b or better, I have to add 
strong encryption.  If I lose 50% of the speed or 
even 75% of the optimal 11 mbps speed, I'm still 
beating a second phoneline and dial up server
at $23-$32 a month.

One concern I have is a sticker that said don't take the 
card out of the pcmcia adapter.  I hope this is standard 
pcmcia.  I'm after that as much as a chance to play with 
wireless.  It says it's model SMC2632W on the card front, 
but on the back I see SMC2602W under a long bar code.  
It's supposed to be 802.11b. compliant.  Is there any 
way to alter this card so that it can take an external 
antenna?

If this card doesn't work, maybe I can pick up a prism.
The adapter card has an asic that says PLX Technology
PCI9052 S 0052 T2B BR2129.1 TAIWAN.  I can't read the
other asics or they're blank.

Well, I'll see if I can get this recognized. 
The next thing will be to get a second WiFi
card and attempt a peer to peer link :-)

-- 
-----------------------------
Michael C. Robinson

Associates of General Studies 
PCC March 2003.

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Tue Nov 18 20:15:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Tue Nov 18 20:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FS to handle large files?
In-Reply-To: <200311182340.hAINeL610130@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200311182340.hAINeL610130@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <20031119041437.GA25335@bavariati.org>

On Tue, Nov 18, 2003 at 03:40:21PM -0800, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Hello Linux folkz,
> Could somebody tell me please which FS
> handles large system/DB files better?
> Ext3, XFS, ResiserFS or other?

With large files, the performance differences are AFAIK mostly trivial,
so use what you like.  Look for something expandible.  Better to spend
your time choosing a good Logical Volume Manager.  Live storage
expansion and volume snapshots are lovely things to have on your
database servers.

> I'm setting up SQL RDBMS and need to tune it
> to its best abilities.

Check for info on the database you're using.  Oracle, for instance, has
lots of info on disk layout and suchlike, and I'm sure you can find
plenty of discussions of this topic for MySQL and PostGres.

From holger at selover.net  Wed Nov 19 01:10:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)

Subject: [PLUG] Looking for a web based Postfix/virtual account manager

Here is the Open Source Song from today. 

I was looking for a web based administrator tool we can give a client
who wants to maintain their email accounts themselves (? la web hosting
control panel). This is for a Postfix/Mysql (or LDAP)/virtual
domain/virtual account configuration. 

At Sourceforge, I found 60 projects that have not yet committed any
source. Too young, or never materialized. Then there were 6 others who
had code but can be considered dead. Most of these projects are ISP
admin tools. 

After scanning dozens of these dead projects I read this here on
http://mojo.sourceforge.net/:

"[...] Now go on over to the project page, and have a look and then
laugh and laugh and laugh. [...]" -- yeah, that is the right attitude!

The free tool I liked best didn't seem to like Postfix (i.e. the
Squirrelmail plug-in). 

The list of links and projects is below. The numbers at the begin of
some lines are quickly assigned (and possibly unjustified) ratings (with
1=very good, 5=bad). 

If any of you know of a good and free web based control panel, please
give me a holler. 

Thanks

- Holger (hoping this wind isn't going to blow away Rich...)

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Nov 19 06:56:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Nov 19 06:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Color display: console vs. virtual terminal
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0311190649550.8967@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I'm probably the last to discover this, but I learned last evening that
some colors which display properly in a virtual terminal under X will not
display on a console. This comes from the "I Didn't Know That Department".

  When I slog through the conversion of my reference library to RIS format
using emacs while X is running, the text colors are wheat, light blue and
yellow. When I fired up emacs last evening on a console the colors were dark
red and dark blue. The buffer's text properties were still set for the
desired colors, but the monitor apparently cannot display them.

  How interesting!

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Wed Nov 19 08:32:01 2003
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Wed Nov 19 08:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FS to handle large files?
In-Reply-To: <20031119041437.GA25335@bavariati.org>
References: <200311182340.hAINeL610130@gate.daniloff.com> <20031119041437.GA25335@bavariati.org>
Message-ID: <200311190831.16267.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Tuesday 18 November 2003 20:14, Aaron Burt wrote:
> On Tue, Nov 18, 2003 at 03:40:21PM -0800, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> > Hello Linux folkz,
> > Could somebody tell me please which FS
> > handles large system/DB files better?
> > Ext3, XFS, ResiserFS or other?
>
> With large files, the performance differences are AFAIK mostly trivial,
> so use what you like.  Look for something expandible.  Better to spend
> your time choosing a good Logical Volume Manager.  Live storage
> expansion and volume snapshots are lovely things to have on your
> database servers.

I've seen reports and tests that show that ReiserFS is not the best for very 
large files (DB files usually fall into this category).  XFS and JFS were the 
best if I remember correctly.  XFS is a little problematic with the 2.4 
kernels still as I don't think it is included in the vanilla kernel source 
yet.

The MySQL folks said that ext3 with data journalling on is quite fast and has 
really good recovery characteristics in the event of system crashes.  Use 
appropriately RAID-ed disks and I doubt the filesystem will usually be the 
bottleneck.

Later versions of Reiser have write barriers and data ordering.  This slows 
performance slightly, but increases the likelyhood that your data won't be 
chop suey after a crash.

> > I'm setting up SQL RDBMS and need to tune it
> > to its best abilities.
>
> Check for info on the database you're using.  Oracle, for instance, has
> lots of info on disk layout and suchlike, and I'm sure you can find
> plenty of discussions of this topic for MySQL and PostGres.

If you are using MySQL, the main mailing list for the project has a number of 
extremely well informed people on it who will help answer questions.  I've 
had responses directly from Jeremey Zawodny (sp?) who runs Yahoo's business 
site DBs (all MySQL on biggish hardware) and Paul DuBois (author of the 
excellent "MySQL" book) as well as Monty, Sacha and some of the other core 
developers.  The Postgres mailing list isn't bad, but my experiences with it 
have been quite different from those of the MySQL list.

I've found that Postgres inability to guarantee coherent disk data while it is 
running (according to the manual) makes snapshots a lot more difficult with 
systems that must be up 24/7.  MySQL can do this (LOCK ALL TABLES; FLUSH 
TABLES; do LVM snapshot; UNLOCK TABLES) very quickly and is a rediculously 
easy way to do snapshots for backup or slave system creation.  LVM makes this 
really simple.

I would not do a DB installation without LVM/EVMS and RAIDed drives.

Best,
Kyle

Quick question on iptables, which I'm finally getting around to setting up on my laptop.  I'd like to create a more or less permanent and reusable configuration file, one I can modify for use on other machines.  I've heard of many people writing explicit scripts to configure the filter (iptables -b blah-blah; iptables -blah; . . .), but I also notice that iptables-save creates a formatted config' instead of actual iptables commands.

Is it wise to just use that formatted output as a portable config' file?  That is, to SCP it to another machine and load it there with iptables-restore (even just as a starting point)?  Maybe it would be better to write a script, so that I can compare it with other people's; but my distro' is set up to use iptables-restore at boot time, so maintaining a script could be awkward.

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Wed Nov 19 15:43:01 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Wed Nov 19 15:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Looking for a web based Postfix/virtual account manager
In-Reply-To: <1069232986.15665.35.camel@halo>
References: <1069232986.15665.35.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <1069285140.23378.607.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

On Wed, 2003-11-19 at 01:09, Holger Stephan wrote:
> Here is the Open Source Song from today. 
> 
> I was looking for a web based administrator tool we can give a client
> who wants to maintain their email accounts themselves (? la web hosting
> control panel). This is for a Postfix/Mysql (or LDAP)/virtual
> domain/virtual account configuration. 

I just converted from running
sendmail+amavis(f-secure)+cyrus+procmail+spamassassin to
postfix(postgresql)+amavis-new(f-secure/spamassassin)+cyrus(postgres)+sieve

I manage the accounts with web-cyradm (http://www.web-cyradm.org/)

I manage sieve with smartsieve (http://smartsieve.sourceforge.net)

web-cyradm has two howto's for setting up everything via postgres or
mysql.  They are really complete.

My biggest concern is relying on a DB for mail.  In other words. If the
DB goes down, mail state may be indeterminate.

But the differences are:

postfix vs. sendmail:  I like postfix much more now.  It has all the new
features I need (SSL, AUTH, etc.).  Security is a concern for some for
sendmail, and postfix's model is better, but it is just simpler to get
working.

Amavis-new (not amavis) calls spamassassin.  I am not sure I like this
for one reasons, amavis-new times out the SA call when things like razor
check takes too long.  I may change this.  Otherwise all mail gets
scanned for virus and spam centrally.  Before I used procmail to call
SA.  There are hooks in amavis-new's conf file for per user behavior.

cyrus is upgraded which is good.

sieve replaces procmail for filtering.  sieve is not as well documented,
or as powerful, but cyrus holds all mail under a "cyrus" account and
adding procmail per user is a security hazard.  Now sieve handles the
filters per mail user, but as user cyrus.  This means no external call
outs, but I stopped doing that :)  websieve allows users to setup
vacation messages and other standard scripts.

Postgres maintains the domains and accounts for postfix and cyrus.  This
means the web based program can add virtual mail domains, and added mail
account per domain.  Furthermore you can have domain admins vs super
admin, so if you want a user to control all mail to an admin, there you
go.

I run the web based stuff under ssl.



So far my moderately complex procmail recipies are working.  I have one
which is not.

The only thing left is to figure out unix_notify under cyrus to get IM
message everytime I get a mail to my inbox.....


Oh and now evolution show emails as read in my INBOX.  Damn
government....




-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

said

Ok, I know this is an old thread but this is what I have found.

I was looking at what was being used to display the images on the bootup
of knoppix and morphix because I want something like that in my stuff.
They use isolinux but my searches also found the stuff below.

copied from:
http://linux01.gwdg.de/suse/ftp.suse.com/people/stepan/bootsplash/themes/README.bootSplashMaker
***************
bootSplashMaker is a utility to create bootsplash themes, as they can
be used with SuSE Linux 8.1, UL1, SLES8 etc.
It should be easy to change the code to provide Mandrake compliant output
as well.
This code is very experimental, don't expect much to be there.
You can load/import a set of pictures, and provide a comment, select the
text window in a picture and write out a theme directory.

Requirements:
 * perl
 * perl-Tk
 * perl-Class-MethodMaker
 * ImageMagick

installation:
  chmod 755 bootSplashMaker
  mkdir ~/bootsplash-themes
  export bSM_WORK=~/bootsplash-themes

  then execute
  ./bootSplashMaker

Change the Theme Name, then add several pictures and change the comment to
fit
your needs. Every comment line needs to start with a #

When you save a theme, copy the resulting directory to
/usr/share/splash/themes
and change /etc/sysconfig/bootsplash to use your freshly created theme.
Then run

# SuSEconfig --module bootsplash
# mk_initrd

If you use lilo for booting, you have to rerun the "lilo" program in order
to make lilo recognize your new initrd containing the pictures.

Known Bugs:
The text and bg color are not written correctly. change them according to
your needs manually
Saving to a tgz does not work yet

Contact:
Program written by RayMan <foobar at web.de>.
bootsplash kernel patch written by Stefan Reinauer <stepan at suse.de>
************endcopy

Double check to see if you have a /bootthemes directory and what it
contains.
If there is one there then the kernel has been patch with bootsplash.

http://www.bootsplash.org/index.html
----
Larry Brigman
Fujitsu Computer Products of America
503.693.2051 lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com

From sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com  Wed Nov 19 19:37:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] iptables Config' File
In-Reply-To: <20031119144638.1633d846.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <032601c3af17$73c959b0$6401a8c0@laptop>

Jason, 

fwiw, I have an /etc/iptables that is a script beginning with 
	#!/bin/sh 
	/sbin/iptables bla bla bla
	...
and ending with 
	/etc/init.d/iptables save

So on startup, it loads the formatted config. This also seemed like an
easy way to update/test new configs just by running the script as
necessary. 

The formatted config file seemed weird to me - a noticable difference
from ipchains - so this was my quick fix. It should also make for a
maintainable a portable configuration. 

hope this helps,
sasha

From ian at znark.com  Wed Nov 19 20:44:02 2003
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Wed Nov 19 20:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FS to handle large files?
In-Reply-To: <200311190831.16267.kyle@silverbeach.net>
References: <200311182340.hAINeL610130@gate.daniloff.com> <20031119041437.GA25335@bavariati.org> <200311190831.16267.kyle@silverbeach.net>
Message-ID: <3FBC4668.3030703@znark.com>

Kyle Hayes wrote:
> 
> I've found that Postgres inability to guarantee coherent disk data while it is 
> running (according to the manual) makes snapshots a lot more difficult with 
> systems that must be up 24/7.  MySQL can do this (LOCK ALL TABLES; FLUSH 
> TABLES; do LVM snapshot; UNLOCK TABLES) very quickly and is a rediculously 
> easy way to do snapshots for backup or slave system creation.  LVM makes this 
> really simple.
> 

The disk files should be coherent at every point in time as long as the 
log files are included.  Otherwise, the database couldn't be restored 
when the machine crashes.  It only works with an instantaneous snapshot 
but LVM provides that.

The pg_dump backup is smaller than the live database and makes a much 
better permanent archive.

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/




From kyle at silverbeach.net  Wed Nov 19 21:17:01 2003
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Wed Nov 19 21:17:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FS to handle large files?
In-Reply-To: <3FBC4668.3030703@znark.com>
References: <200311182340.hAINeL610130@gate.daniloff.com> <200311190831.16267.kyle@silverbeach.net> <3FBC4668.3030703@znark.com>
Message-ID: <200311192116.11094.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Wednesday 19 November 2003 20:43, Ian Burrell wrote:
> Kyle Hayes wrote:
> > [postgres/mysql, snapshots, lvm and so on]
>
> The disk files should be coherent at every point in time as long as the
> log files are included.  Otherwise, the database couldn't be restored
> when the machine crashes.  It only works with an instantaneous snapshot
> but LVM provides that.
>
> The pg_dump backup is smaller than the live database and makes a much
> better permanent archive.

From the manual, you cannot take a snapshot of the files used by the DB while 
it is live.  MySQL can do this.  Because the manuals say this, I would assume 
that something is in memory that isn't on disk.  Clearly this something can 
be recreated (or rolled back) because Postgres can recover from crashes.  If 
my snapshot isn't a completely safe and coherent set of data, it isn't a 
snapshot.

Can pg_dump be run safely and without performance degredation on a live 
Postgres DB?

Best,
Kyle




From cstevens at gencom.us  Wed Nov 19 21:17:23 2003
From: cstevens at gencom.us (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Wed Nov 19 21:17:23 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DOE Releases Blackout Report
Message-ID: <1069305390.5104.100.camel@pookie>

Dear Friends,

The Department of Energy released today their report outlining the
causes behind the August 14th electrical blackout that left an estimated
50 million people without power for two days in some areas. You may view
the full report here:

  https://reports.energy.gov/


On page 22, the report gives us the first glimpse of the two primary
reasons for the blackout:

"Subsequent computer failures leading to the loss of situational
awareness in FE's control room and the loss of FE transmission lines due
to contacts with trees were the most important causes."

The task force reveals more details on page 28:

"Starting around 14:14 EDT, FE's control room operators lost the alarm
function that audible and visual indications when a significant piece of
equipment changed from an acceptable to problematic condition. Shortly
thereafter, the EMS system lost a number of its remote control consoles.

Next it lost the primary server computer that was hosting the alarm
function, and then the backup server such that all functions that were
being supported on these servers were stopped at 14:54 EDT."

Translation:

The alarm PC's in the control room were under a denial of service attack
caused by the "Blaster" worm. They probably looked to the user as if
they were running normally as DDOS attacks primarily target the
networking subsystem in these "corner" monitoring stations.

As the worm spread, it infects and overloads the Primary Domain
Controller (signified as the "primary server computer" in the report)
and causes it to either crash or experience an overloaded network
subsystem. The Secondary Domain Controller also either crashes or is
also incapable of communicating on the network as the worm exacts it's
payload. 

The PDC further running the Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition
(SCADA). It is this application that is responsible for grid monitoring
and sending alarm notices to the monitor terminals.

So it is becoming clear that the blackout of last summer was caused by a
Microsoft security flaw. If you're not convinced, consider the report's
hinting about this on page 94:
 
"Many malicious code attacks, by their very nature, are unbiased and
tend to interfere with operations supported by vulnerable applications.
One such incident occurred on January 2003, when the "Slammer" Internet
worm took down monitoring computers at FirstEnergy Corporation's idled
Davis-Besse nuclear plant. A subsequent report by the North American
Electric Reliability Council (NERC) concluded that, although it caused
no outages, the infection blocked command that operated other power
utilities."

If you're still in doubt, here's the ComputerWeek article outlining the
Blaster worm's role in the blackout shortly after it happened:

http://www.computerworld.com/securitytopics/security/recovery/story/0,10801,84510,00.html

Ironically, the worm even delayed New York's restoration of power:

"A former Bush administration adviser who has consulted with the U.S.
Department of Homeland Security on the power grid issue said the Blaster
worm also hampered the ability of utilities in the New York region to
restore power in a more timely manner because some of those companies
were running Windows-based control systems with Port 135 open - the port
through which the worm attacked systems."

This is an outrage. What are the officials operating the power grid
doing running mission-critical alarm control systems on a platform known
for serious security issues?


Very Truly Yours,
--

 | Cooper Stevenson        | Em:  cooper at gencom.us            |
 | General Computer        | Ph:  541.924.9434                |
 | "Open For Business"     | Www: http://www.gencom.us        |

From kevintheobald at vzavenue.net  Wed Nov 19 23:30:03 2003
From: kevintheobald at vzavenue.net (Kevin Theobald)
Date: Wed Nov 19 23:30:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Another topic: the PLUG FAQ
Message-ID: <16316.27978.229831.134128@vzavenue.net>

Sorry if this interrupts the nice p1551ng match over the P[DX]LUG
names.  But I was looking over the PLUG (our PLUG) website, and ran
across the FAQ.  As I read the general stuff on Linux, I had the
impression that a newbie knowing nothing about Linux would get the
idea that Linux is all the work of the GNU project, with this little
"kernel" think that Linus stuck on to complete the package.

It seems that this gives GNU way too much credit.  My understanding of
the history of Linux is that Torvalds used whatever was out there that
seemed useful, including many components written by people not
directly involved with the GNU project, other than that they GPL'd
their code.  At least by the time I started playing with Linux, it was
already at the stage where Xfree86 was considered an integral part of
Linux.  (Was Xfree86 a GNU or FSF project?)

I saw a study cited on /. a few years ago, during one of the monthly
Linux-vs.-GNU/Linux debates.  Someone took a common distro, tallied up
the source code, and found that GNU-based code accounted for only 16%
of it.  The whole naming thing is still debatable, but clearly, at
this time there are many non-GNU contributions to what is considered a
"standard" Linux distro.

(Actually, I don't really get Stallman's argument that it's not only
about giving credit; there's a *principle* involved.  First, Torvalds
GPL'd his kernel at the beginning, without any prompting from Stallman
or the FSF.  So it's not like Torvalds is some kind of
counter-revolutionary; he's just apolitical.  Second, Stallman claims
that the GNU prefix will somehow remind people of the true ideals of
free software (as opposed to apostates like ESR) but how are people
supposed to get that from a name which says nothing about free
software -- unless you know a lot about GNU's history?)

Kevin

> Linux-vs.-GNU/Linux debates.  Someone took a common distro, tallied up
> the source code, and found that GNU-based code accounted for only 16%
> of it.  The whole naming thing is still debatable, but clearly, at
> this time there are many non-GNU contributions to what is considered a

FWIW, we hashed over this in alt.os.linux.slackware a few weeks ago.

I, personally, call it Slackware Linux, Gentoo Linux, RedHat Linux, or
WhateverElse Linux.

That said, there are two sides to every coin.  In Slackware, we counted
- something like 19% of the packages had very close ties to the
FSF/GNU/whatever group.  So 81% is non-GNU?

Well, of that 81%, virtually all the code would have never happened had
it not been for the GNU utilities.  It's all compiled with GCC.  It's
all compiled against glibc.  So it's all GNU, right?

Still, it could be done with GNU, likely...

I don't think there's enough in that argument alone to make a
determination of if it's GNU/Linux or just Linux.  In my book, it's
Linux.  Last I heard, FreeBSD used GCC and glibc - should be they called
GNU/FreeBSD?

Naw.

g'night

Rob

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Nov 20 01:35:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Nov 20 01:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Another topic: the PLUG FAQ
In-Reply-To: <16316.27978.229831.134128@vzavenue.net>
References: <16316.27978.229831.134128@vzavenue.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311200109340.22235@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 19 Nov 2003, Kevin Theobald wrote:
> As I read the general stuff on Linux, I had the impression that a newbie
> knowing nothing about Linux would get the idea that Linux is all the
> work of the GNU project, with this little "kernel" think that Linus
> stuck on to complete the package.

I've always had a hard time with folks refering to the entire system as
"Linux".  It's misleading at best and, at worst, downright wrong.

I think that, if you check out the history, the kernel was, in fact, just
sort of stuck in to complete the package.

> It seems that this gives GNU way too much credit.  My understanding of
> the history of Linux is that Torvalds used whatever was out there that
> seemed useful, including many components written by people not directly
> involved with the GNU project, other than that they GPL'd their code.

Not quite.  If you read the Wired interview with Linus from whatevermonth
1996 (the one with Linus on the cover), you'll find that his account
differs from your understanding considerably.

It seems that Linus wrote his little minix clone to run on his cheap(ish)
386 hardware and to play around with some of the 386 enhanced instructions
and put it out in the wire (USENET) for folks to fiddle with it.  It
wasn't long before someone came back with a patch for this or that.
Eventually people were porting programs to run on his little kernel.  THEN
Linus was introduced to the GNU project.  He didn't know it existed.
Someone said "Oooh, let's try to port some of the GNU stuff to run on your
kernel and you'll have practically a whole working system!" and Linus said
his own equivalent of "Fuck that, that's too much work... I'll just port
my kernel so that the GNU stuff can run native."  In essence, he filled in
the missing gap.  He put a bandaid on the hole that Stallman get really
hung up on patching with some fancy new industrial bung.

In the history of software, it's almost impossible to give the GNU project
too much credit.

> At least by the time I started playing with Linux, it was already at the
> stage where Xfree86 was considered an integral part of Linux.  (Was
> Xfree86 a GNU or FSF project?)

No, it wasn't and still isn't.  It isn't even GPL.  Kinda sad, really.
But that's what happens when you can't keep a handle on your copyrights.

> Someone took a common distro, tallied up the source code, and found that
> GNU-based code accounted for only 16% of it.

16% of the available packages?  That's a shitpile, if you ask me.

And I'd bet that it was the core of the system, too.  I'd like to see what
percentage of the packages are both non-GNU and have no GNU dependencies.

> (Actually, I don't really get Stallman's argument that it's not only
> about giving credit; there's a *principle* involved.

Well, there's the principle of Free Software.  Linus doesn't do anything
to uphold that principle from his failure to properly aggregate the
copyrights for contributed source to his requirement of using proprietary
software to maintain kernel source.  Free Software requires a level of
philosophical and social commitment of which I don't think Linus is
capable.

> First, Torvalds GPL'd his kernel at the beginning, without any prompting
> from Stallman or the FSF.

No direct prompting, but also no real understanding of what it meant.

> So it's not like Torvalds is some kind of counter-revolutionary; he's
> just apolitical.

"just apolitical"?  Apathy kills.

> Second, Stallman claims that the GNU prefix will somehow remind people
> of the true ideals of free software (as opposed to apostates like ESR)
> but how are people supposed to get that from a name which says nothing
> about free software -- unless you know a lot about GNU's history?)

You don't have to know "a lot about GNU's history" to know what the
project is and what it means to be part of the GNU project.  GNU reminds
us that the system is NOT UNIX.  There is a reason why it's not Unix and
that is because Unix is not by or for the people.  Unix is a tool used to
exploit the needs of the many for the profits of a few.  GNU is a tool
against that exploitation.  GNU is the means by which we can take control
of the means by which we meet our needs.

Linux is just some guy's homework.

J.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Thu Nov 20 11:49:01 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Thu Nov 20 11:49:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CD player sound and aux. cable?
In-Reply-To: <200311201922.hAKJMqE14522@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200311201922.hAKJMqE14522@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <1069357647.5545.133.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Thu, 2003-11-20 at 11:22, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> The question is if Linux uses different sound 
> services/fasilities for providing sound for DVD movies 
> and musical CD's?

Yes, all operating systems do, generally speaking.

Normally, CDs are played, as far as the OS knows, by telling the CD
drive to play the CD.  The CD player then reads the CD and outputs the
audio over that dinky little cable directly to the sound card, which
sends the audio right out to the speakers - no real software involved. 
That's why you can play CDs in DOS with no sound card drivers at all.

Now, there are exceptions to every rule - to allow for playing CDs with
things like USB CD drives and the like, there are now several CD playing
utilities out there that don't just tell the CD drive to play the CD -
they actually read the music from the CD and send it to the soundcard
themselves, with lots of software involved.

DVDs are decoded entirely with software.  That is, the drive itself
doesn't decode the audio at all - it leaves software to do that.  Due to
the nature of DVDs, this is the only feasable option.  DVDs can have
multiple audio tracks for different languages or different setups (5.1
surround vs 2-speaker stereo, for example)...

Hope this helps and makes sense...

Rob

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Thu Nov 20 12:41:25 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Thu Nov 20 12:41:25 2003
Subject: My take on (GNU/)?Linux Re: [PLUG] Another topic: the PLUG FAQ
References: <mailman.1069313422.6588.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86n0aqsrk8.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

I've had the privilege of spending quite a bit of time with Richard
Stallman and Linus Torvalds, thanks to my role with Geek Cruises
(www.geekcruises.com).

While Richard definitely gets credit for the FSF and GNU project and
GCC and GNU Emacs and most of the other GNU Tools, Linus did what
Richard was unable to do: create the kernel.

You disrespect Linus for his essential contribution when you call it
GNU/Linux, which is merely RMS's attempt to ride on the coat-tails of
another product.

Knowing RMS and Linus personally, I request that you respect the
expressed wishes of Linus on this, and just call it Linux.  RMS can
and will get his legendary status by other means.
