On Sun, 23 Nov 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Most retailers that get into the spam gang will outsource to the big
> spamhauses, who are experts at this sort of fiddle. It should be easier to
> filter, but it will still be a big fat PITA.

  I wonder, .... Are there penalties for spamming in the bill?

  I ask because I have come up with an idea to fight fax spam. You know that
the fax spammers do not send the originating telephone number and they make
themselves very difficult to identify. This despite the federal laws against
fax spams. While I have spent some time tracking down a couple of spammers
and sending them letters demanding money (per the law), I've not received
any yet. (However, a local lawyer has, but his letterhead probably conveys
more threat than does mine.)

> The cure for spam is to cut it off at the source. No matter how they
> dress it up, it's a form of trespass,that shifts the cost to the
> recipients. Building better filters, or making it easier to filter, is
> like using a bigger umbrella in a shitstorm.

  What I am ramping up to do is an attempt to do just this for the fax spam.
I am sending copies of the spam to the companies being promoted. I will tell
them that because they contracted with (and paid) an illegal spam factory
that I cannot identify I am holding them responsible. I will ask for the
penalties under both the anti-fax-spam law and the do-not-call list (yes, my
fax number is on there, too). I will tell them that if I do not receive
payment in a certain period, I will file in Multnomah County Small Claims
Court for triple damages. They will need to hire a local lawyer or lose by
default.

  Also, I will inform them, I will post their company name and illegal
advertising practices on the Web with the advice that people neither buy
their stock or their products/services. Perhaps someone already has such a
Web site set up.

  Targeting the clients who hire spammers (fax or e-mail) has the best
potential for doing something about it. Harnessing the reach and power of
the 'Net to hurt them financially has a higher probability of success.

  Anyone want to join me in this effort?

Rich

> "Record" key nothing is recorded. Recording device is /dev/dsp.

I used it to record an FM broadcast from the line in, but from the FAQ, it 
looks like it's do-able

http://audacity.sourceforge.net/faq.php
-----------------------------------------------

5. Can I record RealAudio or other streaming audio?

Not automatically. Most streaming audio, including most music delivered to 
the RealOne Player, Windows Media Player, and Quicktime, is specifically 
designed to prevent you from recording it.

Still, it's almost always still possible to record anything your computer 
can play by looping your sound-out jack to your sound-in/microphone jack on 
your computer's sound card.

Use a 1/8 inch stereo mini to 1/8 inch stereo mini cable. Connect one end to 
the sound-out jack on your computer or sound card (where you would plug 
speakers or headphones - it's often colored green). Connect the other end to 
the microphone or line-in jack (it's often colored red).

Now Audacity can record anything your computer plays. Press Record in 
Audacity, and then press Play in your streaming audio program.

-------------

I wonder if you could tap (tee?) /dev/dsp and forgo the cable?


--
Kyle Accardi

From dgc at easystreet.com  Sun Nov 23 11:19:01 2003
From: dgc at easystreet.com (Dave Clemans)
Date: Sun Nov 23 11:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Recording Internet radio
In-Reply-To: <3FC0F92C.2020104@pacifier.com>
References: <1069549807.23716.34.camel@halo> 	<3FC00E25.9000601@pacifier.com> <1069610682.1605.23.camel@halo> <3FC0F92C.2020104@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <3FC109FE.2050600@easystreet.com>

Kyle Accardi wrote:
> 
> 5. Can I record RealAudio or other streaming audio?
> 
> Not automatically. Most streaming audio, including most music delivered 
> to the RealOne Player, Windows Media Player, and Quicktime, is 
> specifically designed to prevent you from recording it.
> 

> 
> I wonder if you could tap (tee?) /dev/dsp and forgo the cable?
> 

Actually you can, if (for example) you can get a copy of the LD_PRELOAD 
library "vsound".  That library puts a wrapper around the open, etc. 
system calls that lets you substitute a file or potentially another file 
descriptor for the file /dev/dsp.

I currently use it (along with the simple command line player from 
Real's HelixDNA project) to access a couple RealAudio internet radio 
stations from my TiVo byRequest linux server.

dgc

This is DUMB DUMB DUMB.

Do you realize the tool of abuse you're becoming?

with a Home Depot flyer.  BOOM!  You guys fly into action and I sit back
and laugh.

Howard Dean, Fourth Grade Graduate."  Negative ads disguised as positive
ads.  It's going to happen quite soon.

Quoth Grish, on Sun, 23 Nov 2003 11:19:50 -0800:

> Unfortunately, you are wrong. The law legitimizes and legalizes spam
> that meets certain conditions (ADV: subject, real headers, etc.)... At
> least how I understand it. IANAL.

Still, I'm very glad the ADV: is required.  That's key.  Though the bill establishes a formal opt-out system (among other obvious flaws), the subject tag provides the means to opt-in instead.

The spam problem (for the 99% of us who think of it as such) calls for both a legislative and a technical solution, the goal of which is to make spamming, if not unprofitable for spammers, at least inexpensive to the rest of us.  The more spam I can channel out of my inbox, the closer we come to both goals.

--Jason Van Cleve

From ian at znark.com  Sun Nov 23 14:47:02 2003
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Sun Nov 23 14:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] replacing the system Hard drive
In-Reply-To: <2977.216.99.218.67.1069626474.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <2977.216.99.218.67.1069626474.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <3FC138BE.4000004@znark.com>

Josh Orchard wrote:
> 
> I have two HD in the sysem.  One is for the OS and some other minor
> things and the other is mostly home dirs and files.
> 

Having two drives does make things easier because you can leave the 
second drive alone.

> I think the system drive is going bad and want to do a complete move
> from the old HD of 30GB to a new HD of 120GB.  Beside attaining a copy
> of Ghost what alternatives do I have?  I know I'll have to take the
> computer off line and boot from a floppy to move the drive but not
> sure how to do it.
> 

You might want to consider doing a fresh install on the new drive.

> My first guess is to use dd but not familiar with that well enough to
> know if that is the best tool for the job.
> 

dd only works if the filesystems are exactly the same.  I have found 
that "cp -a" works fine.  There is also a piped tar command that people 
use to copy files.

> Suggestions?  I want to be able to take the computer offline for a
> short time.  Mount the other HD.  Reboot on a floopy, run a command to
> move the contents from the old drive to the new.  Take out the old
> drive and boot up with the new drive.  The Old OS and all files should
> still be there.  hmm,  Will there be partition problems?  Or just
> extra space I can repartition later?
> 

The way I would do it is:

1. Backup system files onto second hard drive.  /etc, list of packages, 
/root

2. Put in the new hard drive.  Boot to old drive or floppy.

3. Partition new drive.  Copy files from old drive to new drive.

4. Swap old drive and new drive and maybe remove old drive.  Boot to new 
drive.

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/

From raanders at acm.org  Sun Nov 23 16:41:02 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Sun Nov 23 16:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Trouble trying to compile bind 8.4...
In-Reply-To: <1069537849.8556.2.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0311221605080.9664-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On 22 Nov 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> Just out of curiosity, is djbdns bind 8.4 compatible?  I'm wondering
> if I can try to install both and migrate.  How different are the
> configuration files? How do you chroot djbdns?

Don't know about the bind 8.4 capatible but it does follow the (or mostly 
follow) the actaul standards.  Of course I'm talking from no _real_ 
experience with tinydns - Ed's the one in the know on this.
   I do run dnscache for two caching nameservers it it runs as dnscache 
(and dnslog for the logging function).  These currently are _VERY_ lightly 
loaded servers so I can't attest to their performance under load but they 
are much smaller (code wise) than bind and do a specific task - answer DNS 
queries.

Back to tinydns.  You should look into it.  The 'zone' files aka. database
are much simpler and designed to be processed by programs easily.  You can
migrate (http://cr.yp.to/djbdns/frombind.html).  But wait ... Several
other benefits come at no additional charge.  Lighter foot print and more 
security are just two.
   If you get interested try attending one of Ed Sawicki's "DNS Boot Camp"
classes (http://www.alcpress.com/training/dnsboot/).


Rod

> ON-topic to all you folks who bitch about off-topic posts?  Perhaps plug

> this crud from the inbox of those who have better things to do than sludge
> through email on this topic.

Jeme,

    (1) I liked your posting.  I am generally uneasy about new laws
        in part because of laws tend to have many unintended consequences.
        I'm afraid that any anti-spam legislation could possibly ban a lot
        of legitimate communication, while encouraging at least some
        of the spam the legislation is aimed at.

    (2) Thus, I tend to think the best solutions to our spam problems are
        technical.

    (3) In terms of getting a PLUG-spam or PLUG-email list, we create one
        if people wanted.  Do you think there would be enough long term
        interest in such a list to justify it.  Personally, I wouldn't
        limit the list to discussion of spam; but rather expand it to
        any mail problems including technical discussions of potential
        solutions.

From holger at selover.net  Sun Nov 23 23:06:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Sun Nov 23 23:06:02 2003
Subject: PLUG-spam list??  Was Re: [PLUG] House Passed the Anti-Spam Bill
In-Reply-To: <1069654721.1927.72.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0311232149400.24755-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com> 
	<1069654721.1927.72.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <1069657503.2445.194.camel@halo>

On Sun, 2003-11-23 at 22:18, AthlonRob wrote:
> FWIW, that sounds like a decent idea to me.  I would subscribe to a
> PLUG-email list.

Me too.

In my opinion the spam discussion is relevant for Linux activists for
these reasons:

1) A good part of us administer Linux servers and spam is part of the
task.

2) Spam in a way 'helps' us as it increases the awareness of the average
user. IT, software, the operation system is getting more media
bandwidth. We need this recognition, especially when we promote a system
that cannot be consumed as easily as the mainstream fast food system.
When IT runs in the background without any ripples people will take it
for granted and reduce its priority. This will also affect the budget. 

3) One reason why I am attracted by Linux is the freedom of choice,
freedom of using more control over the technology I am working with many
hours a day. New laws that reduce the freedom of distributing
information scare me. In my country, not too long ago, law has burned
books and banned information, free speech. Sure, a spam law is meant for
"bad" information. Problem is how to define "bad". You leave control
over deciding what is "bad" to people who may have a different
definition of "bad". Maybe not today, but such a law can be used as a
door opener in the future. For that reason I am generally oppose
outlawing the distribution of information, unless it supports a crime or
collides with the constitution. 

4) In 3) I explain that, for me, making spam a crime is a drastic
measure. I don't see the necessity. Others have pointed out the problem
can be controlled with technology. And labor. Which may work for the
administrators in our group (no, not me). 

5) Why is spam such a big deal? Last week I posted to this group why it
is not a problem for me. I control it with SpamAssassin and a few other
rather easy techniques and receive such a small number of spam mails
that I don't even get annoyed. I use Linux for this. If it works with
our toolset we should see this as a chance to deliver superior
technology on Linux to get a handle on this problem. Not that you
couldn't do this on Windows servers. But now there is a race to deliver
working solutions to this problem, and open source solutions are holding
a pretty good position in this race. People are annoyed and a working
solution will get their attention. 

6) The spam problem is often mixed and confused with security. Sometimes
with reason, when spam also delivers a virus. Security has a huge
potential to change the IT landscape with a momentum we may not have
expected a few months back. And security talk tends to work to the
advantage of Linux. 

7) We are talking about technology here, right? Well, however the
society deals with spam, technology will be the most important component
in any solution. As was pointed out by others, a US law to ban spam will
still keep enough spam coming from other countries. So, lets work on the
technology to solve this problem. 

Thus, a triple hip hip hurray on spam! ;)

Sorry for the long ramble, normally not my style.

- Holger

On Sun, 23 Nov 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> Well, if I can find the right way to execute a non perl command like sed
> in the client perl CGI script, I should be able to break the long line
> and assign the pieces off.

If you are calling sed from within perl, you really shouldn't be using
perl.  I mean, that makes absolutely no sense whatsoever.

> I've executed other non perl commands.

... probably unnecessarily.

> I think there are some bugs in my script overall.

No offense, but judging from the level of knowledge your question belies,
I'd say there has to be.

> Lining parentheses up in the way that looks correct oddly breaks it.

Are you using an editor that helps you with this?

> I thought all variables were global in perl.

No.  And some of the scoping can be a real hassle unless you explicitly
narrow everything to where it is declared.

use strict;

perldoc strict

> Maybe my subroutines need to be defined within the main function to give
> all the variables global scope.

I think you don't know how perl works.  There are lots of good tutorials,
but I happen to like Programming Perl.  It's a fine book.

For this purpose, you should certainly be using the perl CGI library.
While it's not always necessary for simple applications, it might help you
to deal with things that you're finding difficult.

use CGI;

Add all that up, and your CGI script should start like this:

#! /usr/bin/perl -wT

use strict;
use CGI;

Got it?

POST or GET?

Either way, one string is spec...

| Only some of the browsers I have send it this way, others post it
| as three seperate strings which is much easier to work with...


I've never heard of this behavior before. Granted, I'm not deeply
immersed in CGI programming, but I have done my share of it.

| Is there a standard behavior or not for this?


Yes. The CGI/1.1 spec.

http://hoohoo.ncsa.uiuc.edu/cgi/

| How can I break this apart with a perl script?
|

The painfully obvious way is:


grishnav at egosurf cgi-bin $ perl
$test = "a=b&1=2&4=3";

my %hash;
my @array = split(/&/,$test);
for (@array) {
~        my ($name, $value) = split(/=/);
~        $hash{$name} = $value;
}
print "$hash{'a'}\n\n";
^d
b

grishnav at egosurf cgi-bin $


But the better way is:

#!/usr/bin/perl

use strict;
use warnings;
use CGI qw/:standard/;

my $password = param('password') or die ("stfu\n");
my $a - param('a') or die ("End users suck\n");

[...]


And the even better way is to use the OO version of the above (if
you're mind has been warped in the ways of OO, that is):

#!/usr/bin/perl

use strict;
use warnings;
use CGI qw/:standard/;

my $q = new CGI;

my $password = $q->param('password');
my $a = $q->param('a');

[...]


More info:

perl => http://www.perldoc.com/
cgi.pm => http://www.perldoc.com/perl5.8.0/lib/CGI.html


Hope that helps....

Michael C. Robinson wrote:

|
| Well, if I can find the right way to execute a non perl command
| like sed in the client perl CGI script, I should be able to  break
|  the long line and assign the pieces off.


Why in the HELL would you want to execute SED from a perl script?

You can execute with backticks, or system(), and open().
`sed -e "blah"`;
system("sed -e \"blah\"");
open(SED,"sed -e \"blah\" |");

But why? Anything sed can do, perl can do better.

Consider the following:

cat randfile | sed -e 's/field/b/'

perl:

cat randfile | perl -ne 's/field/b/; print;'

They will produce the exact same output.

| I think there are some bugs in my script overall.


If you're executing sed from a perl script, yeah, there probably are.

| I thought all variables were global in perl.


No... though I can't remember exactly what the rules are anymore...

| Maybe my subroutines need to be defined within the main function to
| give all the variables global scope.


??

Why do all of your variables /need/ global scope?

Michael C. Robinson wrote:

| Another problem I'm running into with my perl script using
| NetEasyTCP is that I need to be able to open a connection to
| multiple servers where some may not be up.  These servers are meant
| to provide redundancy for each other, I should be able to turn one
| off and have the client script still work.  What do I need to do
| instead of:
|
| client -> send ( ... ) || die; client -> receive ( ... ) || die;
|
| ?
|

I've not yet dived into the realm of socket programming, in Perl (or
any other language, for that matter).

However, here's a stab in the dark:

client -> send ( ... );
client -> recieve (...);

If you don't tell your script to die, it (generally) won't. Write a
subroutine that handles the error (prints a warning, logs it,
whatever) and move on.

client -> send (...) or &failure("$!");
client -> recieve (...) or &failure("$!");

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Nov 24 09:50:02 2003

	 <20031124083635.GT15659@maybe.net>

Message-ID: <1069696159.5511.21.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2003-11-24 at 01:09, Josh Orchard wrote:

> Is there some way to test for that?  Can I create another swap like a
> file since I can't make another partition now.  I knew in HP you could
> add to the swap space by defining a file then make that file the
> primary swap.  Not very efficient but worked.  Anything similar for
> linux?

I realize you seem to have ruled out a bad swap partition, so this may
not be much help... but is a worthy tip for folks, regardless.

To use a swap file instead of a swap partition, or in addition to (you
can create these on the fly if you find you need more swap in the middle
of something)... 

dd if=/dev/zero of=/path/to/swap/file bs=1M count=n
...where n is the number of megabytes you want the swap file to be.

mkswap /path/to/swap/file
swapon /path/to/swap/file

...and bam, you've got more swap.

Rob

  AKA. the MACH micro-kernel.  AKA. FreeBSD

From: 
http://developer.apple.com/darwin/history.html

 "Darwin also incorporates a full implementation of BSD (Berkeley Software
Distribution) UNIX, welded on top of the Mach kernel. The hybrid BSD
architecture adopted by Darwin embodies its historical association with the
BSD code base and underscores both the project's strong relationship with
the various BSD organizations and its strong cultural affinity with the open
source developer community. Indeed, Darwin itself constitutes a full-blown
operating system, complete in and of itself, made available as open source
by Apple -- a fact that's both astonishing and under-appreciated. 

Darwin is comprised of five main components: the Mach microkernel and BSD
subsystem, the file system, networking, and the I/O Kit."

  Darwin is a fine OpenSource project.  I'd like to play with it sometime,
*if* I can find some cheap hardware to run it on.

From raanders at acm.org  Mon Nov 24 11:32:02 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Mon Nov 24 11:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Trouble with CGU forms...
In-Reply-To: <1069647978.12300.51.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0311241125210.6234-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On 23 Nov 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> I'm trying to use a CGI form to send three values to a 
> perl script.  Most browsers send it as three values, but 
> sometimes I get 

CGI.pm is your friend.

	use CGI.pm;

	my $SignUp = new CGI;
	my %SignUpInfo;

	my @PARAMS = $SignUp->param;

	map {$SignUpInfo{$_} = $SignUp->param($_)} @PARAMS;

And you have these three or any number of new ones.

> host=eagle.robinson-west.com&pass=bogusbogus&a=on.

This is what I am currently using since the number of variables seems to 
be cancerous and growing from within the CGI script also not just from the 
HTML page and form.  :-(


Cheers,
Rod

Hi, it's me again. Anyhow I purchased a 160-GB hard
drive that was too large for my BIOS to support, and
installed an offboard drive controller for that
reason. Windows XP has a driver for this controller
and installed it without any trouble. And that's
saying quite a bit, in view of XP's notorious driver
problems. 

And what about Red Hat 9.0? Promise Technology's Web
site offers drivers for this card, but when I followed
their instructions, including kernel parameters, the
drive was not recognized. Then I tried the
installation without their assistance, and the drive
was recognized, though as hde. The installation
program was already beginning to install packages into
newly-created ext3 partitions when it encountered
problems and gave up. 

Could it be media problems, or inadequate support for
the Promise controller? I made the disks myself,
though they passed the md5sum check and the additional
media check that Red Hat provides. I would be willing
to try another distribution, if that is more likely to
succeed--including, of course, Fedora, which I have
not yet downloaded. I would be particularly interested
in hearing from people who have distributions
successfully installed with such RAID controllers.

From michael at robinson-west.com  Mon Nov 24 12:43:02 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Mon Nov 24 12:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux server constantly rebooting.
In-Reply-To: <1069691383.3914.452.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <3958.216.99.218.67.1069656122.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<1069660445.3965.407.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
	<4994.216.99.218.67.1069662802.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<20031124083635.GT15659@maybe.net>
	<1105.216.99.218.67.1069664982.squirrel@sautez.com> 
	<1069690439.846.9.camel@fastlinux.homenet> 
	<1069691383.3914.452.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1069706285.16848.6.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Mon, 2003-11-24 at 08:29, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> On Mon, 2003-11-24 at 08:13, Derek Loree wrote:
> > Have you tried booting Knoppix, yet?  If it still reboots, then you
> > should start unplugging things until you can get something to stay up. 
> > Bad RAM might do this too, memtest86 is the tool for that.
> 
> Excellent, Derek. This removes software as the issue. I really suspect
> hardware here, don't you?
> 

How about power management?  I have trouble where sometimes my Pentium
III's won't boot when it's on in the bios and sometimes they won't boot
when it's off.  It's probably the messiest idea next to the serial and
parallel ports that is on the modern PC.  It's arguably better to make
devices use less power to operate than it is to try to make them power
manage, especially if they're always busy and never idle.  Another big
one to look for that is often not obvious is what your parallel port
is set to in bios, setting it to ECP or standard appears to be much 
safer than setting it to EPP.  I've seen windows boxes run for a while
and crash because of the parallel port setting.  I suspect there's a
bug between EPP mode and power management, but I'm not sure.

-- 
-----------------------------
Michael C. Robinson

Associates of General Studies 
PCC March 2003.

From miken at hotsushi.com  Mon Nov 24 13:16:01 2003
From: miken at hotsushi.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Mon Nov 24 13:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] linux server constantly rebooting
In-Reply-To: <3957.216.99.218.67.1069655989.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <20031124220704.05B99109D@www.hotsushi.com>

>My server is constantly rebooting.  It gets to the log in screen then
>some blocks of data go across the screen then reboots.  Get uptimes of
>like 5 minutes.

Hi,

Had a box do this after a few years.  Turned out I'd selected a power
supply that was barely adequate (250W for 2 SCSI drives, 2 CDs, lots of
cards).  I pulled a hard drive and it went back to reliable operation.  Put
the drive back, bumped the power supply by a hundred watts and all is well.

Cheers,
Mike

cgui will notice that you now have all these options.

From sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com  Mon Nov 24 22:03:01 2003
From: sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com (Sasha Romanosky)
Date: Mon Nov 24 22:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RAID 1 suggestions
In-Reply-To: <4437.216.99.218.67.1069737763.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <000001c3b319$b92bb6f0$6401a8c0@laptop>

I've got a soyo motherboard with the onboard promise lite RAID 0/1
capability. I set it up with RAID 0 (presumably for gaming performance
on windows) and have regreted it every day since. I would have much
rather done onboard RAID 1 and more or less rid myself of backup
hassles. 

This board actually has 4 IDE channels: 2 for RAID 0 or 1 configuration
(colored black) and 2 others just cause (colored blue). So you can use
the black IDE channels for raid (one drive on each - chaining doesn't
work on these channels when using RAID) and the blue IDE channels for
other IDE devices (master/slave is fine). Making for a total of 6
devices. 

The bios also allows you to use the black channels as regular IDE
controllers if you don't want to do RAID. I'm not sure if this would
increase ide device capacity up to 8 or not, but it gives you more
channels than a regular motherboard, in either case.

At one point I wanted to do SW RAID 5 and from my research it seemed
that the performance hit, on a modern system, even in software, wasn't
enough to really make a difference. Given that, I wouldn't imagine that
RAID 1 would produce any noticeable delay*. 

If I had to do it again, I'd probably invest the time to learn md in
linux and remove any hw/vendor dependencies of using onboard raid. 

Hope that helps.

sasha

* of course, I'm talking a little out of my ass, so ymmv.

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Nov 24 22:21:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon Nov 24 22:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RAID 1 suggestions
In-Reply-To: <4437.216.99.218.67.1069737763.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4437.216.99.218.67.1069737763.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311242215350.22235@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 24 Nov 2003, Josh Orchard wrote:
> This lead me to think about running RAID 1 as a cheap backup.

Is this perfectly sound?  I mean, it seems to be and I do it on my home
fileserver, but I'm wondering if someone who knows a hell of a lot about
such things would just agree without caveat or if there's something that
should be taken into account.

> Does anyone know which is better?  Will the bios system give better
> support and be faster?  Will I even notice the difference?  I have
> priced a system that will do for my needs for around $500.  I could save
> a few dollars using MD but if the extra cash increases proformance I
> would spend the money.

Well, the intuitive response is that the hardware implementation will be
faster and less drain on system resources, but that really depends, I
suppose, on exactly which hardware and how it's implemented.

I use Linux MD (software raid) RAID1 on an old P166 for an NFS server
(serving /home to every other machine) at the house and I can't say that
it's given me even the tiniest bit of trouble.  It's a bit slower than a
single local disk, but I think that the network has a heck of a lot more
to do with that than the RAID.

Oh, and I've had power outages and all kinds of weird things happen in the
last few years with no obvious ill effects.  It's reiserfs on RAID1.

J.

It's sound, as long as you have a hard copy of the commands to run  to
change your mirrored disk to a single disk. 

I set my "gotta run" solaris boxes up with raid 1 boot drives. I keep a
copy of the instructions to unmirror the drive that survives a crash in
my filing cabinet. 

To safeguard against one taking out the other, and deleting the wrong
file, you should also have an off system backup.

From chris-plug at maybe.net  Mon Nov 24 23:09:01 2003
From: chris-plug at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Mon Nov 24 23:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RAID 1 suggestions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311242215350.22235@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <4437.216.99.218.67.1069737763.squirrel@sautez.com> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311242215350.22235@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20031125070811.GU15659@maybe.net>

On Mon, Nov 24, 2003 at 10:22:01PM -0800, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> On Mon, 24 Nov 2003, Josh Orchard wrote:
> > This lead me to think about running RAID 1 as a cheap backup.
> 
> Is this perfectly sound?  I mean, it seems to be and I do it on my home
> fileserver, but I'm wondering if someone who knows a hell of a lot about
> such things would just agree without caveat or if there's something that
> should be taken into account.

I've been doing it for quite some time and have, in fact, returned a few
drives and replaced some here and there. And my data marches on. There's
some segments I wouldn't mind backing up, but I can't afford the kind of
media that would take. Any kind of data storage plan these days isn't so
straightforward as "buy a bunch of tape and back it up". In fact, in
some cases, for certain kinds of storage scenarios, you're better off
just backing it all up to a spare hard drive and putting it into a safe.
What's the point of spending $10,000 on a SuperDLT and/or Ultrium
storage solution just to store a bunch of email?

> 
> > Does anyone know which is better?  Will the bios system give better
> > support and be faster?  Will I even notice the difference?  I have
> > priced a system that will do for my needs for around $500.  I could save
> > a few dollars using MD but if the extra cash increases proformance I
> > would spend the money.
> 
> Well, the intuitive response is that the hardware implementation will be
> faster and less drain on system resources, but that really depends, I
> suppose, on exactly which hardware and how it's implemented.

Not, actually. 99% of these on-board solutions are little more than boot
assistance and vendor lock-in. They don't do any computation whatsoever.
Look at the drivers in Linux. They all say "software" RAID for these
cards. You really are better off using md. Or a real hardware RAID
controller. The Adaptec aacraid driver appears that it may support newer
SATA controllers. I'm very happy with my 3ware. Or you can get any
number of SCSI RAID controllers. I've got an amazing DPT I've grown out
of up for sale. ;-) Plus hardware RAID takes all the headache out of
software RAID1 booting (which I've done in the past). BIOS RAID may
actually help on this one issue, surprisingly -- no experience, though.

I don't have time to go look it up, but jwz had an article on how he's
noticed that he hasn't done backups in years -- just migrated data from
machine to machine -- i.e., making sure the hardware's fresh every so
many generations.

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Nov 25 08:32:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Tue Nov 25 08:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] (no subject)
In-Reply-To: <4794.216.99.218.67.1069777193.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0311250828090.11915-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

This means that 192.42.93.34 advertized itself as having authoritative
information for domain socceramerica.net but in fact does not.
It's a problem in the remote server configuration, but nothing you need to
worry about.

If you don't want to see these messages, add this to your bind config
file:
logging {
category lame-servers { null; };
};

From drl at drloree.com  Tue Nov 25 08:54:01 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue Nov 25 08:54:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RAID 1 suggestions
In-Reply-To: <4437.216.99.218.67.1069737763.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4437.216.99.218.67.1069737763.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <1069779263.846.78.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-11-24 at 21:22, Josh Orchard wrote:
> Hello,
> 
> With my constantly rebooting system, which seems to have resolved
> itself over night, I have decided to rebuild a new system.  It has
> been 4-5 years of it running well and I think one drive is not doing
> well.
> 
> This lead me to think about running RAID 1 as a cheap backup.  I read
> about Motherboards with the promise bios RAID built into them.  I have
> also used MD in Linux once or twice to setup one RAID system for
> afternoon(okay it was like 2 days) fun.

RAID is not a substitute for a good backup.  It cannot be taken
off-site, and the both hard drives are just as vulnerable to power
supply spikes or surges.  It can make for an easily recoverable system,
but don't rely on it for the only protection of your data.

Check out the article at Tom's Hardware Guide:

http://www.tomshardware.com/storage/20031114/raidcore-01.html

This gives a good overview of the current state of IDE RAID
controllers.  However, a real RAID controller (not a software RAID
controller like most of the Promise controllers) is going to blow that
$500 budget. 
> 
> Does anyone know which is better?  Will the bios system give better
> support and be faster?  Will I even notice the difference?  I have
> priced a system that will do for my needs for around $500.  I could
> save a few dollars using MD but if the extra cash increases
> proformance I would spend the money.

Real RAID is going to be faster, but to really get the performance out
of it, you will need to get the 10,000 RPM SATA drives, and the combo of
the drives and the controller will more than double your budget.

The linux software RAID is, IMO, better than the software RAID that the
Promise people have put together.  The tricky part is convincing your OS
to boot to the RAID device.  So far, I've avoided the issue by having
the OS reside on a 4 or 5 gig partition, and have /home and/or /var
mounted as RAID devices.  The OS partition is then rsync'ed to a
similiar sized partition on the second drive each night.

HTH,

Derek Loree

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Nov 25 09:54:01 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue Nov 25 09:54:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RAID 1 suggestions
In-Reply-To: <1069779263.846.78.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

 <1069779263.846.78.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <7385-43007@sneakemail.com>

On Tue, 25 Nov 2003, Derek Loree drl-at-drloree.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> RAID is not a substitute for a good backup.  It cannot be taken
> off-site, and the both hard drives are just as vulnerable to power
> supply spikes or surges.  It can make for an easily recoverable system,
> but don't rely on it for the only protection of your data.

I'll second this.

The big reason for me not to rely on RAID as a backup is that mirroring
will dutifully mirror accidental deletes/changes.  Backups create a nice
point-in-time copy.  (The same could be done to an extra hard disk, but
that's just a backup to disk, not RAID...)

I use RAID as a means to avoid having to rebuild my system when a
hard drive dies.  It also ensures that when this happens I have zero data
loss.

> The linux software RAID is, IMO, better than the software RAID that the
> Promise people have put together.  The tricky part is convincing your OS
> to boot to the RAID device.  So far, I've avoided the issue by having
> the OS reside on a 4 or 5 gig partition, and have /home and/or /var
> mounted as RAID devices.  The OS partition is then rsync'ed to a
> similiar sized partition on the second drive each night.

I've not had any problems putting boot, root, and even swap on a software
RAID partition with RedHat 7 or newer.  The /boot partition needs separate
LILO and/or GRUB entries for each half of the mirror for easier booting
when one disk dies, but otherwise software mirroring is quite
straightforward.

I've had a hard time finding a way to do software mirroring on my Win2k
Professional system though.  Does anyone know of a free product that does
this? (preferably Open Source, but I'm not going to get my hopes up...)

  -- Steve

On Tue, Nov 25, 2003 at 12:42:17AM -0800, Russell Senior wrote:
> 
> I've been dinking around with user-mode linux recently.  I am using a
> debian file system I believe I got from the user-mode linux site some
> time ago (apt-get updated recently), as well as a 2.4.22-5um kernel I
> got from Debian.  One curiosity is that _sometimes_ the boot stalls on
> "Calculating module dependencies...".  If I press a key, it boots the
> rest of the way.  Sometimes it goes all the way to a login prompt
> without intervention.  Anyone know (hazard a guess) why?  It is sort
> of annoying.  My startup script looks like:

You may want to try the rootstrap tool first (apt-get install rootstrap)
which is designed to build your own custom, current Debian uml image.
Also of note, I believe you should use "con=pts" instead (at least it's
what I'm using ;-), and if you want it to fully "background" use
"con0=pts,fd:1" and watch the boot message carefully for the pts that
tty1 is mapped to. Then minicom in on that pts. (Though using fd:0 the
first few times might be easier :-D)

I use uml here extensively, though my disk and network configuration is
completely different from what you're using. I'm sure we can hammer
something out, eh? :-)

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Tue Nov 25 11:03:01 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Tue Nov 25 11:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RAID 1 suggestions
In-Reply-To: <7385-43007@sneakemail.com>
References: <4437.216.99.218.67.1069737763.squirrel@sautez.com> <1069779263.846.78.camel@fastlinux.homenet> <7385-43007@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <20031125190142.GB23507@bavariati.org>

On Tue, Nov 25, 2003 at 09:53:12AM -0800, Steve Bonds wrote:
> I've had a hard time finding a way to do software mirroring on my Win2k
> Professional system though.  Does anyone know of a free product that does
> this? (preferably Open Source, but I'm not going to get my hopes up...)

Unlike NT 3.5 and 4.0, Win2K/XP Pro have SW-RAID disabled in the
pro/workstation versions.  Silly, I know, but having Marketing make
weird technical decisions is par for the course with commercial s/w.

Three ways to get RAID:
1. Buy a RAID controller.  Even a cheapo pseudo-RAID controller will do,
since you wanted SW-RAID from the beginning.  You'll need to reinstall
everything to get it on the RAID drive, and please have a driver disc
(and spare) handy for the install and for some recovery operations.
2. Follow the RAID Hack instructions (in Dutch) at:
http://balusc.xs4all.nl/Ned/Twe-WRH.html
3. Find raidhack.w2k.enu.exe on eDonkey or whatever.

Note that 1 puts you at the mercy of a hardware vendor and 2 and 3,
while cheap, are fraught with danger and will likely break your EULA.
That's the non-Free world for ya.


flames to microsoft-haters-l please,
  Aaron

> > without intervention.  Anyone know (hazard a guess) why?  It is sort
> > of annoying.  My startup script looks like:
> 
> You may want to try the rootstrap tool first (apt-get install rootstrap)
> which is designed to build your own custom, current Debian uml image.
> Also of note, I believe you should use "con=pts" instead (at least it's
> what I'm using ;-), and if you want it to fully "background" use
> "con0=pts,fd:1" and watch the boot message carefully for the pts that
> tty1 is mapped to. Then minicom in on that pts. (Though using fd:0 the
> first few times might be easier :-D)

I agree, the rootstrap tool does a good job of building a current debian
system using good old apt, change your sources as needed.  If you have
problems with Woody, try Sarge instead.

I use "screen" to handle the uml start up, this way the boot messages
are available, and it will start on its own without an X-server, or
dedicated console assignment.  This is the script that I use to start
the uml as a service from /etc/init.d/:

#!/bin/bash


screen -S uml -d -m su - derek "cd /home/derek/uml ; linux eth0=tuntap,,,192.168.0.3 umid=uml con=pty con0=fd:0,fd:1"

HTH,

Derek Loree

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Nov 25 11:57:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue Nov 25 11:57:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RAID 1 suggestions
In-Reply-To: <4514.216.99.218.67.1069742039.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4437.216.99.218.67.1069737763.squirrel@sautez.com>   
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311242215350.22235@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <4514.216.99.218.67.1069742039.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <18296-97190@sneakemail.com>

On Mon, 24 Nov 2003, Josh Orchard josh-at-emediatedesigns.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I don't know what else I would want to take into account. Here is what
> I'm trying to resolve:
>
> 1. Backups
> 2. Little but preferred no maintenance
> 3. Easy recovery
>
> It just seemed that RAID 1 was a simple solution with little worries.
> The other option is to RSYN the drives minus the obvious /proc and some
> others.  But this doesn't give you hot swap ability.  You would have to
> turn off the drive do a lilo or other grub loader thingy and then it
> would work again.  Maybe.

For a really simple, low-effort way to achieve this, I would think about
the following:

Allocate 50% of each drive for the usual filesystems, software mirrored.
This protects you from hardware failure but not from accidental deletes,
programs going nuts, filesystem bugs, etc. etc.

For example, on a pair of hypothetical 40GB drives you could have half the
drive used like this:

200MB  /dev/md0 /boot
512MB  /dev/md1 <swap>
8192MB /dev/md2 /
8192MB /dev/md3 /home

The rest of the drives serves as a mirrored local to-disk backup area:

16384MB /dev/md4 /backups

I suggest setting up a script that uses "dump" to back up the mirrored
partitions to the backups area.  A sample script is attached.

The first level 0 dump should be copied to a couple tapes, a stack of
CD-Rs, or a hard drive that is removed from the system.  (Alternatively,
only allocate 25% of your disks, and make the backup area the other 75%,
but that wastes a lot of your online storage on static data.)

The level 0 backup would only be needed if a file that has not changed
since that level 0 backup was created needed to be restored.  I've never
had to do this, since I seem to only damage/delete recently created files.
However, you'll want that level 0 backup somewhere-- just in case.  (I
usually use stacks of CD-Rs for this.)

The attached backup script sample schedule never does a level 0 (full)
backup for this reason.

Easy recovery is the reason I like the dump utility.  Using "restore -i" I
can use the bash-like interface to mark the files I want restored, then
restore them.  (Because RAID provides basic protection, I'm seldom doing a
full restore.)

The "Tower of Hanoi" sequence mentioned in the script makes it a bit
harder to find the files you want restored but saves lots of disk space.
If you want a truly easy recovery, just make every backup a level 1 and
you'll never need to hunt through multiple backups to find the files you
want.

As always, do a test restore to familiarize yourself with the process so
you don't have to learn it under pressure.  Also, periodic test restores
help ensure that the backups are valid and that you've included all the
devices that should be included.

  -- Steve
-------------- next part --------------
#!/bin/sh

# Backs up system to a second local drive using "dump".  The only parameter
# is the "dump" incremental level.  This script has only been tested
# on Linux using ext2 dump.

# YOU MUST RUN A LEVEL 0 BACKUP MANUALLY BEFORE USING THIS SCRIPT.  It will
# still work without this, but your first "level 1" will be huge.

# Below is a sample schedule of system backups with level 1 on 
# Saturday.  Adjust schedule as makes the most sense for your 
# activity schedule.  The below "Tower of Hanoi" sequence
# is highly recommended since it allows for a maximum number of points
# in time available for recovery with a minimum amount of storage usage.
# (At the expense of some additional complexity during restores.)

# To restore a given day's data:
# DoW     Levels needed
# ------ --------------
# Sat(6): 1
# Sun(0): 1,3
# Mon(1): 1,2
# Tue(2): 1,3,5
# Wed(3): 1,2,4
# Thu(4): 1,3,5,7
# Fri(5): 1,2,4,6

# Sample crontab entries for the above schedule:

#00 06 * * 6 root /root/backup.sh 1 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1
#00 06 * * 0 root /root/backup.sh 3 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1
#00 06 * * 1 root /root/backup.sh 2 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1
#00 06 * * 2 root /root/backup.sh 5 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1
#00 06 * * 3 root /root/backup.sh 4 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1
#00 06 * * 4 root /root/backup.sh 7 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1
#00 06 * * 5 root /root/backup.sh 6 >> /var/tmp/backup.cron.out 2>&1

# The simplest way to restore a file is to use 
# "restore -t -A <archive file>" to list the contents of the dump and
# grep for the file(s) that need to be restored.  Then use "restore -i"
# to interactively restore them.

# Note that this script overwrites each level's previous backup with the
# new one.  It also aborts on the first error so any subsequent 
# filesystems will NOT BE BACKED UP.

# Steve Bonds
# Email: rn5o6kw02 at sneakemail.com
# Copyright 2003, All rights reserved
# Redistribution permitted under the terms of the GNU General Public License
# version 2.0.  http://www.gnu.org/copyleft/gpl.html

bail() {
	MAIL_NEEDED=yes
	echo `date` "[$$]: Error: $1"
	echo `date` "[$$]: Error: $1" >> $MAIL_BODY
	MAIL_SUBJECT="Fatal backup error on $HOSTNAME"
	send_mail
	exit 1
}	

send_mail() {
	if [ "${MAIL_NEEDED}x" != "x" -a "${MAIL_TO}x" != "x" ]; then
		cat $MAIL_BODY | $MAIL_CMD "$MAIL_SUBJECT" $MAIL_TO
		cat $MAIL_BODY
	elif [ "${MAIL_NEEDED}x" != "x" ]; then
		echo "Subject: $MAIL_SUBJECT"
		cat $MAIL_BODY
	fi
	rm -f $MAIL_BODY
}

############################################################
# Customize these as needed
MAIL_TO=root

# This script assumes that the following structure is in place:
# ${BACKUP_AREA}/level0
# ${BACKUP_AREA}/level1
# ...
# ${BACKUP_AREA}/level9
BACKUP_AREA=/backups

# List of devices to back up without the /dev in front.  Don't
# try to back up the area where $BACKUP_AREA is located or you
# will waste a LOT of space.
DEVICES="md0 md1 md2 md3"

############################################################
# These should be fine as-is

HOSTNAME=`hostname`
MAIL_CMD="mail -s"
MAIL_BODY=`mktemp backup.XXXXXX`

############################################################
# Actual commands

LEVEL=$1
: ${LEVEL:?"Please specify backup level (0-9), 0=full"}
shift

# Backups contain every file on the system, so it's real important to be sure
# that only root can read them.
umask 077

case $LEVEL in
	[0123456789]) # OK to proceed
	;;
	*) echo "Invalid level, must be 0 through 9"
	exit
esac

for device in $DEVICES; do
	# If you like, you can create cd-sized images via -M -B 665600
	# This is handy for burning them onto CD-R media

	# The filenames are used several places, so only figure them
	# out once.  Do not embed a datestamp so each level's backup
	# overwrites the previous one.
	DUMP_FILE=${BACKUP_AREA}/level${LEVEL}/${device}.dump
	ARCHIVE_FILE=${BACKUP_AREA}/level${LEVEL}/${device}.archive

	# Remove existing backup at the same level from last week
	rm -f $DUMP_FILE $ARCHIVE_FILE

	dump -${LEVEL} -f $DUMP_FILE -A $ARCHIVE_FILE -q -u -z1 /dev/${device} && echo `date` "$device backup succeeded" || bail "Problem backing up $device" 

done

From serendipity at pobox.com  Tue Nov 25 12:08:01 2003
From: serendipity at pobox.com (Brian Quade)
Date: Tue Nov 25 12:08:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] sudoers confusion
Message-ID: <3FC3B590.9060809@pobox.com>

I am setting up a couple of machines with users and permissions, but 
after reading the sudoers man page I am confused about which hosts the 
sudoers file affects.  For example, as far as I understand, sudoers is a 
local file for that machine only, not a system-wide server file that 
provides information for the whole network like named does.  But the man 
page has an example that shows permissions for many machines on a 
network.  How can a sudoers file on one machine control permissions for 
other machines on the network?  Isn't it true that if I try to execute 
some commands on another host, it would be that other host that 
determines my permissions, not the sudoers file on my machine or any 
other host on the network?  I guess my main question is: Does a sudoers 
file only determine permissions for users executing commands on the host 
where the sudoers file exists, or does it only determine permissions for 
users who are logged into the host where the sudoers file is, or can it 
determine permissions for machines that the user is neither logged into 
nor trying to execute commands on?




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Nov 25 12:46:01 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue Nov 25 12:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] sudoers confusion
In-Reply-To: <3FC3B590.9060809@pobox.com>
References: <3FC3B590.9060809@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <17361-48843@sneakemail.com>

On Tue, 25 Nov 2003, Brian Quade serendipity-at-pobox.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> How can a sudoers file on one machine control permissions for
> other machines on the network?

It can't.  More below...

> Isn't it true that if I try to execute some commands on another host, it
> would be that other host that determines my permissions, not the sudoers
> file on my machine or any other host on the network?

Yes.

> I guess my main question is: Does a sudoers file only determine
> permissions for users executing commands on the host where the sudoers
> file exists,

Yes.

> or does it only determine permissions for users who are logged into the
> host where the sudoers file is,

Isn't this the same question as before or did I misunderstand you?  Sudo
only controls execution of commands so the login vs. execute distinction
doesn't apply.

> or can it determine permissions for machines that the user is neither
> logged into nor trying to execute commands on?

Only if the sudoers file exists on that system too.

The reason hostnames exist in the sudoers file is so the exact same file
can be copied to many systems.  If the hostname entry in the sudoers file
doesn't match the local host name, that entry is ignored.

For example in this hypothetical sudoers file:

----- /etc/sudoers
bigadmin ALL=(ALL) ALL
midadmin host01,host02=(ALL) ALL
smalladmin host01=(ALL) ALL
-----

This file has been coped to /etc/sudoers on host01, host02, and host03.

On host01, all three users can run any command as any user.  On host02,
only midadmin and bigadmin can run any command.  Smalladmin has no
capabilities at all when running sudo on host02.  On host03, only bigadmin
can run commands via sudo.

The sudo documentation does a poor job of explaining this.

  -- Steve

On Tue, 25 Nov 2003, Josh Orchard josh-at-emediatedesigns.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Gives that there is about 1 in 2.6B^7 chance. I can live with that.

Backups aren't about guarding against double failure-- they're about
guarding against the far-more-probable accidents that RAID can't help with
such as file deletion, file overwrites, program bugs, accidental "mkfs",
etc.

At the barest minimum, you should copy /home onto CD-Rs or to another
system "occassionally".  How much effort would it take to recreate
everything vs. the effort to make a copy once in a while?

If you think you can recreate everything, perhaps just a "find" list of
all your files E-mailed to yourself from time to time would be enough.  At
least this way you'd know what had to be re-created.  ;-)

  -- Steve

From boro at borosenclave.com  Wed Nov 26 00:03:02 2003
From: boro at borosenclave.com (borodimer)
Date: Wed Nov 26 00:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables
References: <LAW12-F15fTRHvJ7uwt00014e77@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <000901c3b3f3$ae283000$0d000d0a@borolan>

You should double check that ip forwarding is enabled.  `cat
/proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward`  If is it disabled, equal to zero (0), then
do a `echo "1" > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward` to enable it.  It is
generally a good idea to throw that line into your firewall script or in
your sysctl.conf set "net.ipv4.ip_forward = 1".

If you already have ip forwarding enabled, then please disreguard this
message.

Thanks,

  Phil Schultz
  Head of SalemLUG
  www.salemlug.org

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Nov 26 06:50:03 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed Nov 26 06:50:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Promise drive controller
Message-ID: <20031126144827.GA5316@gate.kl-ic.com>

I have had hit-or-miss results with the Promise card.  I am using
the ATA-133 card, the ones that Maxtor rebrands and includes with
the big drives.  These cards work on one of my machines, and not
for the other.  I had to modify my grub.conf:

...
kernel /boot/vmlinuz-2.4.20-19.9 ro root=/dev/hde1
...

I am on the road, and have poor access to the machines, so if you
are still having problems in another week, contact me and we'll
debug this stuff.  

Keith

On Tue, 2003-11-25 at 23:45, Matthias A wrote:
> I'm trying to use my webserver as a router, as well. I've put a second 
> network card in, and verified that both of them work.
> However, I can't seem to get iptables to do NAT.  
> input/forward/output/prerouting/postrouting in all tables is configured to 
> 'accept', and the 'nat' table has a rule "-A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j 
> MASQUERADE". However, this doesn't seem to actually do any IP masquerading.
> Is this obviously incorrect?

As somebody else pointed out, you need to be sure to make sure ip
forwarding is enabled.  If it is, and that isn't the problem, it's
really a little difficult to just see one line of an iptables rule and
diagnose a problem.  It would be a lot easier to see the whole script
(assuming you're using a script... if not, iptables-save) to see if
there are any big issues with it.

Rob

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Nov 26 09:41:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Nov 26 09:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RAID 1 suggestions
In-Reply-To: <7385-43007@sneakemail.com>
References: <4437.216.99.218.67.1069737763.squirrel@sautez.com>
 <1069779263.846.78.camel@fastlinux.homenet> <7385-43007@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <519-98201@sneakemail.com>

On Tue, 25 Nov 2003, Steve Bonds 1s7k8uhcd001-at-sneakemail.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I've not had any problems putting boot, root, and even swap on a
> software RAID partition with RedHat 7 or newer.  The /boot partition
> needs separate LILO and/or GRUB entries for each half of the mirror for
> easier booting when one disk dies, but otherwise software mirroring is
> quite straightforward.

I should add that there is one problem I see often with the software
RAID-1.  Every now and then, for no apparent reason, a single disk
partition will be dropped out of the mirrored pair.  The only indication
is a message in syslog and the /proc/mdstat now shows "[U_]" instead of
the expected "[UU]".  I have a cron script that monitors this, but it can
be quite the annoyance.

I see no I/O errors logged at the time and SMART says all is well on the
drive.  It's also generally just a single partition, not the whole drive,
so I doubt it's a hardware problem.

To get the partition back I just:

raidhotadd /dev/mdX /dev/hdXX

Then wait for the resync to complete.

  -- Steve

From serendipity at pobox.com  Wed Nov 26 09:50:29 2003
From: serendipity at pobox.com (Brian Quade)
Date: Wed Nov 26 09:50:29 2003
Subject: [PLUG] sudoers confusion
References: <3FC3B590.9060809@pobox.com> <17361-48843@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <3FC4E6BD.8030304@pobox.com>

Using the same sudoers file for every host on a network seems like a bad 
approach to me.  It's just like the DNS problem.  DNS servers exist 
because static hosts files are not adequate to answer queries for a 
whole network because they become outdated over time.  But sudoers is 
not a server, it is just a static local file, so it doesn't really 
provide information for the entire network, only for individual hosts. 
 So if sudoers permissions change, then the sys admin would have no 
choice but to copy the global sudoers file to every host on the network 
again.  This just puts a bunch on information on each host, most of 
which has nothing to do with those hosts.  I can't see any benefit to 
that.  Does anyone know of a reason why I might not want to create a 
unique suoders file for every host on my network and maintain them 
separately?



Steve Bonds wrote:

>On Tue, 25 Nov 2003, Brian Quade serendipity-at-pobox.com |PDX Linux| wrote:
>
>>How can a sudoers file on one machine control permissions for
>>other machines on the network?
>>
>
>It can't.  More below...
>
>>Isn't it true that if I try to execute some commands on another host, it
>>would be that other host that determines my permissions, not the sudoers
>>file on my machine or any other host on the network?
>>
>
>Yes.
>
>>I guess my main question is: Does a sudoers file only determine
>>permissions for users executing commands on the host where the sudoers
>>file exists,
>>
>
>Yes.
>
>>or does it only determine permissions for users who are logged into the
>>host where the sudoers file is,
>>
>
>Isn't this the same question as before or did I misunderstand you?  Sudo
>only controls execution of commands so the login vs. execute distinction
>doesn't apply.
>
>>or can it determine permissions for machines that the user is neither
>>logged into nor trying to execute commands on?
>>
>
>Only if the sudoers file exists on that system too.
>
>The reason hostnames exist in the sudoers file is so the exact same file
>can be copied to many systems.  If the hostname entry in the sudoers file
>doesn't match the local host name, that entry is ignored.
>
>For example in this hypothetical sudoers file:
>
>----- /etc/sudoers
>bigadmin ALL=(ALL) ALL
>midadmin host01,host02=(ALL) ALL
>smalladmin host01=(ALL) ALL
>-----
>
>This file has been coped to /etc/sudoers on host01, host02, and host03.
>
>On host01, all three users can run any command as any user.  On host02,
>only midadmin and bigadmin can run any command.  Smalladmin has no
>capabilities at all when running sudo on host02.  On host03, only bigadmin
>can run commands via sudo.
>
>The sudo documentation does a poor job of explaining this.
>
>  -- Steve
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

It is geared towards Apple users primarily. The way it works in iCal is 
that each of these things are subscriptions. You can un-check the ones 
that you don't want to view and unsubscribing is a matter of just 
hitting the delete key.  On other calendars, it doesn't work as

both the iBooks and PowerBooks. Since X11 is included as well as fink, 
I have access to over 3000 unix apps and pretty much use my iBook 
exclusively. Panther is a very nice OS and has a ton of things that 
make me more productive. I would be happy to go more into those with 
anyone that is interested. Apple desktops are nice as well but they are 
considerably more and I like the mobility. the 12" iBooks with a g4 and 
combo drive ( cd-r/dvd drive) starts at just $1099 which is rather 
reasonable for a laptop.

On Wed, 26 Nov 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Groan! Lookie here:
>    <http://www.cnn.com/2003/TECH/ptech/11/26/master.term.reut/index.html>
>
>   What the LA County PC police seem to not understand is that hard
> drives, cdrom drives and others are not offended by being labled
> "master" and "slave". As a matter of fact, some like not having the
> responsibility of being first.

Well, it doesn't matter, of course, whether the participants like it or
not.  It isn't about whether the drives are offended.  It's about people
being uncomfortable with some words.  (I have a friend who is perfectly
comfortable with the label "pervert" for her lifestyle.  It's apparently
used frequently in her particular community.  That doesn't mean it's an
appropriate word to use in every context to describe her.  And it still
makes other people uncomfortable that aren't being labelled.)

Yeah, it's a great display of ignorance to be offended with the words in
this case... a bit like King James changing the word "slave" to "servant"
in most of his rendition of the Holy Bible.  It's an attempt to appease
those with limited understanding of the situation.

But to quote the actual article:

<quote src="above url">
"I do understand that this term has been an industry standard for years
and years and this is nothing more than a plea to vendors to see what they
can do," he said. "It appears that some folks have taken this a little too
literally."

Sandoval said that he had already rejected a suggestion that the county
stop buying all equipment carrying the "master" and "slave" labels and had
no intention of enforcing a ban on such terms with suppliers.
</quote>

So that pretty much sums up the position without taking some knee-jerk,
hateful stance.  They had complaints and forwarded them.

Now, the truly crazy bit is here:
<quote src="same url above">
In June, the Los Angeles city council unanimously passed a law requiring
that any companies doing business with the city disclose profits they may
have made from slavery in the 19th Century. In 2000, the council supported
federal legislation seeking reparations for descendants of slaves.
</quote>

How on EARTH can they possibly estimate the profits reaped from slavery in
the 19th century?

The effects of 19th (and 18th and 17th etc.... hell, 20th and 21st)
century slavery are so broad and deep, I don't think there's a single
company around (whether they existed back then or not) that hasn't
profitted from slavery.

It's kooky to even ask anyone to disclose that kind of information.

Slavery was just early corporate welfare.

J.

From Anderson.Robert at menlolog.com  Wed Nov 26 13:37:02 2003
From: Anderson.Robert at menlolog.com (Anderson, Robert H - MWT)
Date: Wed Nov 26 13:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] sudoers confusion
Message-ID: <25E622D843625C40BE0EEC150B437C1B2CCEA9@cnfqe029.cnf.prod.cnf.com>

In many environments there are several boxes that the same group of users
use for, say, development lifesyscle. You might have a dev, test, and
production box, all with the same sudoers file. If you version your sudoers
file, which is a good idea, you would benefit from having it all in one file
because you would have one place to look for things and one place to make
changes. You could keep your severs in sync with this file by implementing
an automated deployment process. If you use CVS, perhaps you would use the
loginfo file in CVSROOT to kick off the automated deployment process each
time the sudoers file is updated.

-Rob Anderson

>-----Original Message-----
>From: Brian Quade [mailto:serendipity at pobox.com] 
>Sent: Wednesday, November 26, 2003 9:46 AM
>To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
>Subject: Re: [PLUG] sudoers confusion
>
>
>Using the same sudoers file for every host on a network seems 
>like a bad 
>approach to me.  It's just like the DNS problem.  DNS servers exist 
>because static hosts files are not adequate to answer queries for a 
>whole network because they become outdated over time.  But sudoers is 
>not a server, it is just a static local file, so it doesn't really 
>provide information for the entire network, only for individual hosts. 
> So if sudoers permissions change, then the sys admin would have no 
>choice but to copy the global sudoers file to every host on 
>the network 
>again.  This just puts a bunch on information on each host, most of 
>which has nothing to do with those hosts.  I can't see any benefit to 
>that.  Does anyone know of a reason why I might not want to create a 
>unique suoders file for every host on my network and maintain them 
>separately?
>
>
>
>Steve Bonds wrote:
>
>>On Tue, 25 Nov 2003, Brian Quade serendipity-at-pobox.com |PDX Linux| 
>>wrote:
>>
>>>How can a sudoers file on one machine control permissions for other 
>>>machines on the network?
>>>
>>
>>It can't.  More below...
>>
>>>Isn't it true that if I try to execute some commands on 
>another host, 
>>>it would be that other host that determines my permissions, not the 
>>>sudoers file on my machine or any other host on the network?
>>>
>>
>>Yes.
>>
>>>I guess my main question is: Does a sudoers file only determine 
>>>permissions for users executing commands on the host where 
>the sudoers 
>>>file exists,
>>>
>>
>>Yes.
>>
>>>or does it only determine permissions for users who are logged into 
>>>the host where the sudoers file is,
>>>
>>
>>Isn't this the same question as before or did I misunderstand you?  
>>Sudo only controls execution of commands so the login vs. execute 
>>distinction doesn't apply.
>>
>>>or can it determine permissions for machines that the user 
>is neither 
>>>logged into nor trying to execute commands on?
>>>
>>
>>Only if the sudoers file exists on that system too.
>>
>>The reason hostnames exist in the sudoers file is so the exact same 
>>file can be copied to many systems.  If the hostname entry in the 
>>sudoers file doesn't match the local host name, that entry is ignored.
>>
>>For example in this hypothetical sudoers file:
>>
>>----- /etc/sudoers
>>bigadmin ALL=(ALL) ALL
>>midadmin host01,host02=(ALL) ALL
>>smalladmin host01=(ALL) ALL
>>-----
>>
>>This file has been coped to /etc/sudoers on host01, host02, 
>and host03.
>>
>>On host01, all three users can run any command as any user.  
>On host02, 
>>only midadmin and bigadmin can run any command.  Smalladmin has no 
>>capabilities at all when running sudo on host02.  On host03, only 
>>bigadmin can run commands via sudo.
>>
>>The sudo documentation does a poor job of explaining this.
>>
>>  -- Steve
>>
>>_______________________________________________
>>PLUG mailing list
>>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org 
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>>
>
>
>
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Wed Nov 26 17:44:02 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Wed Nov 26 17:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: iptables - 4 interfaces
In-Reply-To: <20031127005619.GD5555@subtend.net>
References: <20031127005619.GD5555@subtend.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.53.0311261738340.23814@antares.mpcu.com>

On Wed, 26 Nov 2003, Kris wrote:

> Speaking of iptables, does anyone have a script that handles 4 interfaces?
> Right now I'm in the process of duplicating the commands from the DMZ on a 3
> interface script to incorporate a 4th one.

IMO, fwbuilder is the right tool for this.  4 interfaces is alot and no 
matter how good a iptables wiz you are,  it's much too easy to fat finger 
a config file.  And with fwbuilder you can comment the config file, xml 
based, to aid in the future audit of your firewall rule set.


www.fwbuilder.org.  Requires X and some specific libraries, but a very
nice product and the author is responsive to all queries via the
mail-list.  I run fwbuilder from central host and scp the resulting
scripts to the firewalls that I manage.

From root at loraksus.org  Wed Nov 26 20:15:02 2003
From: root at loraksus.org (Karol Kulaga)
Date: Wed Nov 26 20:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT:*&^%Faxes
In-Reply-To: <1069866399.28583.30.camel@apollo.spears.org>

Get a roll of black construction paper, tape it in a loop in your fax
machine and hit send before you go to sleep. Or fax several hundred
pure black pages from your computer.
Now, although pure black is nice, you can be creative.

Several hundred pages of

====FAX=DIAGNOSTICS====
I/O Error 13.2453.2
Unplug and call for service.

work very well, as do informative pages about federal junk fax law and
the more immature stuff - schoolgirls on copiers and the such.

After making them spend $40+ for toner and a box of paper, generally
they leave you alone. I think there is a blacklist that a lot of the
fax spammers use, and doing something like this gets you on there ;)

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Thu Nov 27 10:35:02 2003

References: <20031127182124.20178.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1069958633.6685.74.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Thu, 2003-11-27 at 10:21, Robert Kopp wrote:
> I had this problem once earlier just after installing
> Linux, but I don't remember how I solved it.It starts
> a bunch of things.
> 
> Starting xinetd                   OK
> Starting sendmail
> 
> Starting console mouse services   OK 
> 
> When reaching sendmail, it hangs for a long
> time--probably two or three minutes. 

My guess, with problems like hanging services, is DNS isn't set up
properly... your machine may not have a resolvable hostname or something
similar.

> I do not use
> sendmail, so presumably either removing it or not
> attempting to start it is the answer. Could anyone
> give me advice? 

If you don't use sendmail, why is it starting up when you boot your
box?  :-)

I would suggest stopping sendmail from loading itself when you boot up -
the hows of that are dependent upon the linux distribution you're
running.  If it's Gentoo, "rc-update del sendmail default" should do the
trick.  If it's Slackware "chmod -x /etc/rc.d/rc.sendmail" should do the
trick.  If it's something else... have fun.  :-)

Happy Thanksgiving

Rob

From michael at robinson-west.com  Thu Nov 27 14:05:02 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Thu Nov 27 14:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Graylisting in Postfix.... Teaching evolution to dump spam...
Message-ID: <1069970407.27751.78.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I'm using spamassassin, but I put suspected spam 
in a folder because there can be false positives.  
Thing is, if there are definite spam indicators, 
can't spamassassin send those messages with a 
different header than it does possible spam?  
I'm thinking of fake outlook, address forged, 
and improper html in message.  The only thing 
I would add to having those messages trashed 
is storing any real address they came from to 
deny any inbound connection in the future.  I 
can look at this list for any address that 
shouldn't be blocked later and use the phone
in most cases if it's someone I need to be 
IM'ed by.

How do I stop any malformed messages or definite 
spam from originating at my server and going out?
Another check that should be done is every 
outgoing message should be checked for sensitive
system passwords, etc.

It's ridiculous to look at all suspected spam 
in evolution because a lot of it is just plain 
obvious.  Can I pass my mail to something before
evolution gets it after spamassassin does?  It
would be nice to run it through a filter 
that catches the spam score being at fifteen, 
etc. I want to keep definite spam out of the 
spam folder in evolution because it does take
time to manually inspect stuff.

Can mimedefang be used with Postfix?  

How can Postfix be set up to do graylisting?

A trick I'm considering is a dual MTA mail
system.  The first MTA that gets email is
a special type.  This MTA only forwards
a special message with the header of a message
it wants to forward inside and a reply to 
address that will essentially subscribe the 
recipient to that message if they want it.  
For mailing lists, this might be a pain,
though exceptions for those can always be 
looked into.  Considering some messages are 
nondescript traps that flash you when you 
investigate, requiring that the intent be 
in the subject and header is probably 
reasonable.

Does anyone know how to mine the real addresses
IM's are coming from and build a database of
all addresses with user associations that my
email server deals with?  Having the information
can help with whitelisting and blacklisting 
efforts.

-- 
-----------------------------
Michael C. Robinson

Associates of General Studies 
PCC March 2003.

On Thu, 2003-11-27 at 14:00, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> I'm using spamassassin, but I put suspected spam 
> in a folder because there can be false positives.  
> Thing is, if there are definite spam indicators, 
> can't spamassassin send those messages with a 
> different header than it does possible spam?  

I put everything over score 8 into a folder that I never look at.
Between 5 and 8 goes into a folder that I do look at once a week. Not
too much in there and almost never a false positive. 

That way you don't have to go through the mass amount of all spam mails.
- Holger

> If I am wrong please let me know before too long, in case I mess
> something up.

If you can verify they go together, you're not doing the wrong thing.

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu Nov 27 22:23:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Thu Nov 27 22:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel headers
In-Reply-To: <20031128024121.GF20291@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
References: <20031127150450.GC9192@brian.brianandkellyderr.com> <1069952770.6685.40.camel@dell.linux.box> <20031128024121.GF20291@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
Message-ID: <3FC6E98A.6040106@pacifier.com>

Brian Derr wrote:
> On Thu, Nov 27, 2003 at 09:06:10AM -0800, AthlonRob wrote:
> 
>>Reinstall the kernel-headers package...
>>
>>You're supposed to have /usr/include/linux match up with what glibc, et
>>al, was compiled against, not what the kernel-flavor-of-the-day happens
>>to be.  :-)
> 
> 
> Ok, that being said I have upgraded glibc several times since I had
> kernel 2.4.19 or whatever it was.  Should I install the latest
> kernel-headers package then?  I'm banking on yes so I'll do that before
> I get a reply.  Guess I'm just answering my own question out loud.  :-)
> 
> If I am wrong please let me know before too long, in case I mess
> something up.

Good question.  Couldn't sleep without knowing more...  Check this page from 
Linux From Scratch, to quote

http://www.faqs.org/docs/linux_scratch/chapter06/kernel.html

------------------
6.11.3. Why we copy the kernel headers and don't symlink them

In the past it was common practice to symlink the /usr/include/{linux,asm} 
directories to /usr/src/linux/include/{linux,asm}. This was a bad practice, 
as the following extract from a post by Linus Torvalds to the Linux Kernel 
Mailing List points out:

I would suggest that people who compile new kernels should:

  - not have a single symbolic link in sight (except the one that the
    kernel build itself sets up, namely the "linux/include/asm" symlink
    that is only used for the internal kernel compile itself)

And yes, this is what I do. My /usr/src/linux still has the old 2.2.13
header files, even though I haven't run a 2.2.13 kernel in a _loong_
time. But those headers were what glibc was compiled against, so those
headers are what matches the library object files.

And this is actually what has been the suggested environment for at
least the last five years. I don't know why the symlink business keeps
on living on, like a bad zombie. Pretty much every distribution still
has that broken symlink, and people still remember that the linux
sources should go into "/usr/src/linux" even though that hasn't been
true in a _loong_ time.

------------------


So, presumably when a distro releases an updated glibc package they may 
(should?) still compile it against the initial kernel release that they 
provided.

IOW, if FishHeadLinux 8.0 comes with kernel 2.4.20-1, then no matter how 
many times they issue a new glibc package, it will always be compiled 
against 2.4.20-1.  Even if they release kernel-2.4.20-23.

Then FishHeadLinux 9.0 comes out with a new kernel and new glibc compiled 
against that.

--
Kyle Accardi
a little full of turkey




From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Thu Nov 27 22:26:02 2003
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)

Subject: [PLUG] fedora apt-get upgrade
In-Reply-To: <86wu9lt490.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0311272233001.21122-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On 27 Nov 2003, Russell Senior wrote:

>I installed and setup apt-get in a fedora core 1 install I've been
>playing with.  I just did my first apt-get update, which seemed to go
>fine and apt-get upgrade which went fine until the end:
<snip>
>   Unknown signature /var/cache/apt/archives/strace_4.5.1-1_i386.rpm: (SHA1) DSA sha1 md5 (GPG) NOT OK (MISSING KEYS: GPG#4f2a6fd2) 
>   E: Error: 0 unsigned packages
>   6 unknown signatures
>   0 illegal/corrupted signatures
>
>So, where do I put the missing keys and where do I get them from?

Looks like you are using apt packages that have not been updated
to include the fedora keys. GPG#4f2a6fd2 is the Fedora key:
http://pgp.mit.edu:11371/pks/lookup?search=0x4f2a6fd2&op=index


This should fix it for you:

  rpm --import /usr/share/rhn/RPM-GPG-KEY*

-Eric

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Thu Nov 27 23:55:02 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Thu Nov 27 23:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] fedora apt-get upgrade
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0311272233001.21122-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0311272351340.11915-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

This is the best solution. Most repositories have their keys available,
here are some more:
rpm --import http://www.fedora.us/FEDORA-GPG-KEY
rpm --import http://rpm.livna.org/RPM-LIVNA-GPG-KEY
rpm --import http://freshrpms.net/packages/RPM-GPG-KEY.txt
rpm --import http://dag.wieers.com/packages/RPM-GPG-KEY.dag.txt
rpm --import http://atrpms.physik.fu-berlin.de/RPM-GPG-KEY.atrpms

However. every now and then you run into a package which does not have the
right key, in which case you can disable key checking in apt.conf
