It has come to my attention that this list is highly 
abused.  Certain people including Jeme and even Carla 
and another guy have a tendency to flame.  There may 
be others as well who do this.  It's at a minimum 
impolite at worst being very distracting and even 
spiteful at times.  I don't know where some people 
are coming from, but since when do you take a non
professional attitude to a list that's supposed to 
be about legitimate Linux tech questions as opposed 
to Jeme's morality or Carla's lack of tact?  Is it 
unreasonable to ask people to censor their own 
language and above all avoid addressing anyone on 
here with an attitude of your nuts or your delusional?

More than this is needed, if anyone goes out of line 
with offensive non Linux tech questions it either 
needs to be regulated by the list administrator or 
the people who are deciding to flame themselves.  
People aren't regulating themselves, even going on 
plug-talk thinking I might calm some of this down I 
found I was totally naive to even try.

Would it be that hard to block a person for a short
period or make a subscription switch to plug-talk?
I hope a free for all where people can come 
with an attitude of show no respect for anyone else 
defending themselves when someone complains, instead 
of trying to be accomodating, isn't the permanent 
norm.  A bayesian filter on this mailing list, applied
to all subscribers equally, should be able to put a 
stop to this.  This censorship in the long run, if 
done non preferentially with proper foresight, has 
the potential to increase the list's value.

I am discouraged that Jeme chose such an off
topic post again that is so highly controversial  
It lowers the discussion even if Jeme gets the 
benefit of the doubt that he's simply stubborn 
about using language that's abusive because 
he's "special."

Not to single out Jeme, the same should apply 
to anyone who wants to do this.  It's a shame 
if the community doesn't have the will to 
address abuse as a whole instead of addressing
it on an individual basis.  Unfortunately,
I am having a hard time with all the you're
a nut cracks including Carla's your a lunatic
post which totally surprised me.  This should
be my community and I should find a way to
make being on at least this list work, but
I'm just barely in the mood to do that
because of the abuse.

Sometimes I wonder if there are many out there 
getting my posts where I only notice three to 
ten posters to my threads on this list that is 
supposed to have close to 150+ people on it.
If the linux community fragments, one thing 
frankly all of us should recognize as a 
possibility, where will Linux and other 
OSS be?  Unity is important for Linux and 
OSS.  That which divides threatens the 
talent pool.
  
Linux communities must find the will to put 
aside individual political beefs, religious 
beefs, anything else that's a beef, and 
other prejudices to be most affective.  

The one up man ship when something goes 
where it should doesn't help with tech
problems though it's awfully hard for 
people to stop without a moderator.
This is why a good samaritan is sometimes 
the person who breaks up a fight :-)

I hope this is a challenge to those who
read it.  It shouldn't be the fuse for
another flame thread.  If it is, 
good bye Ed, Kyle, Mike, and everyone
else who has helped me at one time or
another.

> 
> 
> A large problem with moderation is agreeing on what needs to be blocked.
> If you:
> 	a) block email from posters that, in your view, persistently 
> 	abuse this forum
> 	b) ensure that your posts don't abuse the forum
> 
> You'll find the list a much more pleasant place to participate.  Because
> you will have screened out off topic posts.  
> 
> This is not hiding under a rock.  This is taking direct and concrete 
> action to fulfill your desire to have this list conform to your desires.
> 
> I would disagree that you are not part of the problem.  Your seeming 
> inability to read text without injecting non-existent meaning and 
> disposition to enter long, wandering messages does go off topic. 

Hostile sound byte offering no path to compromise or truce.
This is not a community approach, it's not even a fair one.

It wouldn't cost too much too have the list moderated from 
the top if the community really came together to support 
and guide this.  With moderation at the top, someone who 
gets upset one day is more likely to post successfully 
later if a moderator intervenes to spare others.  That 
way, there is the maximum discourse between the maximum 
number of people.  It also wins from the standpoint of 
watchfullness.  Where is the interest in having spam 
dealt with where it starts?  People kill filing the 
posts they don't like based on who posts run the 
risk of missing parts of threads.  It also discourages 
listening to people who ask questions over those who 
answer them, a long term growth barrier.  If the long 
spam threads have proven anything, it's that individual 
filtering doesn't address the problems on this list
adequately.  Filtering needs to be wisely and fairly 
applied to the list itself at the top, not at the 
level of users mailboxes.  This is not operating as a
community if people are at each others throats.

From freyley at gmx.net  Fri Nov 28 22:28:02 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Fri Nov 28 22:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] dvd playback sync
Message-ID: <1070087214.5417.61.camel@localhost>

Hi,

I've had a lot of trouble with playing dvds. The video and sound seem to
get out of sync fairly quickly (10-15 minutes into it) and deteriorate
over the course of watching. I've tried a whole bunch of things, and
it's gotten somewhat better, but still problematic.

Here's the system:

amd athlon t-bird 1100 mhz 
512 MB PC133 DIMM
Matrox G200 8MB AGP video
onboard AC97 sound
NEC DVD Drive, unknown speed

I had an older ATI video card in there for a while, and the upgrade to
the matrox g200 was very helpful. I also started using the 2.6.0-testX
series of kernels, and that helped a lot too, especially with ALSA.

I could upgrade the video card again, try to find a g400, but I'm kinda
skeptical that's the issue. I checked with hdparm and found that the dvd
drive was responding at 2 MB/s. Turning on dma and 32-bit io (-c1, -d1)
brought that up to 2.85 MB/s, but I can't help but think that this may
be one of the problems. Anyone know anything about getting a dvd drive
to go faster? (or do I just need a newer dvd drive?) The actual bus is
ATA/133/100/66/33 and I've gotten up to 22 MB/s off an IDE hard drive,
and there's nothing else on this channel, so it's not the bus.

Also, is that speed the bottleneck? I've been told that PC133 memory is
just too slow for that kind of playback, but I'm skeptical of that. I
was told the sound driver was the problem, but with the 2.6 kernels
comes ALSA, so that shouldn't be too much of a problem anymore.

Thoughts?

Jeff

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Nov 28 22:41:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri Nov 28 22:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The list needs moderation...
In-Reply-To: <1070066043.29195.149.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1070008591.29197.79.camel@goose.robinson-west.com> <20031128164529.GE504@patch.com> <1070052454.29197.114.camel@goose.robinson-west.com> <20031128220729.GA2997@patch.com> <1070066043.29195.149.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <20031129064037.GF16517@sthelens.dimstar.net>

> It wouldn't cost too much too have the list moderated from 
> the top if the community really came together to support 
> and guide this.

"WHO" do you suggest lead this effort? Plug is a free form group, has
been as long as I have been a member. I've been a member for almost 5
years. 

What is considered off-topic is a moving target, and changes daily. An
example of this is the spam discussion. Some felt that the whole thing
was off topic, others felt it should get it's own sub-list, and others
felt it should just go on as it is. 

My point is that plug is not an organization like you expect it to be.
This community is just a bunch of people that believe they can help
one-another. In some cases, these like minded people have vastly
different views on how certain things should be done. e.g. Vi vs Emacs.

If one person is moderating the list, we'll end up with someone
moderated that others disagree with. If it's a commitee, we'll end up
with the same thing, plus the commitee probably fighting amongst itself.

All of this leads to the conclusion that leaving what comes into your
email box up to you is the best way to handle it.

Consequently, we end up with suggestions such as you have already
received to write your own inbox rules to send messages from people who
offend you to whatever bit bucket you wish.

In other words, take care of your own problem, because others on this
list feel it would be harmed by moderation.

Another point made by others is YOU need to show a little self
restraint. Posting a reply to an off-topic thread is every bit as bad as
the original post. You are simply perpetuating something that you are
now claiming needs to be resolved.

-- 
Russ Johnson

On Fri, 2003-11-28 at 22:26, Jeff Schwaber wrote:

> I've had a lot of trouble with playing dvds. The video and sound seem to
> get out of sync fairly quickly (10-15 minutes into it) and deteriorate
> over the course of watching. I've tried a whole bunch of things, and

Well, you already did most all of the things I would have suggested
here... switch to alsa being the first one... getting a preemptable
kernel being number two.

Next up - what are you utilizing to play your DVDs in the software
realm?  MPlayer?  If you aren't using mplayer, start now.  :-)

If you are using MPlayer, make sure you're using 1.0pre2 or CVS.

You know about using +/- to change the audio as you're watching a video,
right?

I found I had problems with OSS emulated DVD playing software getting
out of sync when watching a DVD after twenty minutes or so... I found
recompiling the software (ogle and xine at the time) with Alsa support
solved that problem.

Have fun.

It says instead of coming together as a community and having the
opportunity to work things out so that the largest number of people
can work together affectively, excuses that that only leads to 
fighting will reign instead.  Instead of kill filing it would be
refreshing to hear someone else for once argue for a more diplomatic
approach.  If there is no will to build community, why is this
called the Portland Linux/Unix group anyways?  I simply don't buy
it that a committee would only fight.  I also don't buy the idea
that it's impossible to have a vote through this list in order to
set reasonable moderator standards.  As far as discrimination,
discrimination along with plain old anger right now is rampant.  
This is one of the reasons why so many people defend themselves.  
To a large extent, this is feeding into off topic threads.

to debate whether or not moderation should happen to the list 
itself.

to say, "hey any out there listening to Jeme, I don't agree 
with his off topic post showing up on here."  Do I want to be
associated with this list?  Not if Jeme's message and other
messages I don't agree with fill it up with no one moderating
for those who are vulnerable.  It's a warped view of the world
that's being created which itself arguably gives the list a 
bad reputation.  How does much of what gets on here fits in 
with helping people use Linux?  I don't agree with this ultra 
liberal view that a community should not take responsibility 
to keep a discussion list it hosts within it's mission 
statement.  Especially considering the nature of much of the 
off topic stuff that is hitting plug now,the last point takes
on a real urgency.  Libraries have standards of conduct for
patrons, is this such an alien concept?

From serendipity at pobox.com  Sat Nov 29 07:34:02 2003
From: serendipity at pobox.com (Brian Quade)
Date: Sat Nov 29 07:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] sudoers still not working
Message-ID: <3FC8BB45.7040304@pobox.com>

I have the following extremely simple sudoers file (comments removed):

root        ALL = (ALL) ALL
admin    ALL = (ALL) ALL

admin is a login with its own private group.  I get no grammar errors 
after running visudo using the -s parameter.  But when I login as admin 
and try to run groupadd, I get "command not found".  I can login as root 
and run groupadd just fine.  I tried rebooting the system, but that 
didn't work either.  Has anyone worked with sudoers enough to know what 
else I have to do to give a user full access to the system?  Shouldn't 
this just be a 2-minute, one-liner change to a text file?

Eventually, I was hoping to get sudoers working well enough to figure 
out how to give the mysterious nfsnobody user full access to my exported 
directory.  Depending on which user creates files and directories in my 
exported nfs directory, users sometimes can not see directories or files 
because they are owned by a different user.  I thought sudoers would be 
the place to allow all nfs users to see and execute everything in that 
directory.




From grishnav at egosurf.net  Sat Nov 29 09:31:01 2003
From: grishnav at egosurf.net (Grish)
Date: Sat Nov 29 09:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] sudoers still not working
In-Reply-To: <3FC8BB45.7040304@pobox.com>
References: <3FC8BB45.7040304@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <3FC8D783.7050409@egosurf.net>

Brian Quade wrote:

 > But when I login as admin and try to run groupadd, I get "command
 > not found".


groupadd probably isn't in your normal user path.

Try something like:

sudo /usr/sbin/groupadd

If you don't know where it is, do a find / -name groupadd 2>/dev/null

If that works, you can do a

PATH=$PATH:/sbin:/usr/sbin:/usr/local/sbin:[ . . . ]

On 29 Nov 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

>Because people are told to moderate themselves, it makes sense 
>to debate whether or not moderation should happen to the list 
>itself.

PLUG is a loose-nit group that has a wide degree of variance in
experience, opinions, and expectations. The only way we are all
going to get along is to accept these differences. We've managed
to get along with each other, more or less, for the last 10 years.


Moderating the list so that it aligns with a particular set of
members' views, morals, political leanings, emacs vs vi, etc, is
a bad deal. 

I disagree with a number of the people who post on PLUG. But
that is part of what keeps PLUG interesting to me. If everyone
here was exactly like me, I would quickly get bored and leave.


The alternative is that we self moderate. Occasionally someone
will step out of line, that is the price we pay to keep this
an open forum. Freedom always comes at a price.

If PLUG is too free-wheeling, or you can't tolerate the opinions
of some of the posters, there is always the freedom to vote
with your feet. There are a million other Linux/open source/free
software forums.


-Eric

> 
> IOW, if FishHeadLinux 8.0 comes with kernel 2.4.20-1, then no matter how

> 
> Then FishHeadLinux 9.0 comes out with a new kernel and new glibc compiled 
> against that.

So, in other words I need to find out what kernel version the current

From chris-plug at maybe.net  Sat Nov 29 10:18:01 2003
From: chris-plug at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Sat Nov 29 10:18:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel headers
In-Reply-To: <20031129181146.GK6731@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
References: <20031127150450.GC9192@brian.brianandkellyderr.com> <1069952770.6685.40.camel@dell.linux.box> <20031128024121.GF20291@brian.brianandkellyderr.com> <3FC6E98A.6040106@pacifier.com> <20031129181146.GK6731@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
Message-ID: <20031129181742.GE3005@maybe.net>

On Sat, Nov 29, 2003 at 01:11:46PM -0500, Brian Derr wrote:
> On Thu, Nov 27, 2003 at 10:22:02PM -0800, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> > sources should go into "/usr/src/linux" even though that hasn't been
> > true in a _loong_ time.
> 
> Is Linus telling us we shouldn't use /usr/src/linux to keep our kernel
> sources?

No, just that: a) if your distribution used a symlink (bad idea) from
/usr/include/linux to the kernel headers, it will require your source to
be in some canonical location. Which was historically /usr/src/linux.
Anymore, it shouldn't matter what directory you put it in. Feel free to
untar linux-2.4.23.tar.bz2 into /usr/local/src/clowns-need-food-1.0 if
you want.

> So, in other words I need to find out what kernel version the current
> glibc package was built against.  Hrmm, interesting...

Yup. Some distributions put the kernel headers for /usr/include/linux
into the glibc package. Some put a dependency from the glibc package to
a kernel-headers package (Debian just switched from the former to this).
Some leave you to your own devices, I suppose (bad distro, no cookie for
you).


-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sat Nov 29 10:37:01 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Nov 29 10:37:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] sudoers still not working
In-Reply-To: <3FC8BB45.7040304@pobox.com>
References: <3FC8BB45.7040304@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <1070131388.4589.64.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Sat, 2003-11-29 at 07:29, Brian Quade wrote:
>  But when I login as admin 
> and try to run groupadd, I get "command not found".  I can login as root 
> and run groupadd just fine.

'tis your path.

Here's what a friend did.  His PATH has /usr/local/bin before /usr/bin,
so he put a script called 'sudo' in /usr/local/bin, and left the real
'sudo' in /usr/bin.

#!/bin/bash
PATH=$PATH:/sbin:/usr/sbin:/usr/local/sbin /usr/bin/sudo $@

HTH....    Rob

> into the glibc package. Some put a dependency from the glibc package to
> a kernel-headers package (Debian just switched from the former to this).
> Some leave you to your own devices, I suppose (bad distro, no cookie for
> you).


In Red Hat land, /usr/include/linux is provided by glibc-kernelheaders and 
the file version.h in that dir indicates (in mine anyway)
#define UTS_RELEASE "2.4.9-9"

glibc-kernelheaders is at a different version number than the standard 
glibc-* stuff.

Also, gnu seemes to condradict Linus' preference.  From
http://www.gnu.org/manual/glibc-2.2.3/html_chapter/libc_36.html#SEC693

Special advice for Linux systems
...
"Then rename or delete `/usr/include', create a new `/usr/include', and make 
the usual symbolic links of `/usr/include/linux' and `/usr/include/asm' into 
the 2.2 kernel sources."

So who knows?

--
Kyle Accardi

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Nov 29 13:50:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat Nov 29 13:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] sudoers still not working
In-Reply-To: <200311291130.08211.aschlemm@comcast.net>
References: <3FC8BB45.7040304@pobox.com> <1070131388.4589.64.camel@dell.linux.box>
 <200311291130.08211.aschlemm@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0311291347140.32649@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 29 Nov 2003, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> Wouldn't you want /usr/local/bin before /usr/bin, etc?

I can see a school of thought (I'm not saying it exists) that would treat
/usr/local as the repository for custom versions of things that might
conflict with a shared /usr/bin or /bin, but I've never seen such a thing.

Usually, I've seen /usr/local used as a shared space for local executables
built by admin and non-admin staff for use in that environment.  That
meant, in these cases, that /usr/local was WRITABLE BY NON-ADMINS (usually
the staff group).  This opens you up to all kinds of trojans and
unintentional conflicts.

If /usr/local/bin precedes ANYTHING in your path, you should constantly
check to see if anything there has the same name as something from your
essential operating system packages (/sbin and /bin for sure, but probably
also /usr/sbin and /usr/bin).

Those are my bits.
J.

dealing with problems.  It's burying your head in the sand.

Mostly, it's arrogance and overkill.  You are assuming that this person
you've blocked can never have anything useful to present to you.  And you
are destroying your own ability to benefit from even the posts that you
don't automatically find offensive.

for themselves and you must do their filtering for them.  I reject that
statement as grossly elitist and paternalist.

help.  If they don't do that much, they cannot be helped.

liberal" (i.e. ultra free) is exactly the goal.

Policing and punishing and censoring are not alien concepts, they're just
extremely unpleasant.

On Sat, Nov 29, 2003 at 03:03:58AM -0800, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> It says instead of coming together as a community and having the
> opportunity to work things out so that the largest number of people
> can work together affectively, excuses that that only leads to 
> fighting will reign instead.

It's actually a more community-friendly approach than yours is.  Why?
It allows each user to decide for themselves.  Hardline moderation
doesn't help this.

> Instead of kill filing it would be refreshing to hear someone else
> for once argue for a more diplomatic approach.

Censorship isn't diplomatic.

> I simply don't buy it that a committee would only fight.

PLUG is a committee?  I thought it was a user group, more of a club
then a committee.

> I also don't buy the idea that it's impossible to have a vote
> through this list in order to set reasonable moderator standards.

Easy to get a good estimate of the likely vote outcome right now.
Just go through this thread, see how many supporters you have (unique
people, not posts) and see how many detractors.  It appears you're
out-voted.

> Kill filing does not offer any way to make amends nor any way
> to say, "hey any out there listening to Jeme, I don't agree 
> with his off topic post showing up on here." 

Nor should it have to.  You're supposed to keep the contents of your
killfile to yourself as to avoid influencing people to dodge killfiles
or making yourself look foolish publicly (I'm talking to you, those
who think posting *plonk* is amusing).

> Do I want to be associated with this list?  Not if Jeme's message
> and other messages I don't agree with fill it up with no one
> moderating for those who are vulnerable.

Since when are we responsible for your ego security?  Not that I side
with Jeme.  However, security is the responsibility of the individual.
The best way to defend yourself in this situation is to employ a
killfile.

> It's a warped view of the world that's being created which itself
> arguably gives the list a bad reputation.

PLUG works like an old-skool net community.  One of the points the net
used to be able to pride itself with is remarkable self-regulation.

> I don't agree with this ultra liberal view that a community should
> not take responsibility to keep a discussion list it hosts within
> it's mission statement.

First of all, welcome to the 'net, a perfect demonstration that
communism (as in, a cooperative anarchy) on a grand scale can work,
just not with the commodities of life.  You will encounter a very
live-and-let-live attitude while online.  If you're not comfortable
with this, stay to the mainstream where you're not expected to think
for yourself or form an opinion of your own.  If a dictatorship isn't
your bag, then lighten up and take the killfile option.

This really is a personal preference issue.  This, and not spam, is
why email sorting and filtering was originally created.

> Libraries have standards of conduct for patrons, is this such an
> alien concept?

Meatspace doesn't have the capabilities to tune out outside noise like
killfiles, either.

* Michael C. Robinson <michael at robinson-west.com> [031129 17:34]:
>  
> Sorry, I don't buy the bit that restrictions are the ultimate enemy to
> having a successfull community.  Communism was implemented as a
> totalitarian system in Russia: the state took care of you, distributed
> the wealth in a non democratic fashion, owned all the property, and
> totally banned religion.  Isn't Stalin Saddham's hero?  Anarachy doesn't
> encourage people to come together which is divisive to groups, clubs,
> societies...  I strongly question the opinion some seem to be trying
> to push that Godlessness is the way to go and that anything goes because
> this is the Internet.  If the Internet is a monster, this monster ought

Interesting line of reasoning above. You start with Communism - which
was never implemented in Russia by the Soviet leaders' own admission.
Officially the Soviet Union was a socialist society with a goal of
becoming a true communist nation - in reality, arguments could be made
that it ranged from a dictatorship to an oligarchy.

Religion totally banned? I seem to recall that the Russian Orthodox
Church openly collaborated with the Soviet government in order to secure
its position as the only Soviet state recognized and supported religion.

Yes, by many accounts Saddam Hussein admired and tried to pattern his
rule after Joseph Stalin (and not after Osama bin Laden or the Taliban).
So? Stalin was a monster, and Hussein was a petty tyrant. Those facts
(or perhaps opinions) don't have anything to do with your argument.

And then you bring up Anarchy, and then Godlessness? Does any of this
have anything remotely to do with the question of whether the PLUG
mailing list should be moderated?

Tell us, Michael, do you think the question of list moderation should be
decided by some sort of democratic process? Would you be satisfied if
this was decided one way or the other by the wishes of majority of those
subscribed to this list, or should what is best for everyone be decided
by some smaller group, or perhaps an individual?

do this,

$ /lib/libc.so.6
GNU C Library stable release version 2.2.5, by Roland McGrath et al.
Copyright (C) 1992-2001, 2002 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
This is free software; see the source for copying conditions.
There is NO warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A
PARTICULAR PURPOSE.
Compiled by GNU CC version 2.96 20000731 (Red Hat Linux 7.3 2.96-113).
Compiled on a Linux 2.4.9-9 system on 2003-11-05.
Available extensions:
	GNU libio by Per Bothner
	crypt add-on version 2.1 by Michael Glad and others
	The C stubs add-on version 2.1.2.
	linuxthreads-0.9 by Xavier Leroy
	BIND-8.2.3-T5B
	NIS(YP)/NIS+ NSS modules 0.19 by Thorsten Kukuk
	Glibc-2.0 compatibility add-on by Cristian Gafton
	libthread_db work sponsored by Alpha Processor Inc
Report bugs using the `glibcbug' script to <bugs at gnu.org>.


or more to the point,
$ /lib/libc.so.6 |grep system
Compiled on a Linux 2.4.9-9 system on 2003-11-05.


You could always recompile glibc against your installed kernel sources to be 
absolutely sure.  So I asked my wife, who knows such things, what symptoms 
one would experience with /usr/include/linux headers not matching glibc: 
page faults and other weirdness.  If the kernel's internal data structures 
change and glibc doesn't know, system binaries and user-land apps may scream 
in alien and painful ways.

to go!  :-D

From chris-plug at maybe.net  Sat Nov 29 19:35:02 2003
From: chris-plug at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Sat Nov 29 19:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NFS write performance?
In-Reply-To: <86smk7cz6k.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86smk7cz6k.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <20031130033437.GG3005@maybe.net>

On Sat, Nov 29, 2003 at 01:16:19AM -0800, Russell Senior wrote:
> 
> What kind of NFS(v3) write performance should I expect over a 100 Mbit
> ethernet?  I'll stipulate that the server is a PII-400 x 2cpu, client
> is faster.

First of all, thanks for making me get off my ass and finish LDAP/KRB5
integration on my client box so I could test all this for you. ;-)

Write performance can vary for a number of parameters. Principally,
sync/async will affect write performance. However, async can be
dangerous, it can degrade performance with respect to usage patterns
involving lots of small files, and most importantly: nfs3 wouldn't mount
with it. :-) But Linux' nfs server is notorious for be "less" than, say,
the well-regarded Solaris server. Anyhoo. Other parameters involving
performance affect read performance, too.

Here we go.

Configuration details:

Host   - Dual P3-Xeon 500/2MB, Alteon Fibre Gigabit, 3x120GB hardware RAID5
Client - Dual P3-Xeon 500/1MB, Alteon Fibre Gigabit

File-system was formatted using reiserfs, originally. Fibre was
connected back-to-back.

Socket buffer limits were lifted dramatically, thusly:

echo 262144 > /proc/sys/net/core/rmem_max
echo 262144 > /proc/sys/net/core/wmem_max

(With this option, you can specify, e.g., socket buffers in samba of
128K [or higher] and get rather impressive performance boost. There are
cases where this may not be optimal or safe, depending on [especially]
hardware and usage patterns -- it is, however, a must for gigabit
environments.)

I also increased MTU to 6000, but this is a feature of optical gigabit,
to enable Jumbo Frame support.

Testing methodology was to attempt to keep a relatively consistent
environment while performing bonnie benchmarks from the client. Per-
char benchmarks were omitted as were file-oriented benchmarks. These are
both very important, but they take a lot of time to perform this many
times. ;-)

A "local" score is provided to show bonnie performance on the host
machine without going through nfs. Additionally, hdparm -t rates this
array at 22MB/sec.

It is very important to understand that it doesn't matter how fast your
network is, if your hard drive is slow. All of the following discussion
will only be made in terms of the original local score. In fact, the
network in this scenario was so fast, it was essentially removed as a
variable from consideration.

(Note that if you don't have a fixed font in your email client, that the
following will look pretty wacky.)


Version  1.03       ------Output------- --Input-- --Random-
                    --Block-- -Rewrite- --Block-- --Seeks--
Machine        Size K/sec %CP K/sec %CP K/sec %CP  /sec %CP
local            1G  8460  19  4047   5 17821  13 179.7   2
nfs2-4096            3648   6  3777  17 14575  16 141.5   3
nfs2-8192            3734   6  3690  16  9745  11 116.3   2
nfs3-4096            3790   6  4032  18 10783  13 111.9   2
nfs3-8192            3905   6  3948  18 14402  18 153.4   3
nfs3-16384           4524   7  4644  21 15889  20 184.6   4
nfs3-32768           4822   8  4744  21 17870  21 180.4   4
nfs3-65536           4664   8  4255  19 16678  20 155.6   4
nfs3-131072          5027   8  4697  21 16354  21 206.5   4
nfs3-262144          4982   8  4790  22 15424  20 164.1   4

Some things to understand: NFSv2 doesn't allow rsize/wsize buffers over
8192 (well, it does, but it is highly discouraged, and in my experience
really, really strange stuff begins to happen). Also, the rule of thumb
on Linux is that for NFSv2 your rsize/wsize should match your hardware's
page size. On ia32 this will be 4096. On most other, and particularly
64-bit architectures, this will be 8192. Note that this bears out
above -- NFSv2 benchmarks at 8192 are worse, in general. This is not
true for NFSv3. Also, remember that this system is live, so there will
be fluctuations in the above numbers. Assume that a <5% difference is
insignificant, and don't be amazed that one of the tests over NFS
outperformed the local benchmark. ;-)

I was intrigued by how NFSv3 performance actually got better as
rsize/wsize got larger. So I kept going for a while. Performance seemed
to taper out at around 32768. At this point, reads were essentially
local, although writes were still half of performance. Again, as
discussed above, this may be because of the "sync" option with regards
to the NFS server. It is entirely possible that in a similar
configuration, the client would be able to get much closer to local
performance if the host were Solaris-based. Still, 5MB/sec ain't bad.
:-)

It should be stressed again, that these numbers represent my own
environment and my own benchmarking. Your needs and results will vary.
Also, none of this really answers your question. :-) On a 100MB/sec
network, however, with actual outside traffic, I'd expect read
performance to be closer to 8MB/sec and write performance similar. Your
system is *similar* in performance to my hosts, and as long as it isn't
overly loaded (mine is oversubscribed on swap, due to UML's, for
example) you should certainly not see CPU-bound performance in any way,
whatsoever. It's your hard drive that matters.

I hope you find this useful. (As well as others.)

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

From michael at robinson-west.com  Sat Nov 29 21:35:03 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Sat Nov 29 21:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: No to moderation

> Having said that Mr Robinson needs to realize that the overall opinion
> seems to be massively against him on this issue, and he needs to drop it.
> He favors kill files, and I wouldn't be surprised to find that he appears
> in quite a few at this point.
 
I don't favor kill files.  I favor a community approach instead of
a plug that is the seedy armpit of the world.  Maybe there 
is a reason this isn't viewed as an official Linux user group 
where pdxlug.org is with it's anyone can be kicked off policy.  
If anyone gets away with posting a set of opinions out in full 
onto plug that I don't agree with it, but noone else gets a good 
counter piece out there, that lends itself to trolling on my 
part for lack of a better choice than do nothing about this
bias.

There might have been a time when a man wouldn't be
brutally attacked for saying that's not my opinion and 
I want you to know it.  Or he might get killed, but at 
least if he truly believed he was right that merits some 
admiration of his courage.  Being democratic isn't always 
helpful when it comes to people communicating affectively 
with one another.  Destroy trust and miss common ground, 
it's all over.  The greek war tragedies during some of 
their democracy experiments come to mind too.  It easier
to defeat an army if the leaders of it can't decide what
to do.

I do believe in setting a good example where I ask for 
consideration about the example that is set by what 
slips onto plug regardless of what people kill file 
or not.  If someone from outside receives the plug 
list without filtering it, what does that person get?  
Is is something to be proud to be associated with, 
or is it something where you where you wish your 
email address that shows up in your posts couldn't 
be traced to you?

* Michael C. Robinson <michael at robinson-west.com> [2003-11-29 19:44]:
> On Sat, 2003-11-29 at 18:59, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > Why should everyone else be subjected to your ideals of what should or
> > should not be talked about?
> 
> Why do corporations, schools, and small business have standards of what
> can and can't be transmitted through their electronic infrastructure?

Is this list a "corporations, schools, and small business"?? No. And it
would be a detriment to the list to run it as such. 

> Structure can help stem flame posting and make this list more 
> peaceful.

I've said it before... "In your opinion". The same structure that you
are asking for, also tends to stifle creativity.

> You don't question which side of the road to drive on
> when cars are coming the other way do you?

This isn't a road. It's a mailing list where YOU have control over what
comes into YOUR mailbox. If YOU choose to not control it, don't force
the rest of us to suffer with you. 

> If nothing is blocked but
> questionable posts are only redirected to plug-talk, it's really only a
> matter of people subscribing to both lists if they don't agree with the
> moderator.

Again, I ask. WHO should make that decision for everyone on the list? I
for one, would rather have the power to choose for myself, rather than
have someone (or a group) decide for me. 

> Right now, a majority can't vote at the plug site that a
> thread is too OT and should be stopped, this to me is something that
> really ought to be considered.

So control it on your own system, and you get exact control. You don't
have to wait for a majority to decide it's off topic (if that ever
happens). When you decide it's enough, it stops.

> Why should I be subjected to the bias of plug?

How are you? Do you not have control over exactly what comes into your
inbox? 

If you place the control into the hands of one or more moderators, then
you effectively are making yourself subjected to bias of another.

> Why should I leave because there might be a bias?  In the end I see 
> I'm not being given very many choices here.

Quite the opposite. You are given FULL control. If the list were
moderated, then you LOSE control.

> If I kill file the people who respond most
> often, I've basically left anyways.  Kill filing does offer me any
> way to say I have a problem with what someone is posting, it's just
> ignoring them.

Exactly. But you DO realize you can killfile on a name, as well as a
subject or whatever other attribute you want.

On Sat, 29 Nov 2003, Grish wrote:
> I've not actually tried it yet. But yes, I am using Maildir.
>

> attempts to open /dev/null as if it were a regular file, which of
> course, dosn't happen.

My thought was that it's trying to write to a directory called /dev/null
rather than just append data to the file.

I haven't tried it, either.

> If not because everyone gets sick of arguing it, then because somebody
> snaps and shoots Michael. ;)

Let's hope they just get tired of it, then!  Nothing funny about killing.

> Hell, if this works, I won't even see any further replies.

Woah... you'll want to read this one! (I've modified the subject line in
the hopes that you'll get this message.)

> >>Also, can anybody point to any decent procmail documentation?
> >
> >man procmail
> >man procmailrc
> >
> >Both of those are really, really good.
>
> I tend to think of man pages as references rather than howto's, but I'll
> give it a look, since I know that's not by any means universal truth. I
> hadn't thought to try procmailrc as a manpage, either. :)

Yeah, sometimes there are man pages for rc files.  They're usually pretty
good, too.

apropros (man -k) is your friend.

> Also, is there a way to reliably filter by sender? I read somewhere that
> ^From:.*<whoever> wasn't a reliable. Any truth to that?

Yes.

There's a whole section in the procmailrc manpage about varios FROM
options.  Here's the excerpt about the type I use:

       If the regular expression contains `^FROM_DAEMON' it will
       be substituted by `(^(Mailing-List:|Precedence:.*(junk
       |bulk|list)|To: Multiple recipients of |(((Resent-)?(From
       |Sender)|X-Envelope-From):|>?From )([^>]*[^(.%@a-
       z0-9])?(Post(ma?(st(e?r)?|n)|office)|(send)?Mail(er)?
       |daemon|m(mdf|ajordomo)|n?uucp|LIST(SERV|proc)|NETSERV
       |o(wner|ps)|r(e(quest|sponse)|oot)|b(ounce|bs\.smtp)|echo
       |mirror|s(erv(ices?|er)|mtp(error)?|ystem)
       |A(dmin(istrator)?|MMGR|utoanswer))(([^).!:a-z0-9][-_a-
       z0-9]*)?[%@>\t ][^<)]*(\(.*\).*)?)?$([^>]|$)))', which
       should catch mails coming from most daemons (how's that
       for a regular expression :-).

So there you go.  Use '^FROM_DAEMON' instead of 'From:'.

J.

On Sat, 2003-11-29 at 21:37, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> No no no.  I oppose kill files and favor a community filter
> that everyone can shape through voting

Ok... this may not be my last post in response to your threads, Michael,
but this is the last night I'm reading them - if I see more crap like
this tomorrow, you're going to /dev/null with our other troll.

As far as I can see, what you're asking for is the police.  Now, I am
all in favor of the police for a large public.  We don't, however, need
List Police.  In small communities, there are these things called
'norms' ... unofficial rules we most all abide by.  They aren't written
down.  There's no formal enforcement.  If you violate the norms, you end
up in killfiles.

What you seem to want is a system of punishments for individuals you
disagree with.  This ain't cool for something like a mailing list.  When
we're talking about people behaving recklessly or doing harm to one
another, then a system of punishments probably makes sense.  If we're
discussing technical topics on a mailing list and somebody gets off
topic (gee, like this thread?) such a system is way overboard.  Why
punish when you can make the offender vanish for you?

I believe the outcry against your idea has shown PLUG doesn't want
moderation.  If you feel there needs to be some Newbie-friendly LUG
mailing list that's all moderated, see if PDXLUG is close enough for
you... and if not, start your own LUG.  More power to you.

If you're getting sick of posters here, GET RID OF THEM!  That's what I
do.  You're going to be gone if you keep up with this bullshit.

Adios.  Sleep well.

Rob

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Nov 30 08:47:01 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun Nov 30 08:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Do it yourself moderation
In-Reply-To: <20031130031202.12224.92651.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20031130031202.12224.92651.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20031130164530.GA9463@gate.kl-ic.com>

Michael Robinson wants a moderated PLUG list.  There is a very easy
way to do this.  He can start another mailing list, moderate it 
himself, and include and exclude any posting he pleases.  If he wants to
talk about his classes, textbooks, gays, communism, CSI(?), or any other
subject that flits through his head, or exclude me or Jeme or AthlonRob
or Carla or Eric or anyone else, he is free to do that too.  He can
finance it with teeshirts - I would be proud to wear a teeshirt that
says "My Postings are Rejected by Michael Robinson".

I am a relative newcomer to this list myself, and I suppose if I was
NetGod I would design it differently.  But I'm not, and where the 
reality differs from my expectations I am learning to moderate my
expectations.  The really wonderful thing about the plug list is how
well it works with no moderation at all.  Out of dozens of lists I
have worked with over the last two decades, only one other has worked
as well, and that with occasional ejections of the obstreperous.

I read the digested list, and it is fractionally harder to killfile
Michael Robinson or Jeme Breslin.  Which has turned out OK;  every
once in a while Jeme comes up with something useful and I am glad I
haven't missed it.  As Jeme matures, his signal-to-noise ratio will
improve, and perhaps Michael Robinson's will leave the zero peg
where it is now.  So un-moderated has my vote;  I want to be present
when Michael finally has something useful to say, or when he learns
that is is his infantile behavior rather than some defect in the entire
rest of the world that brings on the relatively restrained criticism
he finds so objectionable.

The most important thing anyone here can do to improve the quality of
the plug list they read is improve the quality of their own postings.  
If Michael Robinson wants to see a better list, he has a lot of 
opportunities completely under his own control.  And if, with the
impatience of immature youth, he wants a better list "right now only",
he is free to moderate his own.

And thanks to all the rest of you that have shown remarkable restraint
in discussing this.  I think I will let it go with this posting (which
follows a private one to M.R.), as this discussion will never end until
M.R.  feels he has had the last word.  Let him have it, because his own
words do more to scuttle the idea moderation than anything the rest of
us can do.

Keith

>>>>> "Brent" == Brent Rieck <bsr at spek.org> writes:

Brent> Steve Bonds wrote:
>> The W3 validator is so easy to use that there's really no excuse to have
>> invalid HTML.

Brent> Uh okay, sure.  Unfortunately a PITA to use for any kind of web
Brent> application - does anybody know of any tools to make things like this

Once you learn the rules, validation is trivial.  Every one of the things
I saw as errors on WVLUG, I could have found without the validator.

The problem is, most people don't learn the rules.  They just jiggle
the handle until the flushing noise stops (as in, it looks good in their
error-correcting browser).

Learn the rules.  Validation is trivial after that.  Get the coding
right, upload your site to your staging area (you *do* have one of
those, right?)  and then use the validator as a final check.  You
should never get any surprises at validation time.

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Sun Nov 30 11:29:33 2003
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Sun Nov 30 11:29:33 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Moderation?
In-Reply-To: <20031130041010.GA11331@bavariati.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0311301046260.18623-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Sat, 29 Nov 2003, Aaron Burt wrote:

> On Sat, Nov 29, 2003 at 06:57:11PM -0800, D. Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> > To the question of moderation on the PLUG mailing list; why don't we
> > simply call a vote?
>
> Who gets to moderate?  It's an onerous duty.

Give the man a cigar. Or a CD containing his favorite distro.

The problems with moderating any list are as follows:

* Someone has to read every post. That would be a full-time job, & most
likely an unpaid full-time job. Which leads to the next point,

* Eventually people & subject lines will be automatically banned. No
matter how it is done, eventually for the sake of saving time the
moderator will end up doing this.

At the best, this will be an incovenience: because a thread with the
subject line "A Newbie's Question about Sendmail", newbies will find it
difficult to ask about Sendmail. At worst, it will lead to a nasty
fight when Ezekiel Nutjob [1] is banned because of his insistence that
one cannot know about Linux unless one has the proper understanding of
how the Greys from Rigel IV were involved in the Kennedy Assassination.

* Another problem is the possibility that a moderator will act
arbitrarily to promote her/his own agenda, for example banning all
questions about BSD or Slackware as ``irrelevant". If one is donating
long hours to this task, the temptation will rear its ugly head.

I'm sure there are other problems that can be mentioned (Eric Harrison
mentioned a very good one above: loss of alternative, & potentially
valuable viewpoints), but the existence of an unmoderated mailling list
leads to the issue of filtering one's inbox.

I see this as a valuable right of every individual. While everyone has
Freedom of Speech -- including Ezekiel Nutjob -- everyone also has the
complementry right Not to Listen. (And if you disagree with this, when
was the last time you read word of the spam you received?)

Having said all of that, I'm about to discuss something that probably
has been in the back of everyones' minds here.

If it should happen that someone is so interfering with this maillist
that its survival is endangered, obviously that person will be banned
from this maillist. That having been said, I (for one) don't see it
happening yet, & I hope (for one) that it doesn't happen without
an overt discussion & clear warnings to the person in question.

Some may see this as a warning; I mean this as stating a simple fact.
If a subscriber's MTA starts an uncontrolled spew of gibberish onto
the PLUG list, that subscriber would obviously be banned. If you accept
that premise, then it follows if a subscriber's contributions keep
us from discussing Linux, UNIX, & related topics, then that subscriber
will be banned.

I don't want to go down that road -- now or ever. But we can.
I hope all of us consider things like netquette, reasonableness, &
politeness as we continue to contribute to this mailing list, otherwise
we will find ourselves going down that road.

</mode=soap box>
>
> Could we go back to arguing about SUVs please?

Was there a discussion about this? Can someone tell me (off-list, please)
what the conclusion was, & what was the name of the thread?

Geoff

[1] Fictious name & example selected in order not to implicate any
individual. Google for usenet kooks for real-life examples of off-topic
posters who either were banned, or led to maillists or newsgroups being
moderated.

like Usenet to generate random data?  It has to be a huge pool of entropy.  
Perhaps the alt.binaries.* lists should be avoided, but mailing lists and 
non-binary news groups should have significant entropy.  I guess you'd also 
want to remove all quoted material (repetition can't be that good for the 
entropy level).

You wouldn't get very many bits of entropy per message, but you'd have so much 
raw data!
